div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p:
THis Learned and uÅ¿efull View of both the Lawes, once more adventureth it Å¿elfe upon the Opinion of Men, and it may now hope to receive a more indifferent cenÅ¿ure then before, as being committed to a Å¿eaÅ¿on more mature, and more perfectly diÅ¿pos'd; for howÅ¿oever the Time that firÅ¿t brought this forth, could not be charged with any notable diÅ¿temper; yet the Common-wealth wee live in is of that thriving nature, that however the preÅ¿ent time may Å¿till bee good, yet it alwayes makes the Å¿ucceeding Age better then it Å¿elfe. This argues the State not neare her ruine, though Å¿ome unruly Spirits, led by an irregular Motion, have beene bold to anticipate; as if every one that bad Å¿o much pitty as to feare, had alÅ¿o judgement
enough to foreÅ¿ee the ruine of a Kingdome. 'Twas more then enough for Å¿uch Men to Å¿et downe the Fate of a Å¿ingle-Å¿oule, without reÅ¿olving upon the doome of a whole Nation. But theÅ¿e that would Å¿eeme to know Å¿uch high things, are moÅ¿t properly puniÅ¿hed by being neglected: for to a Man that would bee thought to know, and knoweth not, no greater miÅ¿erie can happen, then that hee Å¿hould faile of his Expectation. If I were to Å¿erve or follow any time, I would propoÅ¿e the PreÅ¿ent, which as it hath leÅ¿Å¿e of the pretences of former Ages, Å¿o it hath much more of the Moderation: and if it needs muÅ¿t be Å¿uÅ¿pected that the State is not farre from her fall, let this be the onely reaÅ¿on, becauÅ¿e Å¿he draweth Å¿o neere to her perfection. That which heretofore moÅ¿t of all incumbred theÅ¿e Dominions, was the diÅ¿proportion of the Civill Power to the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall. This a Great Prince abated, and the Act was truly maÅ¿culine, yet like thoÅ¿e of the Å¿trongeÅ¿t importance, would not be perfected by the Å¿ame hand; therefore it was by him Å¿o fully done, on the one Å¿ide, that it might be feared leÅ¿t it Å¿hould runne over on the other. To prevent this, the diÅ¿cretion of theÅ¿e late diÅ¿cerning times hath warily provided; the wiÅ¿edome of the Prince
having Å¿o well tempered both the Powers, that it may now be hoped, they Å¿hall agree one with an other as both doe in him, by a glorious correÅ¿pondence. The State thus bending towards the beÅ¿t, and thÃ© moÅ¿t perfect mediocrity, this Author whoÅ¿e hope that alwayes was, couldnot but revive again; therefore it is, that though hee be dead, hee yet Å¿peaketh. If Å¿till there be that will reprehend theÅ¿e our paines, as if they were caÅ¿t upon a man too much Å¿ought after, be it Å¿o; but theÅ¿e men have leaÅ¿t cauÅ¿e to complaine, for if the matter of this Booke be, as they Å¿uppoÅ¿e, then the onely way to Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿e it will be to make it common, for things of that nature are leaÅ¿t of all enquired for, when they are moÅ¿t eaÅ¿ily to be found; but if they rarely appeare, they are more eagerly Å¿ought after, and the more obÅ¿tinately eÅ¿teem'd.

VVhen first I would Å¿ee this TreatiÅ¿e, I beheld it at a distance, and not without Å¿ome prejudice; for Å¿o I was prompted by the inÅ¿inuations of a fallible Report; but finding it under the Protection of the High and Mighty Prince Iames, I tooke libertie to reÅ¿olve against all popular contradiction. For a Note or two, which I have here and there timerouÅ¿ly let fall, If the Reader expect that I Å¿hould aske his pardon; there may bee cauÅ¿e, but there is no convenience: for this kinde of Complement is now adayes indifferently Å¿et before thoÅ¿e things that are well, and thoÅ¿e that are ill done. BeÅ¿ides, it would argue Certaine follie, to be engaged there for pardon, where our choyce is to offend. VVhat I have here done amiÅ¿Å¿e, I Å¿hall hereafter hope to rectifie, either by doing Å¿omething that Å¿hall be better (if that may be) or (which is the Å¿afeÅ¿t way) by doing Å¿o no more.

div.head: TO THE HIGH AND Mighty Prince IAMES, by the grace of God, King of Great Britaine, France and Ireland, Defender of the Faith, &c.
div.p:
MOST gratious Soveraigne, Å¿ince it hath pleaÅ¿ed Your MajeÅ¿tie of Your Princely care towards the Church, and Your Common-wealth, to take knowledge of Å¿ome differences that are in Iudicature betweene Your EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall and Civile Law, and the Temporall Law of this Land (by which joyntly Your MajeÅ¿ties State is managed next after Your owne moÅ¿t rare providence, and the wiÅ¿dome of Å¿uch, whom it hath pleaÅ¿ed Your HighneÅ¿Å¿e to aÅ¿Å¿ociate unto Your Å¿elfe in the great affaires of Your Kingdome) I have been bold to offer unto Your MajeÅ¿tie this Å¿imple TreatiÅ¿e, as that which doth lay out the cauÅ¿e of thoÅ¿e Differences, more particularly than
any man hitherto hath expreÅ¿Å¿ed the Å¿ame. In comming to which (becauÅ¿e I doe Å¿peake for thoÅ¿e parts of Your MajeÅ¿ties Lawes, which are leÅ¿Å¿e knowne unto Your people, and eÅ¿teemed no otherwiÅ¿e of them, than they Å¿ee the practice thereof to bee here within Your Land) I have thought good, as it were in a Briefe, to Å¿et out the whole Å¿umme of both the Lawes, to the view of the people, that they may Å¿ee, there is more worth in thoÅ¿e for whom I Å¿peake, than was by many conceived to bee: So that the profeÅ¿sion of the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall and Civile Law may appeare to the world, neither to bee idle nor unfit for the State; Å¿o farre as it hath pleaÅ¿ed the Royall PredeceÅ¿Å¿ours of Your HighneÅ¿Å¿e to give entertainment unto it, and Your MajeÅ¿tie Your Å¿elfe to admit of it. In all which there is no other thing Å¿ought, than that Å¿uch greevances as have beene of late offered by one IuriÅ¿diction unto the other, and in conÅ¿equence, to all Your Subjects, who follow any Å¿uits in the Civile or EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Courts, may by Your Princely wiÅ¿dome be conÅ¿idered, and by Your authoritie be redreÅ¿Å¿ed, if they be found to be
greevances indeed: for now as things are, neither IuriÅ¿diction knowes their owne bounds, but one Å¿natcheth from the other, in maner, as in a batable ground lying betweene two Kingdomes; but Å¿o, that the weaker ever goeth to the worÅ¿e, and that which is mightier prevailes againÅ¿t the other: the profeÅ¿Å¿ors thereof being rather willing to give Lawes and interpretations to other, than to take or admit of any againÅ¿t themÅ¿elves. For which, the weaker appeales unto your HighneÅ¿Å¿e, humbly deÅ¿iring Your MajeÅ¿ties upright and Å¿incere Iudgement to diÅ¿cerne where the wrong is, and to redreÅ¿Å¿e it accordingly, which is a worke worthy Your MajeÅ¿ties high conÅ¿ideration. For as the Land is Yours, Å¿o alÅ¿o the Sea is Yours, and the Church is under Your HighneÅ¿Å¿e protection, as a Childe is under his Tutor; Å¿o that all the Lawes thereof appertaine unto Your MajeÅ¿ties care & comfort alike: For which, not onely the whole profeÅ¿sion of Your EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall and Civile Lawyers that now are, but thoÅ¿e which Å¿hall Å¿ucceed in thoÅ¿e places for ever hereafter unto the worlds end, will praiÅ¿e and magnifie
Your MajeÅ¿ties gratious favour towards them, and wee that now are will pray to God for the long and happie proÅ¿peritie of Your HighneÅ¿Å¿e, and Your PoÅ¿teritie over us, during the continuance of this Heaven and this Earth, and after the paÅ¿sing away thereof, a perpetuall fruition of the new Heaven and the new Earth, wherein righteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e onely Å¿hall dwell for ever.

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p:
GEntle Reader, I confeÅ¿Å¿e, as I meditated this TreatiÅ¿e upon mine owne motion (as I doe Å¿omtimes matters of other argument, when my leaÅ¿ure Å¿erves mee thereto) Å¿o alÅ¿o I doe not Å¿et it out to the view of the world upon mine owne motion, but was deÅ¿irous it Å¿hould have beene kept in, Å¿aving that I muÅ¿t obey where I am bound. The thing that gave mee cauÅ¿e to this meditation, was, that I Å¿aw many times how meanly men eÅ¿teemed of the Civile and EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law of this Land, valuing them by the practice of Å¿o much of them, as we have among us. And therefore I thought good, although not wholly to unfold the riches of them, yet to make Å¿hew of them folded up, in Å¿uch Å¿ort as Mercers make Å¿hew of their Å¿ilkes and velvets, laid up in whole peeces in their Å¿hops; whereby it may bee Å¿eene, what great variety they have of all theÅ¿e kinde of wares, although the goodneÅ¿Å¿e of the ware it Å¿elfe cannot be diÅ¿cerned, becauÅ¿e it is foulded up: BeÅ¿ides, Å¿eeing how frequent prohibitions are in theÅ¿e dayes in cauÅ¿es of either cogniÅ¿ance more than have beene in former time, I thought it not unworthy my labour to inquire and Å¿ee upon what juÅ¿t grounds they are raiÅ¿ed up in this multitude; not of any humour I have, to gaineÅ¿ay the lawfull proceedings of any Court (which I reverence and moÅ¿t readily acknowledge their authoritie in all things belonging to their place) but to know and Å¿earch out the truth of thoÅ¿e Å¿uggeÅ¿tions that give cauÅ¿e unto theÅ¿e prohibitions. For whenas Å¿uch Lawes as are written of theÅ¿e buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿es, are written indifferently, as well for the one IuriÅ¿diction as the other, no man is to be offended if the one IuriÅ¿diction, finding it Å¿elfe preÅ¿
Å¿ed by the partiall interpretation (as it Å¿uppoÅ¿eth) of the other, inquire the ground of Å¿uch interpretation, and labour to redreÅ¿Å¿e it if it may be, by the right interpretation thereof: To the end, that either IuriÅ¿diction may retaine their owne right, and not the one bee overtopt by the other, as it Å¿eemeth to be at this day: And that in Å¿uch matters (as they concerne) of their owne right, as depend of no other authoritie but of the Prince alone: which is the thing onely that is Å¿ought in this little TreatiÅ¿e. And therefore the Reverend Iudges of this Land are to be intreated, that they will vouchÅ¿afe an equall interpretation of theÅ¿e matters, as well to the one IuriÅ¿diction as the other, for Å¿o it is comely for them to doe; and if they doe it not, the other are not Å¿o dull-Å¿enced, but they can perceive it, nor Å¿o daunted, but that they can flie for Å¿uccour unto him, to whoÅ¿e high place and wiÅ¿dome, the deciding of theÅ¿e differences doth of right appertaine. PENELOPE is Å¿aid to have had many wooers comely in perÅ¿on and eloquent in Å¿peech, but Å¿hee reÅ¿pected none but her owne ULYSSES: Such Å¿hould be the minde of a Iudge, that whatÅ¿oever other appearance or Å¿hew of truth be offered, one Å¿aying, This is the true Å¿ence of the Law, and an other that; yet the Iudge Å¿hould reÅ¿pect none but the very true germane and genuine Å¿ence thereof indeed. Which if it were religiouÅ¿ly or indifferently obÅ¿erved in every Court, then needed not this complaint that now is, but every IuriÅ¿diction Å¿hould peaceably hold his owne right, Å¿uch as the Prince, Law, or CuÅ¿tome hath afforded unto it.

SECT. 1.

argument.p: The DiviÅ¿ion of the whole booke into foure parts.

div.p:
BEfore I Å¿hew how neceÅ¿Å¿ary it is for his MajeÅ¿tie and the Realme, to maintaine the Civile & EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Lawes, as they are now practiÅ¿ed among us in this Realm, I will Å¿et downe, as it were, in a briefe, what the Civile, and the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Lawes are: then will I Å¿hew how farre forth they are here in uÅ¿e and practiÅ¿e among us: thirdly wherein wee are abridged, and put beÅ¿ide the uÅ¿e and poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion thereof, by the Common Law, even contrary to the old practiÅ¿e thereof, and the true Å¿ence and meaning of the Lawes of this Realme, and the Statutes in this behalfe provided: and
laÅ¿tly, wherein we might be releeved and admitted to the practiÅ¿e of many things in the Civile Law, without prejudice to the Common Law; and Å¿o both the Lawes might know their owne grounds and proper Å¿ubjects, and not one to be jumbled with the other, as it is at this day, to the great vexation of the Subject. But before I Å¿peake of the Civile Law in particular, I will define what Right, or What Law is. Law is, in generall: Law therefore is (as Æ²lpian Å¿aith, L. 10. in fin. ff. de JuÅ¿ticia & Jure) the knowledge of Civile and humane things, the underÅ¿tanding of thoÅ¿e things which are juÅ¿t and unjuÅ¿t. This Law is primarily divided into the Law publick, and the Law private. The 1. Jus publicum. publick, is that which appertaineth to the generall Å¿tate of the common-wealth, for I meane the Law publick, not in reÅ¿pect of the Forme, that they were publickly made, as we make lawes in our Parliaments (for Å¿o all the Civile Law is publick, as made by publick authority) but in reÅ¿pect of the object, or end thereof, for that they concerne the Church, the Clergie, the MagiÅ¿trate, and other like publick functions, none of which levell at the rule of equity, or equality between man and man, as private lawes doe, but ayme at that which is moÅ¿t fit, ingenerall, for the common State. 2. Jus privatum.

The private Law, or the private mens Law, is that which concernes every Å¿ingular mans Å¿tate; which, for that it is occupied in giving every man his owne, it muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿itie be proportionable to the rule of Equitie and JuÅ¿tice.
Private Law is of three Å¿orts, the law of Nature, the law of Nations, and the law Civile.

The law of Nature, is that which Nature hath taught every living creature, as the care and defence of every The Law of Nature. creatures life, deÅ¿ire of libertie, the conjunction of male and female for procreation Å¿ake.

The law of Nations, is that which common reaÅ¿on hath eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed among men, and is obÅ¿erved alike in all Nations, The Law of Nations. as diÅ¿tinctions of mens rights, buildings of houÅ¿es,
erecting of Cities, Å¿ocietie of life, judgements of controverÅ¿ies, war, peace, captivity, contracts, obligations, Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ion, and the like.

The law Civile, being largely taken, is the law that every particular Nation frameth to it Å¿elfe, as the Athenian 3. Jus Civile lawes, and the lawes of Lacedaemon, in which Å¿ence alÅ¿o, the law of England may be called the Civile law, for that it is the proper and private law of this Nation: but in more Å¿trict Å¿ort, the Civile law is the law, which the old Romans uÅ¿ed, and is for the great wiÅ¿dom & equitie therof, at this day, as it were, the common law of all well governed Nations, a very few onely excepted.

And certainly, albeit Å¿undry other Nations by the light of Nature, have many Rules and Maximes in the Civile law: yet, if all the conÅ¿titutions, cuÅ¿tomes, and lawes, of all other people and countries were put together (I except none, Å¿ave the lawes of the Hebrews, which came immediatly from God) they are not comparable to the law of the Romans, neither in wiÅ¿dome nor equitie, neither in gravitie nor in Å¿ufficiency. Whereupon it is, that moÅ¿t of other Nations, (Å¿aving our owne) although they receive not the Civile law wholely for their law, yet they Å¿o much admire the equitie thereof, that they interpret their owne lawes thereby. div.head: SECT. 2.

argument.p: That there be foure Tomes of the Civile Law; The DigeÅ¿t, the Code, the Authentick and the Feuds.

THe whole Civile law it Å¿elfe, is reduced or brought into 4. Tomes, whereof the firÅ¿t containeth the DigeÅ¿t or Pandects, taken out of 27. old reverent Lawyers

The DigeÅ¿ts have their name, of that they are put into a comely order by the Author, ranging every booke and why Å¿o called. title into his proper place, Å¿uch as either the courÅ¿e of Nature affords them, or are fitteÅ¿t for the practice of the profeÅ¿Å¿ion.

VPon a more particular diviÅ¿ion, the whole DigeÅ¿t is divided into Å¿even parts: whereof the firÅ¿t part, Å¿tanding upon foure bookes, containeth the principles, and as it were, the firÅ¿t elements of the Law; as, what JuÅ¿tice & Right is, from whence the Civile Law hath his beginning, what perÅ¿ons be the object of the Civile law, what MagiÅ¿trates the common-wealth of the Romans had, by whom either the lawes were made, or executed: the divers kindes of JuriÅ¿dictions, which thoÅ¿e MagiÅ¿trates uÅ¿ed; Meere, Mixt, or Simple, according to their place: the corrections which the law uÅ¿ed againÅ¿t Å¿uch as diÅ¿obey the Judge, either in not appearing, or not performing that which is injoyned them: what proviÅ¿ion it made againÅ¿t Å¿uch, as by violence reÅ¿cued men out of the Judges hands: what Holy-dayes there were, wherein the Courts were not held: what order the Law tooke againÅ¿t the plaintife, that having cited the defendant, had no Libell ready to put into the Court, unleÅ¿Å¿e happely otherwiÅ¿e the parties upon private agreement compounded the matter betweene them: who were to be admitted advocates, and what cauÅ¿es barr'd them from the office: what is the office of a Procurator, Sollicitor, or Sindict, or Factor; and under what cautions they were admitted, if they had no Proxie, or Mandat, or the partie principall did not in preÅ¿ence authorize them: how they were puniÅ¿hed, who upon reward tooke upon them to vexe men unjuÅ¿tly in the Law, in manner as common Bar â¢â¢ o â¢ s ãâã : what perÅ¿ons having loÅ¿t opportunitie to alleage any thing for themÅ¿elves
beneficiall in Law, may be reÅ¿tored thereunto againe; as Minors, and Å¿uch other, as by feare or craft of the adverÅ¿arie have beene driven away from their lawfull defence: how perÅ¿ons of common truÅ¿t, as Marriners, Inholders, and Å¿uch lik, are bound by Law to reÅ¿tore Å¿uch things as they have taken in charge to keepe.

THe Å¿eventh and laÅ¿t part being divided into Å¿ixe Bookes, treateth of Obligations, which Å¿tand in words, and their effect: how farre two or more principall debtors are bound to the creditor in the whole, or every one for his owne part: Of Suerties, and how farre they are bound, and whether the diÅ¿charge of the one be the releaÅ¿e of the other, and by how many wayes Obligations by words are diÅ¿Å¿olved or releaÅ¿ed, by renovation, by payment, by acceptation

Criminall Judgements are private or publick, that is, they are commenced either upon private offences, or upon publick faults and Å¿uits. Private offences concerne private mens revenge and injuries. Publick, the revenge or injurie of the whole Å¿tate. Private offences which had ordinary proceedings, and ordinary puniÅ¿hment, were many, among whcih Private offences. argument.p: The Å¿econd Volume of the Civile Law, is the Code, which is diÅ¿tributed into twelve Booke.
Why the Code is Å¿o called.

div.p:
THe Å¿econd Tome of the Law, is the Code, and Å¿tands in twelve Books, whereof eight, for the Titles, follow in a manner the order of the DigeÅ¿t, a few titles onely excepted, which are added, beÅ¿ides thoÅ¿e of the DigeÅ¿t; but as for the foure other, which are the firÅ¿t, the tenth, the eleventh, and the twelfth; although the Å¿ubject they treat of be named in the DigeÅ¿t; yet the things which are there named, are not handled in the DigeÅ¿t; and therefore will I paÅ¿Å¿e over thoÅ¿e eight other, leÅ¿t happely I might Å¿eeme to doe one thing twice, and therefore will I referre the Reader over to that which hath beene Å¿aid of them before, in the handling of the DigeÅ¿t; for they are almoÅ¿t twinnes of one mother; Å¿o that whoÅ¿oever knowes the one, Å¿hall with no great difficulty diÅ¿cerne the other,
and come to the other foure; yet not mentioned there: But yet before I lay open the matter thereof, I will in a word or two Å¿hew why this Volume of the Law is called the Code, who is the author thereof, and out of whom it was collected, what moved the author, after Å¿o many learned titles Å¿et downe before, of Å¿uch things as are in the DigeÅ¿t deduced, by Å¿uch a number of worthy Lawyers (as the Lawes of the DigeÅ¿t themÅ¿elves doe by their inÅ¿criptions Å¿hew; for every law, carrieth with him in his forehead, the name of his Author) to make a new flouriÅ¿h of the Å¿ame, and what the knowledge of the Code doth conferre unto a Student or practiÅ¿er of the Law, more than the knowledge of the DigeÅ¿t doth.

The Code therefore is named of the word Caudex, that is, the trunke or timber of the tree, from which the barke of the tree is pill'd or pull'd off, of which men anciently uÅ¿ed to make writing-tables, artificially binding them up into the forme of a booke, and uÅ¿ing them for bookes, before the uÅ¿e of paper or parchment was knowne; inÅ¿omuch, as many of theÅ¿e tables being bound together, they were called a Code, or booke: beÅ¿ides, whereas the ancient Lawyers Why this Tome of the Law is called the Code. before JuÅ¿tinians time, uÅ¿ed to write their pleas and anÅ¿wers in Å¿croules of paper or parchment, JuÅ¿tinian himÅ¿elfe firÅ¿t put them in a booke, and therefore termed them by the name of a Code.

The Code it Å¿elfe is compiled of the anÅ¿wers of 56. Emperours, and their wiÅ¿e Councell, whereof Å¿undry were What the Code is. learned and skilfull Lawyers, as the Å¿torie of that time doth Å¿hew, and the lawes themÅ¿elues doe name Å¿ome of them, as that moÅ¿t excellent and famous man Papinian, and Å¿ome others; that is, from the dayes of Adrian the Emperour, unto the age of JuÅ¿tinian himÅ¿elfe.

The cauÅ¿e that moved JuÅ¿tinian hereto, was, that in the The reaÅ¿on which moved the Emperour to compile the Code. DigeÅ¿t hee found not every caÅ¿e decided, that fals out in common uÅ¿e of life (for how is it poÅ¿Å¿ible, when as every moment there fals out new matter, for which former lawes made no proviÅ¿ion?) and therefore thought good to Å¿upplie
that by new Lawes, which he found defective in the old: Å¿o that the multiplication of thoÅ¿e titles grew not, that the Emperour had any meaning, to fill the world with multitude of Lawes, for hee had found the inconvenience thereof already, and therefore had repealed and aboliÅ¿hed Å¿o many thouÅ¿and of old Lawes, as he had; but it came rather of that, that the multitude of cauÅ¿es were Å¿o many, that every day there fell out Å¿ome unexpected thing that was never heard of before: beÅ¿ide notwithÅ¿tanding the carefulneÅ¿Å¿e of the Emperour himÅ¿elfe, and his great Lawyer Tribonian, and others, whom he uÅ¿ed for the Å¿electing and chooÅ¿ing out of the pureÅ¿t, beÅ¿t, and moÅ¿t agreeing Lawes among themÅ¿elves, out of that indigeÅ¿ted heap of Lawes he then aboliÅ¿hed; yet they were not Å¿o quick Å¿ighted, but in that great worke, Å¿undry antinomies or contrary Lawes paÅ¿t them, which had need to be expounded and amended, and the Authors to be recited. Further, Å¿undry of ancient Lawes were Å¿o Å¿ubtilely written, that there was more wit than profit in them; Å¿o that it was expedient, the Emperour Å¿hould explain the Å¿ame, & putting all Å¿ubtility aÅ¿ide, give a right Å¿ence unto the Law. LaÅ¿tly, whereas many things were delivered by them briefly, and therefore obÅ¿curely, the Law-giver in his Princely wiÅ¿dome, Å¿et out the Å¿ame in other Lawes more plentifully and diÅ¿tinctly, all which were the chiefeÅ¿t cauÅ¿es, why the Emperour Å¿et out the booke of the Code.

The Code neither in Å¿tyle, nor in methode cometh to The difference betweene the DigeÅ¿t and the Code. the perfection of the DigeÅ¿t, as that which for the Å¿tyle is a barbarous Thracian phraÅ¿e Latinized, Å¿uch as never any mean LatiniÅ¿t Å¿pake; whereas notwithÅ¿tanding the Å¿tyle of the DigeÅ¿t is very grave and pure, and Å¿uch as doth not much differ from the cloquenteÅ¿t Å¿peech that ever the Romans uÅ¿ed; and for the methode, it hath no particular diÅ¿poÅ¿ition, other than Å¿uch as is borrowed of the DigeÅ¿t it Å¿elfe, and otherwiÅ¿e is rude and unskilfull, where it doth recede from the Å¿ame: yet doth it not lack his good uÅ¿e, for to Å¿uch as follow the practice of the law, the knowledge
of the Code is much more expedient than the knowledge of the DigeÅ¿t is, for that the lawes of the Code doe determine matters in daily uÅ¿e of life; which, becauÅ¿e they are a like in all ages (for the Å¿ame is evermore upon the Å¿tage, the perÅ¿ons a little altered) it cannot be but the learning thereof muÅ¿t be very profitable and expedient for the Common-wealth, whereas notwithÅ¿tanding the learning of the DigeÅ¿t Å¿tands rather in diÅ¿cuÅ¿Å¿ing of Å¿ubtill queÅ¿tions of the Law, and enumerations of the variety of opinions of ancient Lawyers thereupon, which have more commendation of wit, than benefit toward the common-wealth in them; but hereof hitherto.

argument.p: The Argument of the firÅ¿t Booke of the Code.

div.p:
THe firÅ¿t Booke of the Code treateth of Religion, and the Rites and Ceremonies thereto belonging, whereof I Å¿aid there was no Å¿peciall Tractate in the DigeÅ¿t, Å¿aving that it devideth the publick right into that which concernes the Church, and Church-men, and the MagiÅ¿trates of the Common-wealth, proÅ¿ecuting the later branch thereof onely, and omitting the firÅ¿t, becauÅ¿e out of that HeatheniÅ¿h Religion, which was uÅ¿ed in thoÅ¿e ancient Lawyers dayes, and thoÅ¿e Å¿uperÅ¿titious Rites, whereof their Bookes were full, nothing could be taken that might Å¿erve for our Religion: whereupon he inÅ¿tituted a new diÅ¿courÅ¿e thereof in the Code, beginning firÅ¿t with the bleÅ¿Å¿ed Trinitie, one in eÅ¿Å¿ence, and three in perÅ¿on, wherein he Å¿ets downe a briefe Å¿umme of our ChriÅ¿tian faith, agreeable to the doctrine of the Prophets, and ApoÅ¿tles, and the foure firÅ¿t generall CounÅ¿els, the Nicene, ConÅ¿tantinopolitan, EpheÅ¿ine, & Calcedon, forbidding any man publickly to diÅ¿pute, or Å¿trive thereabout, taking occaÅ¿ion upon the NeÅ¿torian hereÅ¿ie, which not long before had Å¿prung up, and had mightily infected the Church, which JuÅ¿tinian by this confeÅ¿Å¿ion of Faith Å¿o publiÅ¿hed to the whole world, and a penall Edict
joyned thereunto, hoped to repreÅ¿Å¿e: After hee hath Å¿et downe a full and Å¿ound confeÅ¿Å¿ion of the ChriÅ¿tian faith, conformable to the Primitive Church; next hee addeth a title of the holy Church it Å¿elfe, and of her priviledges, which either concerne EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall mens perÅ¿ons themÅ¿elves, or their Å¿tate and Å¿ubÅ¿tance, or the actions one EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall man had againÅ¿t an other, or with, or againÅ¿t Lay perÅ¿ons: where alÅ¿o he proÅ¿ecuteth the degrees of PrieÅ¿ts, or MiniÅ¿ters, their offices, orders, and how the Å¿ame are to be come by, (that is, without bribes or Simonie, or other worldly reÅ¿pect, Å¿ave the worth of the perÅ¿on onely) and the rights of holy places [PrieÅ¿ts in the Law are called, from the Latine, Sacerdotes, either becauÅ¿e their office was Deo Å¿aera dare, to Å¿acrifice to God; or elÅ¿e, becauÅ¿e they were conÅ¿ecrated, and as it were, Å¿evered from the reÅ¿t of the people, and given up to God: they were alÅ¿o called Elders, anÅ¿werable to the Greeke ã in non-Latin alphabet ã , either for that they were Å¿o in age, In Authent. de Å¿anct. OverÅ¿eers and Superintendents of the reÅ¿t, Å¿o called of their watchfulneÅ¿Å¿e, care, labour, and faithfulneÅ¿Å¿e in teaching the people, and doing other duties, which they owe unto the Church. [The loweÅ¿t degrees of men in the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tical Hierarchy, were the Clerkes, as the word Clericus is reÅ¿trein'd to a narrower acception. For in the generall, it is moÅ¿t properly applyed to all degrees of the Clergie, and is a terme contradiÅ¿tinct to the Laitie: and they are called Clergie, from the Greeke ã in non-Latin alphabet ã , quia de Å¿orte Domini Å¿unt, vel quia Dominus Å¿ors eÅ¿t & part Clericornm, either becauÅ¿e God is their portion and lot, or becauÅ¿e they are his; as Papias hath obÅ¿erved.] To BiÅ¿hops, PrieÅ¿ts, and other of that ranke, did appertain the care of HoÅ¿pitals, whereof Å¿ome were for Orphans, Å¿ome for Infants, Å¿ome for impotent and diÅ¿eaÅ¿ed perÅ¿ons, Å¿ome

In place next after the BiÅ¿hops themÅ¿elves, comes their power and audience; for albeit the chiefeÅ¿t office of a BiÅ¿hop, is to inÅ¿truct the people in the doctrine of the Word, and in good example of life: yet foraÅ¿much as all will not be obedient unto the Word, neither brought by the perÅ¿uaÅ¿ion thereof to good nurture, and to be kept in order, and the eminencie of the degree, wherein the BiÅ¿hops are placed, is not Å¿ufficient to keepe the people in obedience without Å¿ome power and juriÅ¿diction, and becauÅ¿e the Church it Å¿elfe is the mother and maintainer of JuÅ¿tice, therefore there is by the Emperour himÅ¿elfe, and his predeceÅ¿Å¿ours, as many as profeÅ¿Å¿ed ChriÅ¿tianity, certain peculiar juriÅ¿dictions EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall, aÅ¿Å¿igned to the BiÅ¿hops, more worthy than the Civile, over perÅ¿ons and cauÅ¿es EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall, Å¿uch as touch the Soule and ConÅ¿cience, or doe appertein to any charitable or godly uÅ¿es: and over the Laitie, Å¿o farre forth, as either the Laitie themÅ¿elves have beene content to Å¿ubmit themÅ¿elves unto their government, that is, Å¿o farre as either it concernes their Soules health, or the outward government of the Church in things decent or comely, or that it concernes poore and miÅ¿erable perÅ¿ons, Å¿uch as widowes, orphans, captives, and Å¿uch other like helpleÅ¿Å¿e people are, or where the Civile MagiÅ¿trate cannot be come by, or doth voluntarily delay judgement; in all which, anciently a BiÅ¿hop was to performe double faith and Å¿anctity; firÅ¿t of an uncorrupt Judge, and then of a holy BiÅ¿hop. div.head: SECT. 2.

argument.p: That the matters of ordinary CogniÅ¿ance are Marine, of which Å¿ome are Civill, others Criminall, and what the Civill Marine matters are; and what manner of proceedings they have.

div.p: THe matters of ordinary cogniÅ¿ance of the Civill Law here in this Land, are Marine matters, of which Å¿ome are Civill, Å¿ome are Criminall.

And firÅ¿t for the uÅ¿e of the Sea it Å¿elf; the Law holds it to be ff adlegem Rhodian. de Jactu. tot. tit. common, and that every one hath right to trade & traffique upon the Å¿ame, Å¿o that it be without the prejudice of that Prince or Land, to whom the Sea is adjoyning. The like may be Å¿aid for the Å¿hore it Å¿elfe, Å¿o that it be either for the refreÅ¿hing of themÅ¿elves with water, or victuall, or for the repayring of their Shippes, or buying any thing neceÅ¿Å¿ary thereunto, or it bee either for uttering of any commodity
they have, or buying any thing againe of the people, upon whoÅ¿e land they touch: In which caÅ¿e it were barbarous to repell any, comming in peaceable manner; albeit it may happen upon Å¿ome jealouÅ¿ie of the State, either for that it hath Å¿ome great forrain Enemy, whoÅ¿e continuall invaÅ¿ion they feare, or that the Sea coaÅ¿ts are much infeÅ¿ted with Pyrates, that in this caÅ¿e reÅ¿iÅ¿tance may be made; but when it is made manifeÅ¿t by flag of Truce, or otherwiÅ¿e, they are no other but well meaning men, they are to be entertained with all kindneÅ¿Å¿e

For Contracts in Marine cauÅ¿es, Å¿ome are contracts in deed, Å¿ome are as it were contracts: Contracts in deed are all bargaines and Å¿ales whatÅ¿oever, made betweene Merchant and Merchant for any commoditie, fraught or traffique in the Å¿hip, or any Å¿ale or bargaine made of the Å¿hip, or any thing thereto belonging, as MaÅ¿ts, cordage, anchorage, victuals, or any other thing of like nature, neceÅ¿Å¿arie for the imployment of the Å¿hip.
ThoÅ¿e things which are as it were contracts, are thoÅ¿e perpetuall rights, which are betweene the PurÅ¿er or MaÅ¿ter of the Ship, and the PaÅ¿Å¿engers, or betweene one paÅ¿Å¿enger and an other.

The perpetuall right which is betweene the PurÅ¿er or MaÅ¿ter of the Ship, and the PaÅ¿Å¿engers is, that the PurÅ¿er or MaÅ¿ter be anÅ¿werable for all Å¿uch wares or goods as are brought into the Å¿hip, whether it be delivered to himÅ¿elfe, or any of his Mariners: for he ought not onely to be iuÅ¿t and honeÅ¿t himÅ¿elfe, but alÅ¿o uÅ¿e the miniÅ¿terie of honeÅ¿t people about him; and therefore the MaÅ¿ter of the Å¿hip is no leÅ¿Å¿e bound for their perÅ¿ons than his owne. The PaÅ¿Å¿engers againe are honeÅ¿tly and readily to pay the MaÅ¿ter of the Å¿hip their fraught, and all Å¿uch other charges of dyet, and other proviÅ¿ion as they have put him to; wherein if there be any default of any Å¿ide, the Law affordes an action called Exercitoria, whereby the one or the other may be releeved.

The MaÅ¿ter of the Å¿hip is he, who hath the charge of the L ãâã . Å¿i. de exercitoria axion.
whole anchorage and government of the Å¿hip, and his office is either to let the Å¿hip to hire, or to buy and Å¿ell MerchandiÅ¿e, or to plie fares, or to provide tacle and furniture for the Å¿hip.

The PurÅ¿er, whom the Law calleth Exercitor Navis, is D. ead l. prima Â§ 16. de exersit. action. he to whom all the profit or revenue of the Å¿hip doth come, whether it be in his owne right, or in an others.

The perpetuall right that is betweene paÅ¿Å¿engers and paÅ¿Å¿engers, and Å¿aylers and paÅ¿Å¿engers is, that in caÅ¿e of ejectments, and caÅ¿ting out of goods, and other merchandiÅ¿e into the Sea in time of tempeÅ¿ts, or other dangers, by rocks or quick Å¿ands, for the lightning of the Å¿hip, becauÅ¿e it is for the common good of all that are in the Å¿hip, and the preÅ¿ervation of the reÅ¿t of the fraught of the Å¿hip, it be made up with the common contribution of all: for good reaÅ¿on it is, that they whoÅ¿e goods are Å¿aved hereby, Å¿hould againe with their goods redeeme the others loÅ¿Å¿e, according to Å¿uch proportion of goods, as they have in the Å¿hip, and the Law of the Sea allowes.

But in caÅ¿es of Ejectments, the Law of the Sea is this, (which was taken from the people of Rhodes, who in old time were great Å¿eafaring men, and diÅ¿coverers of Å¿undry countries, whoÅ¿e Rules even to this day are holden for good among all Marriners, for the great equitie and indifferencie that is in them) that as well the MaÅ¿ter or PurÅ¿er of the Å¿hip himÅ¿elfe Å¿hall contribute for the preÅ¿ervation of his Å¿hip, as alÅ¿o the paÅ¿Å¿engers for Å¿uch ware as they have in the Å¿hip, of what Å¿ort Å¿oever it be, albeit happely it be but of Å¿mall weight, as pearles, pretious Å¿tones, and Å¿uch like; and if perchance there be Å¿ome paÅ¿Å¿engers in the Å¿hip, who have no ware nor merchandiÅ¿e in it, yet becauÅ¿e themÅ¿elves are a burthen to the Å¿hip, eÅ¿timate is to be made of his or their apparell, rings, and jewels, according to which, he or they are to contribute towards the loÅ¿Å¿e of Å¿uch things as are caÅ¿t out into the Å¿ea: neither is there any thing in the whole Å¿hip excepted, Å¿ave only thoÅ¿e things which are put therein to be Å¿pent, for the common good of all, as victuals, fuell,
and Å¿uch like; for thoÅ¿e things are not brought in for any one private mans uÅ¿e, but for the benefit and Å¿ervice of all: and Å¿o much the rather, for that if victuals faile, or other like neceÅ¿Å¿aries want, every one muÅ¿t contribute thereto, or impart of that which he hath for his owne private proviÅ¿ion; but of mens owne bodies, unleÅ¿Å¿e they be Å¿ervants, there is no rate to be Å¿et, becauÅ¿e a free-mans body cannot be eÅ¿teemed.

In priÅ¿ing, eÅ¿timate is to be made as well of thoÅ¿e things which are loÅ¿t, as thoÅ¿e things which are Å¿aved, and the price is to be Å¿et downe, not for how much they were bought, but for how much they might be Å¿old, and that for the preÅ¿ent, leÅ¿t the contributors Å¿hould be overmuch charged. Now the contribution is to be made in this manner, firÅ¿t the loÅ¿Å¿e is to be Å¿et downe, then the rate of thoÅ¿e things which are Å¿aved, out of which muÅ¿t be drawne an equall portion, porportionable to the quantity of every mans goods he hath in the Å¿hip, to make up the loÅ¿Å¿e, deducting out of the loÅ¿ers goods for himÅ¿elfe, Å¿o much as is anÅ¿werable to his proportion, Å¿o that he Å¿hall neither be made a cleere Å¿aver, nor a cleere loÅ¿er, but in a certaine quantitie rateable to his part.

But this contribution is in that caÅ¿e to be made, if the Å¿hip be Å¿aved; for otherwiÅ¿e if a wrack happen, either before the ejectment, or in the ejectment, then whatÅ¿oever any of the vectors or paÅ¿Å¿engers catch, is his owne; neither is there any regard to be had of the loÅ¿Å¿e of the Å¿hip, or of the goods, unleÅ¿Å¿e perhaps afterwards they be drawne out of the Å¿ea.

BeÅ¿ide in matters of wrack, there is, as it were, a contract betweene them which have loÅ¿t their goods by Å¿hipwracke, and them upon whoÅ¿e Lands the Å¿aid goods are-driven, that the Å¿ame be reÅ¿tored to them or their heires, if they come in due time to claime the Å¿ame: and therefore it is preciÅ¿ely forbid by the Law, that no man Å¿hall meddle with Å¿uch L. ne quid. ff. de incendio, ruina, & naufragio. goods as are wrecked, and Å¿uch as are proved to have Å¿tolne any thing thereout are holden for robbers; for that Å¿uch goods being caÅ¿t on land, & recovered out of the Å¿ea, remain Å¿till his who was the owner thereof, and deÅ¿cend upon his heire, neither excheat unto the King, neither to any other whom the King hath priviledged in this behalfe. div.head: SECT. 4.

argument.p: That the things which extraordinarily belong unto the CogniÅ¿ance of the Civile Law, are of three Å¿orts, and concerning the firÅ¿t, which reÅ¿pecteth treaties betweene Prince and Prince.

div.p:
ANd thus much of the cauÅ¿es, which ordinarily doe belong unto the CogniÅ¿ance of the Civile Law within this
land. Now it followeth, that I Å¿peake Å¿omewhat of thoÅ¿e things wherein the Civile Law dealeth incidently, and by authoritie of the Prince, & is not the ordinarie object of the Civile law, howÅ¿oever otherwiÅ¿e they cannot be handÅ¿omly dealt in, but by Å¿uch as have the skill of the Civile Law.

Whereof there be three Å¿orts, the firÅ¿t is matters of forrein treatie betweene one Prince and another; the Å¿econd is the ordering of martiall cauÅ¿es, whether they be Civile or Criminall in an Army; the laÅ¿t is the Judgements of EnÅ¿ignes and Armes, and the deciÅ¿ions for challenges of rights of Honour and precedencie, where any of them is in controverÅ¿ie.

For the firÅ¿t, whereas all other Nations in compaÅ¿Å¿e round about us be governed by the Civile Law, and treaties are to be decided by Law (both for thoÅ¿e things which are in queÅ¿tion, and to be concluded by Law, and for thoÅ¿e things which are determined by conÅ¿ultation and agreed upon) who is thereto to be choÅ¿en rather than a Civilian, to whom their law is knowne, as well as to themÅ¿elves: and if perhaps he underÅ¿tand not their language; yet hee underÅ¿tandeth that language wherein the lawes themÅ¿elves are written, and is the fitteÅ¿t tongue for treatiÅ¿es betweene Princes and Princes, becauÅ¿e it is a common tongue to the learned of all the WeÅ¿t part of the world, and thereby every Prince Å¿hall reteine his owne MajeÅ¿tie in parlying, as it were, in his owne language, and not be forced to Å¿peake in an other Princes tongue, which, no doubt, is a great diÅ¿advantage to him that Å¿hall treat; for that every Nation hath Å¿ome proper Idiom, not Å¿o well diÅ¿cerned by the booke-Å¿peaker, as perceived by the Natives of the countrey, where it is Å¿poken, and wherein a Å¿tranger may eaÅ¿ily be deceived.

How much forreine Princes doe eÅ¿teeme of the skill of a Civilian in theÅ¿e matters, it may be underÅ¿tood thereby, that they never, for the moÅ¿t part Å¿end any EmbaÅ¿Å¿age for the treatie of any league or matter of commerce, but that one or moe of them are Civilians. And if the care of theÅ¿e things be Å¿o great with them, Å¿urely the eÅ¿timation of the
Å¿ame ought not to be light with us: for by what lawes their leagues and negotiations uÅ¿e to bee directed, by the Å¿ame muÅ¿t ours bee ordered, Å¿o that for that point, one kinde of learning muÅ¿t Å¿erve for both; for that otherwiÅ¿e one Nation will not be convinced by the other what their capitulations are.

Surely, Å¿uch as over and beÅ¿ides their owne experience, have the knowledge of the Civill Law, have herein a double helpe above another man that wanteth the Å¿ame. FirÅ¿t, their owne underÅ¿tanding, which for the moÅ¿t part is of like proportion as other folks is: Then the skill of the Lawes themÅ¿elves, which are a quinteÅ¿Å¿ence of wit above other humane learning, and were either wholly compoÅ¿ed of the mature and deliberate reÅ¿olutions of Å¿uch Emperours as then Å¿wayed the whole world, or were the doomes & judgments of Å¿uch wiÅ¿e men, as then managed the whole world, and the affaires thereof under them. But who, when hee Å¿eeth a Å¿word in it's Å¿caberd, knoweth whether it will cut or not, although the forme thereof be a preÅ¿umption, that it will: but, doe but draw it out of the Å¿caberd, and try the blade thereof, and then Å¿hall you Å¿ee the Å¿harpeneÅ¿Å¿e of it: I make no application hereof, for that my meaning by my words may be well enough knowne.

But in theÅ¿e matters, the wiÅ¿dome of the State knowes beÅ¿t what is to be done, and I onely remember what other Nations doe, leaving the reÅ¿t to their graveÅ¿t conÅ¿iderations, who by precedents of former times, and men of experience, furniÅ¿hed with exoticke tongues, have carried this part of pollicie very well and Å¿afely hitherto: but now to the or ãâ¦ã g of Martiall cauÅ¿es.

div.head: SECT. 5.

argument.p: What are Martiall cauÅ¿es, which are the Å¿econd extraordinary matter belonging to the CogniÅ¿ance of the Civill Law with us.

div.p: MArtiall cauÅ¿es are either Civill or Criminall, whereof both are determinable by the Civill law. A Civill Martiall cauÅ¿e, is where either the Captaine or the Souldier requireth Å¿ome thing that is due, and withholden from him, as his Å¿tipend, his apparell, which among the Romans was due twice a yeare, that is, their Sommer apparell from the firÅ¿t day of April to the firÅ¿t of September, and their Winter from thence to Aprill; his diet, which among the Romans was two dayes hard bisket, the third Å¿ofter bread, one day wine, an other day vineger, one day bacon, and two dayes mutton; his priviledges either in caÅ¿es of preferment, as to be removed from one degree to another, or in caÅ¿es of immunitie, as to be freed from all Å¿ervile functions, If. de re militari & C â¢ eod. tit. l. 12. ff. de privilegio veteranorum: & de caÅ¿trenÅ¿i peculio & C. eodemtit. l. 12. C. de erogatione militaris annonae & C. de veÅ¿t. militari. and Å¿undry other like, which a diligent reader may gather out of the titles of the DigeÅ¿t and Code of militarie affaires, and other like titles which accompany them.
Souldiers faults are either proper to themÅ¿elves, or common with others.
ThoÅ¿e are common with others, which other men fall into, and are corrected with like ordinary proceeding as other crimes of like nature are, as man-Å¿laughter, theft, adultery, and Å¿uch like.

ThoÅ¿e are proper which doe properly appertaine to militarie diÅ¿cipline, and are puniÅ¿hed by Å¿ome unu ãâ¦ã or extraordinarie puniÅ¿hment, as are theÅ¿e, not to appeare at MuÅ¿ters: to Å¿erve under him he ought not to Å¿erve: to vage or wander long from the Tents, although he returne of his owne accord: to forÅ¿ake his Colours, or his Captaine: to leave his Å¿tanding: to fly over to the Enemy: to betray the HoaÅ¿t: to be diÅ¿obedient to his Captain, Coronell, or Lieutenant, to loÅ¿e or Å¿ell his Armour, or to Å¿teale another mans:
to be negligent in forage, or providing of victuall: to neglect his watch: to make a mutiny, to fly firÅ¿t out of the field, or other like, which are delivered in the late cited titles. Concerning this Arrian, who wrote the life of Alexander the great, thus Å¿aith; Every thing is counted an offence in a Souldier, which is done contrary to the common diÅ¿cipline; as to be negligent, to be Å¿tubborne, to be Å¿lothfull.

The puniÅ¿hments wherewith Souldiers are corrected, are theÅ¿e, either corporall puniÅ¿hment, or a pecuniarie mulct, or injunction of Å¿ome Å¿ervice to be done, or a motion or removing out of their places, and Å¿ending away with Å¿hame.

By capitall puniÅ¿hment is underÅ¿tood for the moÅ¿t part death, or at the leaÅ¿t beating, unleÅ¿Å¿e happily it be pardoned, either for the unskilfulneÅ¿Å¿e of the Souldier, or for the mutinie of the company, being thereto drawen by wine and wantonneÅ¿Å¿e, or for the miÅ¿eration or pittie of the party offending.
All which a wiÅ¿e Judge moderateth according to the quality of the perÅ¿on, the quantitie of the offence, and the opportunitie of the time.

div.head: SECT. 6.

argument.p: That the third and laÅ¿t matter of extraordinary CogniÅ¿ance in the Civill Law here with us, concerneth the bearing of Armes, and ranging of every man in his proper place of honour: and firÅ¿t of Armory.

div.p:
THe laÅ¿t extraordinary matter that the Civile Law Judge dealeth in, is the bearing of Armes, and the ranging of every man into his roome of honour, according as his place requires: and here firÅ¿t of Armes. For skill in Armory, although it be a thing now almoÅ¿t proper to the Heraulds of Armes, who were in old time called Feciales, or Caduceatores, becauÅ¿e they were meÅ¿Å¿engers of warre and peace; either to proclaime the one, or denounce the other: yet the ground thereof they have from the Civile Law, Å¿o that
thereby to this day they may be directed in their skill, or controlled if they doe amiÅ¿Å¿e.

For beÅ¿ides, that there are many other places in the Law C. ut nemo privatus praediis Å¿uis, vel alienis vela regia imponat, ut nemini liceat Å¿ine Jud. author. Å¿igna imponere. &c. De Å¿tatuis & imaginib. ut nemini liceat fignum Å¿alvatoris, &c. De his qui potentiorum nomine titulos praediis Å¿uis affigunt. & ibi doct. ff. dererum diviÅ¿io. l. Å¿anctum. C. de ingenuis & manumiÅ¿Å¿. l. adrecognoÅ¿cenda ff. de rerum diviÅ¿ione l. Å¿anctum. which touch Armory, as appeareth by the titles here quoted in the margent, Barthol. himÅ¿elfe maketh a Å¿peciall tractate thereof, and divideth the whole matter of Armes into three ranks, according to the divers Å¿orts of men that bare them: for Å¿ome are Armes of Å¿ome publick dignitie and office, as the Armes of the Legate, or ProconÅ¿ull, the Armes of BiÅ¿hops, the Armes of the Lord Admirall; other are Armes of Å¿peciall dignities, as Armes of Kings and Princes, which no man is to beare or paint in his houÅ¿e or Å¿tuffe, unleÅ¿Å¿e it bee for to Å¿hew his duetie or Å¿ubjection therein.

The third Å¿ort is, of thoÅ¿e which are private mens Armes, of whom part have them by the grant of the Prince, or by authoritie of thoÅ¿e, to whom the Prince hath given power to grant Armes to others, as hath the Earle MarÅ¿hall within this Realme of England; others have taken them by their owne authoritie, which albeit in former times they might doe, as alÅ¿o they might take Å¿uch names as every one did like of (for names and Å¿ignes in the beginning were invented, for to know and diÅ¿cerne one man from an other) and as every man might change his name, Å¿o might hee change his Å¿igne, Å¿o that it were not done in fraud and deceit: but after it was forbidden, both that any man Å¿hould C. de mutatione nominis l 1. ff. de FalÅ¿is, l. Å¿al Å¿i nominis. change his name, becauÅ¿e it was not thought it could be done with any good meaning, and that no man Å¿hould beare Armes of his owne authoritie; and therefore Officers were appointed under Princes (as I have Å¿aid) who Å¿hould give Armes to Å¿uch as deÅ¿erved well of the common-wealth, either in warre or peace: for albeit in the beginning Armes and Colours were proper to men of warre, to avoid confuÅ¿ion in the hoaÅ¿t, and to diÅ¿cerne one company from an other, yet when it came to be a matter of honour, it was challenged no leÅ¿Å¿e by men of peace, than by men of warre; for true indeede is that Å¿aying of Tully, Parva Å¿unt foris
arma, niÅ¿i eÅ¿t conÅ¿ilium domi: and the Emperour Å¿peaking of the benefit that Advocates, and Å¿uch like bring to States L. Advocati C. de Advocatis diverÅ¿orum â¢ udicorum. and Common-wealths, Å¿aith thus, Advocates which breake the doubtfull fates of cauÅ¿es, and with the Å¿trength of their defence Å¿undry times, as well in publick cauÅ¿es as in private, raiÅ¿e up thoÅ¿e that are falne, and releeve thoÅ¿e which are wearied, doe no leÅ¿Å¿e good unto man-kinde, than if by warre and wounds they Å¿aved their parents and countrey: for we (Å¿aith hee) doe not count, that they onely doe warre for our Empire, which do labour with Å¿word, Å¿hield, and target, but alÅ¿o our Advocates, for indeed the Advocates or Patrons of cauÅ¿es doe warre, who by confidence of their glorious voyce doe defend the hope, life, and poÅ¿teritie of Å¿uch as be in danger: thus Å¿aith hee; and thereupon commeth that diÅ¿tinction of CaÅ¿trenÅ¿e peculium, Et quaÅ¿i caÅ¿trenÅ¿e peculium, Å¿ignifying thereby, that albeit CounÅ¿ellours to the Å¿tate, Lawyers, and Å¿uch like be not actuall warriers, yet they are repreÅ¿entative warriers, and doe no leÅ¿Å¿e Å¿erve the Common-wealth than they. The Souldier riÅ¿eth betime in the morning, that he may goe forth to his exploit, the Advocate that hee may provide for his Clients cauÅ¿e; hee wakes by the trumpet, the other by the cock; he ordereth the battell, the other his Clients buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e; hee taketh care his tents bee not taken, the other that his Clients cauÅ¿e be not overthrowne: Å¿o then either of them is a warrier, the one abroad in the field, the other at home in the Citie. BeÅ¿ides Barthol. treateth in that place, what things are borne in Armes, either naturall, as beaÅ¿tes, birdes, fiÅ¿hes, mountaines, trees, flowres, Å¿unne, moone, Å¿tarres, or Å¿uch like: or artificiall, not taken from things exiÅ¿tent, as colours, Å¿imple and mixt, divided by halfes or quarters, or by lines, direct, croÅ¿Å¿e, overthwart, or Å¿uch other; then how each of theÅ¿e is to bee carried, wherein Art muÅ¿t follow Nature, that every thing figured, be borne according to the nature of that which it doth figure, and not otherwiÅ¿e: and therefore as in enÅ¿ignes, flagges, or Å¿tandards, the Å¿peare or Å¿haft goeth before, & the Å¿treamer or colours
follow after, Å¿o the face of every creature that is figured or deÅ¿cribed in the banner or hatchment, muÅ¿t looke unto the Å¿haft or Å¿peare; unleÅ¿Å¿e a man beare two creatures, one looking toward the other, for then this obÅ¿ervation hath no place, for vaine it is to conjecture where things are certain, otherwiÅ¿e it is the nature of the face to goe before, and the body to follow after: and the like reaÅ¿on is of the parts of every creature which is likewiÅ¿e borne in Armor, which are diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hed by before and behinde, whoÅ¿e Å¿ite muÅ¿t be Å¿uch, that the head looke to the Å¿peare, otherwiÅ¿e would it Å¿eeme to goe backe like a monÅ¿ter: but if the forepart alone of any creature be borne in a Scucheon, as often it happeneth that men give onely a Lyon, Beare, or Buls head for their Armes, then muÅ¿t not the head directly looke unto the Å¿haft, but aÅ¿ide: further, every of theÅ¿e creatures be Å¿o deÅ¿cribed in the coate, as his vigour and generoÅ¿itie be beÅ¿t Å¿et out, whether it be a fierce or Å¿avage beaÅ¿t, or a milde and gentle creature. But for colours, his rule is, that the nobleÅ¿t colour be put in the firÅ¿t part of the field, howÅ¿oever the coate be divided, quarter or pale. And of colours, the golden colour is the chiefeÅ¿t, as that which doth figure the Sunne, which is the fountaine of light, which is moÅ¿t acceptable to every mans eye. The next is Purple or Red, which doth figure the fire, that is the higheÅ¿t and nobleÅ¿t of the foure Elements, and next the Å¿unne it Å¿elfe in dignitie. The third is Blew, of the Heralds called Azure, and Ceruleus in Latin, which figureth the Aire, which is a cleere and tranÅ¿parent body, and moÅ¿t capable of light, and commeth in nobility next after the fire. The fourth is White, which commeth neere to the Light, and therefore is more noble than Black, that draweth neere to darkneÅ¿Å¿e, and therefore is the baÅ¿eÅ¿t of all Colours. And for mixt colours, as every one hath more or leÅ¿Å¿e of White or Black, Å¿o either they are nobler or baÅ¿er in reputation or degree. And thus much in generall as concerning the knowledge of Armes.

div.head: SECT. 7.

argument.p: Concerning the Places and SucceÅ¿Å¿ions of Princes, and other honourable PerÅ¿onages, and firÅ¿t of their Places.

div.p: NOw followeth what the Civile Law holdeth, as concerning Princes, and other honourable PerÅ¿ons, and their Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ions and places, which a grave Judge of this Land hath anciently acknowledged to belong unto the Civile Nedham 37. Hen. 6. fol. 21. Law.

By the Civile Law, all power commeth from God, as the Scripture teacheth, and among powers the two greateÅ¿t are the Empire, and the PrieÅ¿thood; for as God hath ordeined the one to rule the outward man, and to bring all his actions within the compaÅ¿Å¿e of reaÅ¿on, and Å¿o to eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h common-wealths, and to order the Å¿ame: So alÅ¿o hath hee provided the other for the inÅ¿truction of the inward man, and the planting of Religion among men.

By the Empire, I underÅ¿tand, not onely the Empire of Rome (which Å¿ometimes bare rule over moÅ¿t part of the world, at the leaÅ¿t ten mighty Kingdomes, which now are growne into particular Empires and Monarchies themÅ¿elves) but alÅ¿o every Å¿everall Kingdome, which acknowledgeth no other Emperour than his owne Soveraigne; for howÅ¿oever they differ in name and title, yet is the office it Å¿elfe all one: For every one of them is Gods immediate Vicar upon earth in their owne kingdomes, for matters appertaining unto JuÅ¿tice. Whereupon the Civile Law gives them very honourable titles, Å¿ometimes tearming them Gods upon earth, for the great authority they have over ff. de leg. 2. l. ff de legat. 2. l. C. 4 tit. 1 â¢ . C. 1. tit. 3 l. 56. C. 1. tit. 1. l. 5. other men under God; Å¿ometimes MiniÅ¿ters of God, for the Å¿ervice they doe God in their common-wealths; Å¿omtimes moÅ¿t holy, and moÅ¿t religious, for the care they ought to have about Religion, and correcting of thoÅ¿e things which are done againÅ¿t the feare of God; for a King ought in all things to propound the word of God before him for his C. 1. tit. 1 l 5. rule, and to follow the doctrine of the ApoÅ¿tles; Å¿omtimes
they are called moÅ¿t milde, becauÅ¿e a King in all the courÅ¿e of his life, but Å¿pecially in matters of puniÅ¿hment ought to imitate the mercie and favour of Almighty God. C. 5. tit. 4 l. 23.

Although the Emperour or King be reckoned among his Nobilitie, becauÅ¿e he Å¿hould not be puft up with the glorie L. fin. C. de ver. Å¿ignif. c. de dignitat. l. 8 lib. 12. of his place, & conceive he were of a more excellent mould than the reÅ¿t, when indeed wee are all of one, and the Å¿elfe Å¿ame clay; yet he is both by the ordinance of God and man ã in non-Latin alphabet ã , (as the ApoÅ¿tle tearms him) among them, that 1 Petric. 2. ver. 13. is, one who is Å¿upreame Soveraigne above the reÅ¿t, and whom they ought in all things to obey, Å¿o it be not againÅ¿t the Law of God, and common JuÅ¿tice; for himÅ¿elfe is in Å¿teed of the whole Law, yea he is the Law it Å¿elfe, and the Abc. Å¿ignific. via extâª de penitentiis &c. C 6 t 23. l. 19. C. de teÅ¿tib. l. omnium. onely interpreter thereof, as in whoÅ¿e breaÅ¿t is the whole knowledge of the Å¿ame; which albeit the Doctors doe hold with a qualification, as thereby underÅ¿tanding, not onely the Princes perÅ¿on, but alÅ¿o his Chancellours, both which put together, make up a perfect Å¿tate of a Prince: yet foraÅ¿much as all that benefit of wiÅ¿dome and government that commeth from them unto the Common-wealth, is principally derived from the Prince, as from the head, who hath vouchÅ¿afed to make them, as it were, members of his body, and Å¿o by them to derive the power of his government unto all; it may be rightly Å¿aid, that in the Princes breaÅ¿t, reÅ¿teth the fulneÅ¿Å¿e of all knowledge, for the well ordering of his common-wealth; for what they Å¿ee, they Å¿ee for him, what they heare, they heare for his uÅ¿e, what they underÅ¿tand, they underÅ¿tand to doe him Å¿ervice, and Å¿o conÅ¿equently of the reÅ¿t of the actions of the minde and body, they obey the Prince as their Soveraigne: Å¿o then as the Prince hath the primacie in the government of his common-wealth, and all thoÅ¿e which governe under him, governe by, and for him; Å¿o alÅ¿o hath he the precedencie, and protocliÅ¿ie, or foreÅ¿itting in all aÅ¿Å¿emblies before the reÅ¿t, and Å¿uch other as have precedencie or foreÅ¿itting, have it by the Princes indulgencie.

Next unto the Prince is his Queene, who Å¿hineth by the C. 7 tit. 37. l. 3. in princip.
beames of her King, and hath the like prerogative as himÅ¿elfe hath. After them comes next in place the Kings Children, becauÅ¿e children in a Å¿ort are partakers of their Fathers dignitie: but yet among children there is a difference, that the male be preferr'd before the female, & among thoÅ¿e which are males, the eldeÅ¿t have the preheminence in going, Å¿itting, Å¿peaking, and other like matters of reÅ¿pect. After the Kings Children follow in the next ranke Dukes, after them MarqueÅ¿Å¿es, then Earles, fourthly Vicounts, and laÅ¿t Barons; all which have dignities either heritable, or granted by the bountie of the Prince, whereupon their nobilitie is founded, and whereby they onely and no other are to be accounted Peeres of the Land. Among theÅ¿e, for courteÅ¿ie Å¿ake, are reckoned Å¿uch as deÅ¿cend of Noble HouÅ¿es, every one according to his degree, untill the third generation: L. 1. c de dignitat. lib. 12. and the daughters of theÅ¿e great HouÅ¿es, Å¿o long as they marrie to any that are in degree of Peeres, reteine their fathers dignitie, but if they marrie under the degree of Peeres, then they loÅ¿e their fathers place, and follow the degree of their husband; which notwithÅ¿tanding is in practice otherwiÅ¿e heere among us, but without any warrant of Law. The like is of the Widowes of the Peeres, who L. Mulieres 13. C. de dignit. l. 12. c. de equeÅ¿tri dignitat. l. unic. lib. 12. while they live Å¿ole and unmarried, reteine the nobilitie of their husbands; but if they marrie, then they follow the condition of their Å¿econd husbands, be it honourable or otherwiÅ¿e.

Next in place after Peeres come Knights, whereof Cujacius Cujacius lib de Feudis. following the moderne French Heraldrie, maketh three Å¿orts; one whereof hee calleth Chevalliers, the other Bannerets, the third Bachilers, but Å¿etteth downe no proper difference of the one from the other; and therefore I leave that to bee enquired of thoÅ¿e, which Å¿hall be curious thereof. Among the Romans, for ought that I have read, L. cumte. c. de Nuptiis. there was but one order of them, and they were next in degree to the Senatours themÅ¿elves, as with us they are to the Peeres.

Betweene Knights and Doctors of the Law, hath ever
been queÅ¿tion for precedencie, Å¿ince either of them hath been in credit in Common-weales, as may appeare both by the compariÅ¿on that Tully maketh betweene Lucius Murena, a Knight of Rome, and Publ. Sulpitius a Lawyer, either of them Å¿tanding for the ConÅ¿ulÅ¿hip, in his eloquent Oration made for Murena, and many diÅ¿putes of Bartol and Baldus, arguing the caÅ¿e to and fro, which although it be yet diÅ¿putable in forreine Countries, where the Civile Law is in credit; yet here among us where all preferment is taken from it, and the ProfeÅ¿Å¿ours thereof are Å¿hut up, as it were, into a narrow corner of their profeÅ¿Å¿ion, it is without controverÅ¿ie, and the prioritie thereof indubitable: but yet this ChaÅ¿Å¿aneus de gloria mundi lib. 9. is the reÅ¿olution of thoÅ¿e which are learned in this point, that in Å¿uch acts as concerne learning, a Doctor is to bee preferred before a Knight, but in acts that concerne militarie knowledge, a Knight takes place before a Doctor: but in other acts which are neither proper to the one, nor to the other, firÅ¿t are preferred Å¿uch Doctors as attend about the Prince; Å¿econdly Å¿uch Knights as waite upon the Prince; thirdly Å¿uch Doctors as being not about the Prince, are excellent in learning; fourthly come Knights without any place of preferment; laÅ¿tly Doctors of meaner gifts and place.

Although by the Civile Law there be no Gentlemen of title under Knights, but all the reÅ¿t went under the name of people, yet in other common-wealths there are, and with us bee, even in this ranke, which have names of preheminence, whereby they are in degree aboue the reÅ¿t; as with the French there are l â¢ s Gentilhommes, and le Gens de ordinances, and with us are Squiers and Gentlemen, all which give EnÅ¿ignes or Coat-Armours, and thereby are diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hed from the meaner people: in which reÅ¿pect Bartol calleth them Noble, but yet of a weake nobilitie, for that it hath no further prerogative Bartol ãâã . de InÅ¿ign. in it, than that it makes them differ from the baÅ¿er Å¿ort of people.

Of theÅ¿e two Å¿orts of Gentlemen with us, the Squier
hath the priority, And Å¿o it might have Å¿eemed by the EngliÅ¿h name. for though we now call this kinde of Gentleman an EÅ¿quier, yet our AnceÅ¿tors called Å¿uch a one S â¢ yld-cnapa, a th â¢ eld-knave, that was the knave (or as wee Å¿ay now, the boy of Å¿ervant) that uÅ¿ed to beare a Shield or other Armour after his MaÅ¿ter in the wartes: and this is anÅ¿werable to the Latin Armiger, and to the originall of the dignity; whereas the word EÅ¿quier (which we now uÅ¿e) fioÌ the French, properly noteth an other thing. L. 1. c. de dignitut. lib. 10. & 12. who Å¿eemes by the common name wee give him in Latin, to have had his origen, either for that hee carried the Armour of the King, Duke, or other great Homer. Iliad. Plin. lib. 35. natural. hiÅ¿tor perÅ¿onage, as wee Å¿ee not onely in holy Scriptures Saul and Jonathan had their Armour-bearers; but in PoÃ«ts and other prophane Å¿tories, Patroclus was Achilles Armour-bearer, and Clitus great Alexanders: whereupom Å¿ome write that ã in non-Latin alphabet ã , which is he whom we call Armiger in Latin, is a footeman, that with a Å¿peare, Å¿hield, or head piece, followeth an armed Knight in battaile, or rather as Å¿ome other Å¿uppoÅ¿e, it is the footman himÅ¿elfe armed in the field: howÅ¿oever the word be taken, this is Å¿ure, that theÅ¿e were men of good account in the old time, as thoÅ¿e which won themÅ¿elves credite out of warre, and Å¿o their eÅ¿timation remained in their poÅ¿teritie; and as thoÅ¿e were in time before, Å¿o are theÅ¿e which are in our dayes, as deÅ¿cending, for the moÅ¿t part, from their worthy AnceÅ¿tours.

There is no dubbing or creating of theÅ¿e by the Princes hand, or him to whom the Prince hath given authoritie, as it is in the creating of the Nobilitie, and the making of Knights, but every one whom the Captaine hath vouchÅ¿afed that Å¿ervice, is by the Å¿ervice it Å¿elfe a Squier; and that not onely hee which hath done the Å¿ervice in warre, but alÅ¿o Å¿uch which have done any equivalent Å¿ervice in peace, as Lievtenants, and Sherifes of Shires, and JuÅ¿tices of Peace within their Countie: for even in this, as in other Promotions hath that diÅ¿tinction of the Law place, of CaÅ¿trenÅ¿is peculii, & quaÅ¿i caÅ¿trenÅ¿is, whereby Å¿ervice of the Common-wealth at home, is levelled and made equall with that abroad. Gentlemen have their beginning either of blood, as that they are borne of worÅ¿hipfull parents, or that they have done Å¿ome thing worthily in peace or warre, whereby they deÅ¿erve to beare Armes, and to bee accounted Gentlemen, for hee is a Gentleman who is commonly Å¿o taken and reputed.

div.head: SECT. 8.

argument.p: Concerning the SucceÅ¿Å¿ion of great PerÅ¿onages in their places of Honour.

div.p: NOw it followeth, that I Å¿peake Å¿omthing alÅ¿o, how great perÅ¿onages one Å¿ucceede an other in their places of honour.

And firÅ¿t, to begin with the Empire it Å¿elfe, as the greateÅ¿t earthly dignitie under God, albeit in the beginning it were raiÅ¿ed up by no right, but by uÅ¿urpation, Julius CaeÅ¿ar changing the former government of the State, and challenging to himÅ¿elfe the whole managing of the Å¿ame; yet after it came to an orderly courÅ¿e, inÅ¿omuch as hee that had the preÅ¿ent poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of it, diÅ¿poÅ¿ed it to his beÅ¿t liking by his laÅ¿t Will and TeÅ¿tament. So Julius himÅ¿elfe deviÅ¿ed it to Octavius his Å¿iÅ¿ters Å¿onne: and albeit that deviÅ¿e tooke not effect, by reaÅ¿on of the treaÅ¿on that was wrought againÅ¿t Julius owne perÅ¿on, Å¿o that Octavius was faine to recover it by an other right, even by the death of Lepidus and Antonius his colleagues in office; yet that very Will of Julius gave a pretence to Octavius, who after was called AuguÅ¿tus (becauÅ¿e hee did increaÅ¿e the Empire with many worthy Victories) to Å¿tand for the inheritance of the Empire; in conÅ¿ideration of which title the Senate and people of Rome more eaÅ¿ily Å¿ubmitted themÅ¿elves unto his government. AuguÅ¿tus in like Å¿ort bequeathed it to Tiberius, and Tiberius to Caius: and Å¿o it came from one to an other, untill Å¿ome of them by cruelty and licentiouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e of life, became Å¿o odious to God and man, that the people roÅ¿e againÅ¿t them, and bereft them of that libertie, which they had preÅ¿cribed in appointing of their SucceÅ¿Å¿ors, and Å¿omewhiles themÅ¿elves, and Å¿omewhiles the Souldiers made choiÅ¿e of whom they thought good, or by whom they thought beÅ¿t to be rewarded. And thus the right of SucceÅ¿Å¿ion
unto the Empire, was toÅ¿t up and down many hundred yeares betwixt Inheritance, BequeÅ¿t, and Election, untill at the laÅ¿t, it came unto that eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed Å¿tate, as now it is in, and Å¿etled Electours of the Empire, Å¿o often as it happened to be voide. SucceÅ¿Å¿ion in Kingdomes, in moÅ¿t part of the world, in former time hath beene, and at this day is by right of bloud, (a few onely excepted, which are Elective, as the Kingdome of Poland is at this day) and in SucceÅ¿Å¿ion the eldeÅ¿t Å¿onne taketh place before the reÅ¿t; and if there be no heire male, then the eldeÅ¿t daughter Å¿ucceedeth in the kingdome, and her iÅ¿Å¿ue: for Kingdomes (as alÅ¿o Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ion in other dignities) are impartible. And yet France (to exclude Edward the third from the inheritance of the Crowne thereof, who deÅ¿cended of IÅ¿abel the Å¿iÅ¿ter of Charles the faire, and Å¿o was next heire male unto the kingdome of France) alleaged for themÅ¿elves the Law Salick, pretending none which claimed by the woman, albeit he were the next heire male in bloud, was to Å¿ucceed, as long as there were of the male line alive, how farre Å¿oever they were off in degree from the laÅ¿t King deceaÅ¿ed. div.head: SECT. 2.

div.p:

TheÅ¿e, for the moÅ¿t part, are meere quirks and Å¿ubtilties of law, and therefore ought to have no more favour in any wiÅ¿e, honourable, or well ordered ConÅ¿iÅ¿torie, than the equity of the cauÅ¿e it Å¿elfe doth deÅ¿erve; for Å¿uch maner of Å¿hifts (for the moÅ¿t part) breed nought elÅ¿e but matter of

The Prohibitions of the law, as have beene before Å¿hewed, are neither many, nor much repined at, becauÅ¿e they containe a neceÅ¿Å¿ary diÅ¿tinction betweene JuriÅ¿diction and JuriÅ¿diction, and imply the Kings right, and Subjects benefit: but the Prohibitions of fact or of men, are both infinite and odious, for that there is, well nigh, no matter either Civile or EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall, be it never Å¿o cleere or abÅ¿olute, but they clog and incumber it with Å¿ome Prohibition; and

div.head: SECT. 3.

argument.p: Conoerning the common Lawyers action of Trover, and what is meant in the Law by a Fiction, to Å¿hew, how the Civile JuriÅ¿diction is impeached in matters of Admiraltie.

div.p: FOr Marine cauÅ¿es it is well knowne, that all Å¿uch bargaines and contracts, or as it were contracts, as are made by any perÅ¿ons either in any forraine countrey, or any haven or creeke of the Sea, or any Å¿hore thereof, as farre as the greateÅ¿t winter wave doth runne out, or upon any great river, to the firÅ¿t bridge next to the Sea, for any merchandize, Å¿hip, tackle, or other negotiation belonging to the Sea, or to any merchandize brought from beyond the Sea, is, and ought to be of the admirall cogniÅ¿ance, and Å¿o evermore hath beene Å¿ince the Court of the Admiraltie was firÅ¿t erected: and yet the common Lawyers (to defeate the Civile Law of the triall thereof) have deviÅ¿ed Å¿undry actions, and among the reÅ¿t, an action of Trover, whereby they faine, that a Å¿hip arrived in Cheapfide, or Å¿ome other like place within the Citie, and there the Plaintife and Defendant meeting together, bargained upon Å¿ome merchandize, or other like Å¿ea-faring matter, by which fiction, they pretend the bargaine now is to be tryed in the Common Law, and not by the Civile Law, as being done in the body of a Countie, and not upon the maine Sea, or any other place Å¿ubject to the Admirall JuriÅ¿diction.

But that this fiction, or any other like qualitied to this, Å¿hould have any Å¿uch force, as to worke any effect in Law, I will Å¿hew, firÅ¿t by the definition of a fiction, then by thoÅ¿e things that are neceÅ¿Å¿arily attendant thereon.

upon an untruth, for a truth, in a certaine thing poÅ¿Å¿ible to be done, and yet not done: upon which fiction the Doctors hold, there waite two things, the one is Equitie, the other PoÅ¿Å¿ibility. For FirÅ¿t, unleÅ¿Å¿e there be cauÅ¿e why, that which is not, Å¿hould be fained to be, and that which is, Å¿hould bee accounted not to be, and that which is done in one Å¿ort, or at one time, or in one place, Å¿hould be imagined to be done in an other Å¿ort, at an other time, and in an other place, there is no reaÅ¿on a fiction Å¿hould be admitted: for the Law alloweth no man to come to extraordinary remedies, but where ordinarie remedies faile: and therefore if that which is in controverÅ¿ie may bee obtained by any other meanes, than by a fiction, a fiction is not to be afforded: but if ordinary meanes cannot be had, then fictions may be entertained L. in cauÅ¿a. ff. de minorib. to Å¿upply the defect of the ordinary meanes, that thereby, although the truth be otherwiÅ¿e, yet the effect of the Law may be all one.

And as the Law cannot proceed to a fiction without equity, Å¿o neither can it faine any thing that is impoÅ¿Å¿ible, for Art evermore followeth Nature; and therefore if a man would faine diÅ¿proportionable things, Å¿uch as the Painter did in Horace, who made Boares wallow in the waves of the Sea, and Dolphins wander in the woods; theÅ¿e fictions in no Å¿ence can be admitted, for that they are Å¿uch, as neither Nature nor ReaÅ¿on can brooke. In like Å¿ort, if a man would faine one to live, who were dead two hundred yeares Å¿ince, Bartol l fi is qui pro emptore num. 21. 22. 23. & Å¿equen tib. Å¿o that it were not poÅ¿Å¿ible that hee or any of his equals Å¿hould live at that age, this would not hold in Law, for that it is above the age that the Law doth preÅ¿ume any man may live by Nature; although the Law doth preÅ¿ume Å¿uch as dye in warre for defence of their countrey (for the better encouragement of thoÅ¿e that are alive, to venture themÅ¿elves in like Å¿ervice for the common-wealth) to live for ever; becauÅ¿e their fame doth flouriÅ¿h for ever: and upon like reaÅ¿on the Law will not Å¿uffer any perÅ¿on to adopt an other for his childe, who is either elder or equall in age unto himÅ¿elfe, or is not Å¿o farre under his yeares, as by courÅ¿e of Nature hee might be his naturall childe indeed: Å¿o much the Law deteÅ¿teth impoÅ¿Å¿ibilities, that it will not Å¿uffer a man to faine that which in common Sence and Nature might not be true indeed.

Now, if theÅ¿e things be true, as in all reaÅ¿on and Å¿hew, by former precedents they appeare to be true, I would gladly Å¿ee how actions of Trover, (whereby the Common Lawyers tranÅ¿late unto themÅ¿elves matters of Marine triall) if they be Å¿quared to theÅ¿e Rules of Fictions, can bee maintained: for firÅ¿t to Å¿peake of equitie, which the Law requires in theÅ¿e manner of proceedings, what equitie can it be to take away the triall of Å¿uch buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e as belongeth to one Court, and to pull it to an other Court; Å¿pecially, when as the Court from whence it is drawne, is more fit for it, both in reÅ¿pect of the fulneÅ¿Å¿e of knowledge that that Court
