For, albeit otherwiÅ¿e they are very wiÅ¿e and Å¿ufficient men in the underÅ¿tanding of their owne profeÅ¿Å¿ion, yet have they Å¿mall skill or knowledge in matters pertaining to the Civile profeÅ¿Å¿ion: for that there is nothing written in their Bookes of theÅ¿e matters, more than is to be gathered out of a few Statutes of former time, whoÅ¿e drift was not to open any doore unto them, to enter upon the admirall profeÅ¿Å¿ion, but to preÅ¿erue the Kings JuriÅ¿diction from the Admirall incroachment, as may by the Å¿aid Statutes appeare; whereas contrarily, the Civile Law hath Å¿undry titles included in the body thereof, concerning theÅ¿e kindes of cauÅ¿es; whereupon the Interpreters of the Law have largely commented, and others have made Å¿everall Tractates thereof: So that, by all likelihood, theÅ¿e men are more fit and better furniÅ¿hed to deale in this buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e, than any men of any other profeÅ¿Å¿ion, as having, beÅ¿ides the Å¿trength of their owne wit, other mens helpes and labours to relie upon.

BeÅ¿ides, this buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e many times concerns not only our owne countrey-men, but alÅ¿o Å¿trangers, who are parties to the Å¿uit, who are borne, and doe live in countries ordered by the Civile Law, whereby they may bee preÅ¿umed to have more skill and better liking of that Law, than they can bee thought to have of our Lawes, and our proceedings: and therefore it were no indifferencie to call them from the triall of that Law, which they, in Å¿ome part know, and is the Law of their countrey (as it is almoÅ¿t to all ChriÅ¿tendome beÅ¿ides) to the triall of a Law which they know in no part, and is meere forraine unto them; Å¿pecially when the Princes of this Land have anciently allowed the Civile Law to be a Common Law, in theÅ¿e cauÅ¿es, as well to their owne Å¿ubjects, as it is to Å¿trangers.

Further, the avocating away of cauÅ¿es in this Å¿ort from
one JuriÅ¿diction to another, Å¿pecially when the cauÅ¿e hath long depended in the Court from whence it is called, inÅ¿omuch as now it is ready for Å¿entence, or rather is paÅ¿t Å¿entence, and Å¿tands at execution, cannot be but great injurie to the Å¿ubject after Å¿o much labour loÅ¿t, and money Å¿pent in waÅ¿te, to begin his Å¿uit anew againe: which is like to SyÅ¿iphus puniÅ¿hment, who, when he hath with all his might, forced his Å¿tone up to the top of the hill, and Å¿o is (as himÅ¿elfe hopes) at an end of his labour; yet the Å¿tone rowles downe again on him, and Å¿o his Å¿econd labour (his Å¿trength being Å¿pent with the toyle of the firÅ¿t) is more grievous than the former was: which being Å¿emblably true in a poore Clyent, who hath his cauÅ¿e in hearing, there can be no equity in this fiction, whereby a cauÅ¿e Å¿o neere ended, Å¿hould againe be put upon the Anvill, as though it were Å¿till rough worke and new to be begun.

And Å¿urely, as there is no equity in it, Å¿o there is no poÅ¿Å¿ibility Å¿uch a fiction Å¿hould be maintained by Law; for that it hath no ground of reaÅ¿on to reÅ¿t his feete on. For if this be granted, that Å¿uch a fiction by Law may be made, then one of theÅ¿e abÅ¿urdities muÅ¿t needes follow, either that a Å¿hippe may arive in a place where no water is to carry it, or if that it arive according to the fiction, either the people, their houÅ¿es and their wealth Å¿hall be all overwhelmed in the water, as the world was in Noahs Floud, & Ducalions Deluge, and Å¿o no body there Å¿hall be left alive to make any bargain or contract with the Mariners & Shipmen that arive there; or that the people that dwell there Å¿hall walk upon the water, as people doe on land, which Peter himÅ¿elfe was not able to doe, but had Å¿uncke, if ChriÅ¿t had not reacht his hand unto him, and therefore far leÅ¿Å¿e poÅ¿Å¿ible for any other man to doe. So that it may bee well Å¿aid (theÅ¿e things Å¿tanding as they doe) no Å¿uch fiction can hold, and that no action can be framed upon it; for as there is no Obligation of impoÅ¿Å¿ible things, Å¿o there is no Action of things that neither Nature nor ReaÅ¿on will afford to be done: neither is it to the purpoÅ¿e that the maintainers of theÅ¿e fictions doe Å¿ay,
that in this caÅ¿e, the place where the contract is made is not conÅ¿iderable, which I take to be farre otherwiÅ¿e; for that, when that themÅ¿elves will convey a Marine cauÅ¿e from the Sea unto the Land, they will lay it to bee done in Å¿ome Å¿peciall place of a Countrie, bee the place never Å¿o unproper for Å¿uch an action: for that the foundation of theÅ¿e actions, is the place where they were done, as namely that they were done in the body of Å¿uch a Country, or Å¿uch a Country, and not upon the maine Sea, or beneath the loweÅ¿t bridge, that is upon any great river next the Sea. And therfore in two emulous JuriÅ¿dictions, when they are Å¿o divided, as that one is aÅ¿Å¿igned the Å¿ea, the other the land, the place of the action can in no Å¿ort be Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿ed, and another Å¿upplyed in the roome thereof: Quod enim una via prohibetur, alia via non eÅ¿t permittendum, & quod prohibitum eÅ¿t directo prohibetur etiam per obliguum: for if this were granted, then matter enough would bee offered to one JuriÅ¿diction to devour up the other, and the Law would be eaÅ¿ily eluded: which, to reÅ¿traine either of theÅ¿e JuriÅ¿dictions to their owne place, and to provide that one in his greatneÅ¿Å¿e doe not Å¿well up againÅ¿t the other, hath Å¿et either of them their bounds and limits which they Å¿hall not paÅ¿Å¿e: which, as it is the good proviÅ¿ion of the Law, Å¿o ought either JuriÅ¿diction in all obedience to Å¿ubmit it Å¿elfe thereunto, for that the diminiÅ¿hing of either of them is a wrong to the Prince from whom they are derived, who is no leÅ¿Å¿e Lord of the Sea, than hee is King of the Land: and therefore, in no Å¿ort, Å¿uch liberty muÅ¿t be allowed to the one directly or indirectly, as that it Å¿hould be a Å¿poile unto the other; which would eaÅ¿ily come to paÅ¿Å¿e, if when as the Law alloweth not any man to Å¿ue a Marine matter by the ordinary courÅ¿e of the Lawes of this Land, yet a man will follow it by an extraordinary. But where there is an uniformitie of JuriÅ¿diction, as that it is all by Å¿ea and all by land, there may a thing be fained to bee done in one place, that was done in another place, without any mans prejudice, for that in this caÅ¿e the place is not traverÅ¿able (Å¿o it bee not in Criminall matters
where time and place is required, that the accuÅ¿er doe not wander from place to place with the injurie of the accuÅ¿er) for howÅ¿oever the place and the action is altered, yet the truth of the cauÅ¿e remaineth one and the Å¿elfe Å¿ame Å¿till. And Å¿o farre as concerning actions of Trover in Admirall cauÅ¿es: Now it doth follow, that I Å¿hould Å¿peake of like prejudices that grow to the Å¿ame by actions of TreÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e, but thoÅ¿e will I paÅ¿Å¿e over, for that in Å¿o Å¿mall a TreatiÅ¿e as this is, I cannot goe over all: and therefore will I onely put the Reader in minde, that there are more deviÅ¿es, riÅ¿ing out of the Common Law than one, that infeÅ¿t the Admiralty. But now to Wils and TeÅ¿taments wherein they are impeached.

div.head: SECT. 4.

argument.p: Concerning Wils and TeÅ¿taments, wherein they are impeached.

div.p: FOr matters of Wils and Legacies, they are Å¿o proper to the triall of the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tical Law of this Realm, that the profeÅ¿Å¿ors of the Common Law themÅ¿elves, doe oftentimes confeÅ¿Å¿e and Å¿ay, they have no more to doe therewith, than the Civilian hath to do with the knowledge of the matters of Franktenement: and yet even theÅ¿e matters of TeÅ¿taments and Legacies, although Prohibitions be not Å¿o frequent in them, as they are in the reÅ¿t of EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall cauÅ¿es, yet they are not quite voide of them, & that in Å¿ome points, wherein the very life and eÅ¿Å¿ence of a Will doth Å¿tand.

For whereas the ancient Romans, knowing how Å¿ubject matters of Wils are to forgerie and corruption on the one Å¿ide, and Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿ion and concealment on the other Å¿ide, to meet with all craft and Å¿ubtilty whatÅ¿oever, which might Å¿eize on them, did moÅ¿t carefully provide, that there Å¿hould be Å¿even witneÅ¿Å¿es, at the leaÅ¿t, preÅ¿ent at the making of every Will & TeÅ¿tament, except it were in time of Å¿ome generall plague or Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e, when Å¿o many witneÅ¿Å¿es could not conveniently be had together, for fear of infection, or that it
were in the Countrie, where there are Å¿mall multitude of people. And that thoÅ¿e witneÅ¿Å¿es Å¿hould be particularly required to that purpoÅ¿e, with diverÅ¿e other obÅ¿ervations and circumÅ¿tances tending all to the Å¿afe and Å¿ure making thereof; which the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law altered afterward in Å¿undry points, for that many true Wils were many times overthrowne for want of thoÅ¿e preciÅ¿e Å¿olemnities. It therefore reduced the whole number of thoÅ¿e Å¿even witneÅ¿Å¿es, unto two onely, agreeably to the Law of God, and the Law of Nations, where that number of witneÅ¿Å¿es is allowed, as competent to prove any matter, Å¿o that the Å¿ame witneÅ¿Å¿es be honeÅ¿t and credible perÅ¿ons, Å¿uch whoÅ¿e faith is not doubted of. The Common Lawyers, becauÅ¿e themÅ¿elves in Å¿undry matters very dangerouÅ¿ly many times admit one witneÅ¿Å¿e, and give him full credit, and that in matters of great weight and importance, (as though all Å¿hould bee Å¿quared to their rule, and framed to their compaÅ¿Å¿e) if an EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Judge in the probate of a Will, contrary to the rules of his owne Law, will not admit the teÅ¿timony of one witneÅ¿Å¿e, they forthwith fling out a Prohibition againÅ¿t him, as though he had done an offence againÅ¿t the Crowne and dignitie, in that he doth not allow thoÅ¿e number of witneÅ¿Å¿es in the Probate of a Will, that the Common Lawes of this land allow almoÅ¿t in every matter.

For anÅ¿wer to which, if I Å¿hould alleage the preciÅ¿e forme of the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law, which to the eÅ¿Å¿ence of a Will requireth this number of two witneÅ¿Å¿es, or elÅ¿e holdeth it not for a Will (but in caÅ¿es inter liberos, & ad pios uÅ¿us, where the onely hand of the Father or TeÅ¿tator without witneÅ¿Å¿es Å¿erveth for a Will, Å¿o the Å¿ame be knowne to bee the TeÅ¿tators owne hand, or Å¿o proved by compariÅ¿on) I would thinke to wiÅ¿e men I had Å¿aid Å¿ufficiently; but I will not reÅ¿t hereupon, but will convince themÅ¿elves, by themÅ¿elves: for, doe they, I pray you, in their own proceedings, where a Law or Statute requires more witneÅ¿Å¿es than one, content themÅ¿elves with one witneÅ¿Å¿e alone; yea, doe they not in all caÅ¿es where a certaine number of witneÅ¿Å¿es are appointed
to prove a fact by Law or Statute, furniÅ¿h the cauÅ¿e with Å¿o many witneÅ¿Å¿es as the caÅ¿e deÅ¿ires, or elÅ¿e doe they not account the proceeding voide? And will they thinke themÅ¿elves Å¿o preciÅ¿ely bound to the keeping of the letter of the Common Law, and will they not Å¿uffer the Civilian in like maner, to cleave faÅ¿t to the obÅ¿ervation of the Civile Law, eÅ¿pecially when it hath the conÅ¿ent of the Law of God, and the Law of Nations, and is his MajeÅ¿ties EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law of this Land, aÅ¿well as the other is his Temporall Law of the Å¿ame?

I confeÅ¿Å¿e it may be true many times, which one man Å¿aith, Å¿pecially when there concurre therewith many great and violent preÅ¿umptions, and the party that reporteth it is of good credit; but dangerous it is to open this gap to the malice of men, for even Å¿o, many things Å¿hall bee obtruded to the Judge for trueth, which are Å¿tarke lyes; and many things Å¿hall bee pretended to bee gold in Å¿hew, which in proofe and practiÅ¿e will be found to be no other thing, but meere droÅ¿Å¿e. And therefore well decreed the Emperour L â¢ juris urandi. Â§. Simili modo. C. de TeÅ¿tibus. ConÅ¿tantine, that no one mans teÅ¿timony Å¿hould bee heard, though he were never Å¿o great a man in Court.

But perhaps Å¿ome man will Å¿ay, If credit Å¿hall not be given oftentimes to one mans teÅ¿timonie, much wickedneÅ¿Å¿e will paÅ¿Å¿e away unpuniÅ¿hed: For reply to which I anÅ¿wer, It is better to let a bad man Å¿cape, than to puniÅ¿h a good; and although it be true, if a man may excuÅ¿e himÅ¿elfe by deniall, no man will be found guilty; Å¿o alÅ¿o it is true on the other Å¿ide, if it be enough to condemnation to be charged by one man alone, without any other witneÅ¿Å¿es, no man Å¿hall bee innocent; and therefore the admittance of one witneÅ¿Å¿e in cauÅ¿es, and the proceeding thereupon to judgement is very dangerous.

An other like barre to this they lay againÅ¿t EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall proceedings in matters of TeÅ¿tament; whereas an EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Judge proveth a Will, wherein are Mannors, Lands, Tenements, and other like Hereditaments bequeathed, challenging this alÅ¿o to be of the Crowne and dignity,
as though the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Judge thereby took upon him to decree which lands were deviÅ¿able by Will, & which not, or would by his probate adde a Å¿trength unto the Will, to make the deviÅ¿e good or bad, whereas on the contrary part, the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Judge by this act doth only teÅ¿tifie, that Å¿uch a perÅ¿on made Å¿uch a Will, & that the Å¿ame was proved before himÅ¿elfe under his TeÅ¿te, for his laÅ¿t Will & TeÅ¿tament: but for the validity of the Will it Å¿elf, & the Legacies and deviÅ¿es therein, whether they were of lands or tenements, or of goods or chattels, the Probate it Å¿elfe worketh nothing, but leaveth that to the Law, Common or EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall, according as the bequeÅ¿t belongeth to either of them, whether it be good & vailable in Law, or no: for it oftentimes falleth out, notwithÅ¿tanding the Wil be lawfully proved before the Ordinary, yet the bequeÅ¿ts are not good, either in reÅ¿pect of the perÅ¿on to whom the bequeÅ¿ts are made, or in reÅ¿pect of the thing that is not deviÅ¿able in all, or in part; as by the Common Law, lands in Capite cannot be deviÅ¿ed, more than for two parts, but in Socage the deviÅ¿e is good for all; and by the CuÅ¿tome of the Citie of London, & Å¿ome other places of the Land, a man can bequeath no more than his deaths part, and if hee doe, his bequeÅ¿t is void for the reÅ¿t; but in other places of the land a man may bequeath all. By the Civile Law a man can bequeath nothing to a Traytor, or an Heretick, or an unlawfull Colledge, or Company (unleÅ¿Å¿e perhaps it be for the aliment, or maintenance of them in extreame poverty, that they die not for hunger, which is the worke of charitie) and if he doe, the legacie thereof is void to all intents & purpoÅ¿es. So then, the Probate of the Ordinarie in matters of land, neither helpeth, nor hindereth the right of the deviÅ¿e it Å¿elfe, but is a declaration onely of the dead mans doome uttered before Å¿uch & Å¿uch witneÅ¿Å¿es: which taketh his Å¿trength not Å¿o much from the Probate, as from the Law, and is teÅ¿tified onely by the Probate, that the Å¿ame was declared by the TeÅ¿tator, in the preÅ¿ence of the witneÅ¿Å¿es therein named, to be his true and laÅ¿t Will. So that no man herein is to be offended with the Ordinary, as preÅ¿uming of a matter not appertaining unto him, (for his teÅ¿tification in all Law and conÅ¿cience doth belong unto him, to give allowance Å¿o farre unto the defuncts Will, as it is avouched before him to be his laÅ¿t act & deed in that behalfe) but rather they are in this caÅ¿e to thanke the Ordinary, that he by that act of his hath preÅ¿erved the memorie of that, which otherwiÅ¿e perhaps would
have been loÅ¿t and periÅ¿hed, to the great hurt of the Common-wealth, and others which have private intereÅ¿t therein.

div.head: SECT. 2.

And that this was the intent of the King, when hee firÅ¿t received the Church into his protection, with all the priviledges thereof, may appeare hereby, that having united both the Jurisdictions in his owne perÅ¿on, he did not jumble them both together, as now they are, but kept them diÅ¿tinct, one from the other; not onely in authoriÅ¿ing the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall
Courts that were before, but alÅ¿o in uÅ¿ing the very words and phraÅ¿es that the JuriÅ¿dictionaries EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall did uÅ¿e every where in their writings, even theÅ¿e words whereupon men now take hold to frame Prohibitions, viz. div.head: SECT. 5.

argument.p: That the clauÅ¿e of treble Dammages in the 13. chapter 2. Edward the Å¿ixt is to be Å¿ued in the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Courts onely.

div.p:
OUt of the Statute of the 2. of Edward the Å¿ixt cap. 13. they raiÅ¿e many Prohibitions, the firÅ¿t whereof in order of the Statute, although the laÅ¿t in practiÅ¿e, is the prohibition of treble dammages, upon not dividing and Å¿etting out of Tythes, or at the leaÅ¿t, for the not compounding for them before they be carried away: Which forfeiture they Å¿uggeÅ¿t, and thereupon bring a Prohibition, and Å¿o draw the whole Å¿uit of Tythes into their Courts, contrary to the true meaning of this Å¿tatute, which would have thoÅ¿e treble dammages, in caÅ¿e of not juÅ¿tly dividing and Å¿etting out, or not compounding for the Tythes before they be carried away, be no leÅ¿Å¿e recoverable before an EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Judge according to the Kings EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law, than the forfeiture of double value (by the letting and Å¿topping of them to be carried away, whereby they are loÅ¿t, with the coÅ¿ts thereon growing) is remediable at the Å¿ame Law: For albeit the clauÅ¿e which is to redreÅ¿Å¿e this wrong, be put after that part of the Statute, which concernes the Å¿topping and letting of Tythes to be carried away, yet when there is as great reaÅ¿on hatt it Å¿hould Å¿tretch it Å¿elf to the firÅ¿t branch of the proviÅ¿ion, as to the Å¿econd, and the Å¿econd branch hangeth on the firÅ¿t by a conjunction copulative, & there is no hetorogeny or diÅ¿paritie in the matter, whereby it may not be as well verified in the one branch, as in the other, I Å¿ee no reaÅ¿on why it Å¿hould not equally reÅ¿pect them both, according to the rule of the Law; ClauÅ¿ula in fine poÅ¿ita refertur ad C. 6. tit. 28. l. 1.
omnia praecedentia, maximÃ¨ quando non reÅ¿ultaret intellectus contrarius juri, as here it doth not: for the intendment of of either branch of the Statute is, to procure by their Å¿everall forfeitures, a juÅ¿t and true payment of Tythes, the recovery whereof, as the preciÅ¿e words of the Statute in one member reÅ¿traine unto the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law; Å¿o the Identitie of reaÅ¿on in the other member doth confirme it unto the Å¿ame Law, for where there is the like reaÅ¿on or equitie, there ought to bee the like diÅ¿poÅ¿ition or order of I. Illud ff. ad l. Aquiliam. Law.

BeÅ¿ide if the principall cauÅ¿e it Å¿elfe be triable in the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Court, why Å¿hould not thoÅ¿e things which hang thereon bee tryed in the Å¿ame Court, for they are but as it were acceÅ¿Å¿ories to the principall, and Å¿o not onely follow the nature of the principall, but alÅ¿o belong to the Court of the principall, and are determinable where the principall is, for otherwiÅ¿e happily there might fall out contrary Å¿entences of one and the Å¿elfe Å¿ame thing, the one condemning, the other abÅ¿olving.

Further, in that Court wherein the courÅ¿e of JuÅ¿tice already is begun, the cauÅ¿e may with leÅ¿Å¿e labour and eaÅ¿ier expences be ended, being for the moÅ¿t part determinable by one Å¿entence, than that a new proceÅ¿Å¿e thereof Å¿hould begin before another Judge, who knoweth little or nothing of the principall matter, and therefore cannot Å¿o eaÅ¿ily decide the acceÅ¿Å¿orie.

LaÅ¿tly, thoÅ¿e which take this courÅ¿e, firÅ¿t to Å¿urmiÅ¿e a forfeiture, then to draw the originall Å¿uit, whereupon the forfeiture grew into queÅ¿tion, bring in a proceeding far different from the common Å¿tile of all well ordered Courts, in all Nations, among whom the conuÅ¿ance of the cauÅ¿e, and tryall thereof goeth before, and the forfeiture or execution thereof followeth after: But in this HyÅ¿teron proteron, the execution is in the forward, and the tryall is in the rereward: In which doing they deale much like as Cacus the Gyant dealed with Hercules Oxen, who, to the intent that Hercules Å¿hould not finde what way they were gon, drew them
backward by the tayle into his Cave; but as that device Å¿erved not Cacus, but that Hercules had his Oxen againe, Å¿o it is to be hoped, the Reverend Judges of the Land, will not long Å¿uffer this Å¿ubtiltie to prevaile, but as it came in like a Foxe, and reigned as a Wolfe, Å¿o in the end it Å¿hall dye and vaniÅ¿h away like a vaine device, much like the deÅ¿tinie of Boniface the eigth: for the reverend Judges are not onely to miniÅ¿ter juÅ¿tice betweene man and man, Å¿o that every man may have his owne, and none be oppreÅ¿Å¿ed by an other, but alÅ¿o they are to carrie an upright and indifferent hand betweene JuriÅ¿diction & JuriÅ¿diction; yea though themÅ¿elves be parties to the matter in queÅ¿tion, Å¿o that one JuriÅ¿diction eate not up an other, as the LocuÅ¿ts in Egypt devoured up all the greene things of the land.

div.head: SECT. 6.

argument.p: That the naming of Law or Statute in a Statute, doth not make it to be of the Temporall cogniÅ¿ance, if the matter thereof be EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall.

div.p:
ANother rendevous they make of the words of this ProviÅ¿o (Law, Å¿tatute, priviledge, preÅ¿cription, or compoÅ¿ition reall) as though all which paÅ¿Å¿eth under any of theÅ¿e tearms muÅ¿t belong to the triall of the Common Law, and not to the cogniÅ¿ance of the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law, and that forÅ¿ooth, becauÅ¿e theÅ¿e words and tearms are expreÅ¿Å¿ed in the Statute: which is much like unto that, as one would needes have a houÅ¿e, to be MaÅ¿ter Peacocks houÅ¿e, becauÅ¿e hee Å¿aw a Peacock Å¿it upon the top thereof: But it is not the naming of a thing in a Law or Statute, that makes it to be of the Temporall cogniÅ¿ance, or otherwiÅ¿e: but it is the nature or qualitie of the thing named, that rangeth it under the one Law, or the other. So that if the matter ordered in the Law or Statute be Temporall, the cogniÅ¿ance Å¿hall bee Temporall; if Spirituall, then the caÅ¿e is determinable in the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law: for this ProviÅ¿o is not prohibitorie,
as the laÅ¿t ProviÅ¿o of this Satute is, whereby EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Judges are forbidden to hold plea of any thing that is in the Å¿aid ProviÅ¿o conteined; but it is rather directive, and Å¿heweth where the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Judge is to give way to immunities, and to pronounce for them: Å¿o that for any thing is conteined in this ProviÅ¿o to the contrary, the cogniÅ¿ance of theÅ¿e matters, eÅ¿pecially, Priviledge, PreÅ¿cription, and CompoÅ¿ition, Å¿till remaineth at the triall of the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law, as they did before this ProviÅ¿o was made for DepraÅ¿cript. lib. 2. tit. 26. And for the other words, [Law and Statute] therein mentioned: (when as the King hath two Capacities of government in him, the one Spirituall, the other Temporall, and his high Court of Parliament, wherein Lawes are made, doth Å¿tand as well of Spirituall men, as Temporall men, and Å¿o ought to Å¿tand in both houÅ¿es, if the ancient Booke De modo tenendi Parliamenti be true and authenticall, which makes the upper HouÅ¿e of three States, the Kings MajeÅ¿tie, the Lords Spirituall, and the Lords Temporall; and the lower HouÅ¿e in like Å¿ort of three other, the Knights, the Procurators for the Clergie, and the BurgeÅ¿Å¿es; and his MajeÅ¿tie hath within this Realme aÅ¿well EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Lawyers, as Temporall, which are no leÅ¿Å¿e able to judge and determine of EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall matters, then the Temporall Lawyers of temporall buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e) It is not to be imagined, but as his Å¿acred MajeÅ¿tie will have thoÅ¿e Lawes to be held Temporall, and to have their conÅ¿tructions from Temporall Lawyers, which are made and promulged upon Temporall rights and cauÅ¿es: So alÅ¿o his HighneÅ¿Å¿e pleaÅ¿ure is, and ever hath beene of all his predeceÅ¿Å¿ours, Kings and Queenes of this Land, that Å¿uch Lawes and Statutes as are Å¿et out and publiÅ¿hed upon EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall things and matters, Å¿hall be taken and accounted EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall, and interpreted by EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Lawyers, although either of them have interchangeably each others voyce in them, to make them a Law.

div.head: SECT. 7.

argument.p: That the curioÅ¿itie of School-men, in their diÅ¿tinctions upon Tythes, have helped forward Appropriations and Exemptions from Tythes. The Opinion examined, as concerning the Quotitie of Tythes, whether it be Morall, Ceremoniall, or Judiciall.

div.p:
ANd theÅ¿e are thoÅ¿e greevances of the Church, which I Å¿aid the School-mens curioÅ¿itie in their diÅ¿tinctions, either invented, or gave Å¿trength unto them after they were invented; but invent them all, I thinke, they did not, for that theÅ¿e Acts of Appropriations of benefices were Å¿omewhat more ancient than the School-men themÅ¿elves are t ãâ¦ã but the reÅ¿t of the Priviledges, they either came into the world with them, or enÅ¿ued anon afterthem, Å¿o that I may well Å¿ay, they much Å¿trengthened this iniquitie. For when that every man underÅ¿tood by their Doctrine the quotitie of Tythes, or the ãâã part thereof was not preciÅ¿ely by Gods Law (Å¿ince the light of the GoÅ¿pel Å¿prang out as the day light unto the ChriÅ¿tians, who before Å¿ate in darkeneÅ¿Å¿e, and in the Å¿hadow of death) but that it was by the inÅ¿titution of the
Church only: then began they freely to Å¿poyle the Church of her due Tythes, and to give away that to one Church, that was due to an other. And the reaÅ¿on that perÅ¿wadeth the School-men to this, was, that after much adoe, dividing the whole Law of MoÅ¿es into three parts, the Morall, the Judiciall, and the Ceremoniall; they did conclude, that there were three parts likewiÅ¿e in the Tythe, the one Morall, which was a neceÅ¿Å¿arie maintenance for the MiniÅ¿ter, and therefore was naturall and perpetuall: the other Judiciall, which was the number of ten, fit, as they taught, for that people onely, and therefore was poÅ¿itive and remotive: the laÅ¿t Ceremoniall, and that was the myÅ¿terie contained in this Quotitie, or number of Ten, which being but a Å¿hadow onely, was aboliÅ¿hed with the Law it Å¿elfe: whereby they did inferre the preciÅ¿e number of Ten being taken away, by reaÅ¿on of the Ceremonie it Å¿elfe, a competencie now onely doth remaine for the MiniÅ¿ter out of the Tythes: which opinion hath beene well confuted of late, by a very learned man, as his TreatiÅ¿e thereof doth well Å¿hew; but I feare with leÅ¿Å¿e Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e, than the truth of the cauÅ¿e doth deÅ¿erve, for this is a point that toucheth many mens private benefite, and therefore Å¿hall have no more favour than it needs muÅ¿t.

But the deviÅ¿e whereon the School-men did build this Thom. in quodlibet part. 3. art. 6. q. 6. Ceremonie is this, that as all Digits under ten are unperfect, and doe tend to ten as to their perfectneÅ¿Å¿e; Å¿o all men, Å¿ave ChriÅ¿t alone, are unperfect, and have need of ChriÅ¿ts righteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e to make them perfect: Which Abraham well knowing, paid Tythes to MelchiÅ¿edech, who was the figure of ChriÅ¿t, as therein acknowledging, that himÅ¿elfe and all mankinde, who were repreÅ¿ented by the other nine Digits were unperfect by reaÅ¿on of Originall Sin dwelling in them, and therefore had need to bee perfected by ChriÅ¿t, Idem part. 22. q. 87. art. 1. who was figured by the tenth number.

All which that we may grant to be true betweene ChriÅ¿t and all mankinde, as it is true indeed, and that ten is the perfection of the other numbers under ten, for that all the reÅ¿t
of the Digits, when they come to ten, returne back againe to ten, and are multiplied by the coupling of themÅ¿elves with ten: yet, where is this proportion betweene ChriÅ¿t and ten in the Scripture, that Å¿hould make this Ceremonie? which if it cannot be found any where, nor any conÅ¿ent of the primitive Church Å¿hewed for it, as I thinke it cannot be, then may it with as good authoritie be rejected as it is received. For albeit Thomas Aquinas himÅ¿elfe was tearmed a Seraphicall Doctor, that is, Å¿uch a one as had a Å¿enÅ¿e in the underÅ¿tanding of the holy Scripture above all others of his age, and that he did much profit the Å¿tudie of Divinity, with his wittie diÅ¿tinctions: yet is not his authoritie Å¿uch, that it muÅ¿t prevaile in caÅ¿es of Divinitie, without the authoritie of the Scripture, and the conÅ¿ent of the ancient Fathers of the primitive Church, interpreting this peece of Scripture in that Å¿enÅ¿e as he doth, which would make a Å¿weet harmony if it might be had.

And therefore as to my poore Å¿enÅ¿e, better Å¿aid a learned man of our time to this point, writing upon the Sabbath day Iunius in 2. c. 3. GeneÅ¿eo â¢ . in the Å¿econd of GeneÅ¿is, which may be alÅ¿o proportionably underÅ¿tood of the tenth, for that they, were both before the Law in their very number, and were but repeated by MoÅ¿es under the Law, becauÅ¿e they had beene approved by God before the Law in the Å¿elfe Å¿ame numbers: and that which hee Å¿aith of the Sabbath is this, that albeit it hath a Ceremoniall deÅ¿ignation of the day, that is, that it doth figure unto us our perpetuall reÅ¿t, which we Å¿hall have in heaven, after that there is a new heaven and a new earth, yet there is therein two parts, the one naturall, the other poÅ¿itive, as that God Å¿hould have a Å¿eventh day of worÅ¿hip, this is Naturall, and therefore doth remaine, becauÅ¿e it is perpetuall: but that this Å¿eventh day of the Lords worÅ¿hip Å¿hould bee the Å¿eventh after the Creation of the world, this was poÅ¿itive, and therefore was changed by the ApoÅ¿tles and bleÅ¿Å¿ed men of the primitive Church, into the Å¿eventh day after the ReÅ¿urrection of our Saviour JeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t: which, as it is verified by him in the Sabbath, Å¿o may it be in like Å¿ort vouched
by like reaÅ¿on in the tenth, wherein alÅ¿o by like Å¿emblance there are two parts, the one naturall, the other poÅ¿itive. The naturall is this: that God our of all the fruits of the earth, the increaÅ¿e of cattell that are worthy of him, and fit for mans uÅ¿e, Å¿hould have a tenth, both in the acknowledgement of his univerÅ¿all government over us, and alÅ¿o for the proviÅ¿ion of his miniÅ¿ters, and therefore this remaineth: & in that Å¿ence immediately after the diÅ¿olution of the Jews policie, the good ChriÅ¿tians of the Primitive Church, as Å¿oone as they could get any outward forme of a Church, & peace from perÅ¿ecution received it in the very quotitie, as a thing no leÅ¿Å¿e belonging to their MiniÅ¿ters, than it did appertaine to the PrieÅ¿ts, & Levites of the Law: But that the Lord annexed theÅ¿e Tythes by MoÅ¿es to the PrieÅ¿t & Levites for their maintenance, during the time of the diÅ¿penÅ¿ing of the myÅ¿teries under the Law, this is poÅ¿itive, and therefore changed by the good ChriÅ¿tians in the Primitive Church, froÌ the Jewes EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tiques to the ChriÅ¿tian EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tiques.

Neither can it be thought that this number came froÌ the Judiciall part of the Law, as a fit proportion to maintain one Tribe, out of the revenues of the other eleven Tribes: for that this number, or quotitie was revealed to be Gods long before the Law, and before there were any Å¿uch diviÅ¿ion of Tribes among the people of IÅ¿raell; which then were not, but were parted afterward by MoÅ¿es into families according to the number of the twelve Å¿onnes of Jacob. And therefore it is not to be preÅ¿umed, that the Law which came long after, imprinted a forme upon that, which was Å¿o long in beeing before there was any Law or Ceremony. But as the ApoÅ¿tles, or prime ChriÅ¿tians, vvhen as they did firÅ¿t change the day of the Sabbath by divine inÅ¿piration, or otherwiÅ¿e, from the day of the Creation, to the day of the ReÅ¿urrection, durÅ¿t not Å¿ubÅ¿titute any other day into the place of the firÅ¿t day, than a Å¿eaventh; for that the Lord had revealed his pleaÅ¿ure in many places of the Scripture as concerning that number, for his day of vvorÅ¿hip, Å¿o that no other day could be appointed for his day
of worÅ¿hip than a Å¿eaventh: So neither durÅ¿t the good ChriÅ¿tians of the Primitive Church (moved no doubt with no other inÅ¿tinct then the other were, when they tranÅ¿lated this proviÅ¿ion of Tythes for their miniÅ¿tery from the JewiÅ¿h Church unto their owne Church) change the number of ten into another number beÅ¿ides, more or leÅ¿Å¿e: For that God had no leÅ¿Å¿e manifeÅ¿ted his will in Å¿undry parts of the Scripture, as concerning this number, to be a number for the maintenance of his miniÅ¿trie, than he had declared his pleaÅ¿ure as concerning that other number to be a day for his honour, challenging it every where in the Scripture, in the very quotitie for his owne right, and counting it robberie if it were at any time with-holden from him. And therfore it may be well thought, the School-men herein did great wrong to the Church, who by their quaint diÅ¿tinctions brought this certaintie into an uncertaintie, which is no where to be found in the Scripture. Which I am more bold to Å¿peake, for that I Å¿ee Å¿ome have trod this path before me, and Å¿hewed by good demonÅ¿tration, that the turning of this quotitie into a competencie is a thing nothing warrantable by the word of God, but that the quotitie ought Å¿till to Å¿tand as a perpetuall right due to God and his Church. And as the diÅ¿poÅ¿ition of every exhalation Å¿o compacted and drawne together is finer or groÅ¿Å¿er, hotter or colder, Å¿o is the Mettall or Minerall, or other Å¿ubterraneous body, more noble or more baÅ¿e: yea, Å¿omtimes by reaÅ¿on of this diverÅ¿itie of exhalations and vapours, drawne together at one time, are divers conditions of Mettals there confounded together, whereof Å¿ome are noble, as Gold, Silver, and Copper; Å¿ome other are of leÅ¿Å¿e eÅ¿timate, as Tin, Lead, and Å¿uch like. Neither doe theÅ¿e grow onely in the beginning, but they renew againe when they are digged up, (as Trees and Plants in the upper face of the Earth doe riÅ¿e out of the rootes and Å¿temmes of thoÅ¿e trees which have beene cut downe) if the place of their new generation be prepared accordingly: For whereas the place of their generation is farre below in the Earth, Nature, of a certaine modeÅ¿ty in her Å¿elfe, will not yeeld to the generation of theÅ¿e Å¿ubterraneous bodies, but in Å¿ecret places, far remote from the Å¿ight of the Sun, and the privity of other Meteoricall bodies, which are under the firmament. And by that meanes it hapneth, that theÅ¿e Minerall bodies are rarely known & perceived to renew againe; for that being once expoÅ¿ed to the light of the Sunne, they are Å¿eldome or never cloÅ¿ed up againe, by reaÅ¿on of the greatneÅ¿Å¿e of the gulfe that is made in opening of them. But yet the nature of them is Å¿uch, that if their bed were thereto prepared accordingly, ff. Soluto Matrimonio, l. fructus eos. Â§. 13. plin. lib. 36. c. 15. & 18. de naturali HiÅ¿t. they would conceive a new: Which is a thing Å¿o notorious in Quarries of Å¿tone, which are leÅ¿Å¿e abaÅ¿hed at the Å¿ight of the Sunne, and the preÅ¿ence of other Meteoricall bodies in their generation, that the Law it Å¿elfe, and other
good Authors have Å¿et it downe for an undoubted experience, that being digged up, they doe renew againe, by the nature and diÅ¿poÅ¿ition of the mould wherein they are ingendered: Strabo lib. ãâã
For Å¿ome Earths doe as naturally yeeld Å¿tones, and other minerals out of them, as others bring forth Corne, Hay, and other fruits: which if it be true in thoÅ¿e bodies which are in the upper cruÅ¿t of the Earth, why not alÅ¿o in thoÅ¿e bodies which are found and framed below in the Matrix thereof? And if theÅ¿e bodies doe both ingender and renew, which are conceived Å¿o farre below in the Navell of the Earth, why is not Tythe due of them, aÅ¿well as it is of other fruits that are in the Å¿ummitie or heigth of the earth? Whether is it, that Gods hand leÅ¿Å¿e laboureth in the procreation of theÅ¿e Å¿ubterraneous bodies, than it doth in the ripening and quickning of that fruit, that Å¿prings out of the upper face of the Earth? But that is farre otherwiÅ¿e, for here in theÅ¿e upper fruites, one planteth, an other watereth, and God onely gives the increaÅ¿e: But in the other Minerall bodies, God alone doth all, for hee only is the planter, hee is the waterer, and he gives the increaÅ¿e alone. Or is it that God hath leÅ¿Å¿e delight to be honoured with theÅ¿e hid treaÅ¿ures of the earth, than he hath to be worÅ¿hipped with the labour of the plow, or the increaÅ¿e of the cattell of the field? But, that this is not Å¿o, it is plaine by the glorious Temple that Salomon made, which had not only Cedar trees for 2. Chron. cap. 2. the roofe thereof, and Algummin wood for the ornaments thereof, but alÅ¿o had quarrie Å¿tone for the wals thereof, and gold of Paruaim for the beautifying of it, and for the overlaying of it within. And of all other kinde of Mettals, Gold is firÅ¿t remembred in the Scripture, immediately after the GeneÅ¿. 2. verÅ¿. 11 & 12. creation of the world, Å¿o that God himÅ¿elfe may Å¿oeme to have a Å¿peciall regard of this Mettall above the reÅ¿t, for that this alone above all the reÅ¿t, by purifying is not diminiÅ¿hed. Or is it, that God loveth his MiniÅ¿ters leÅ¿Å¿e than other men, Å¿o that hee would have the Laity to have all the precious things of the earth, and his MiniÅ¿ters to have no part of any other thing, but that which is vulgar and common? But
how unlike that is, who Å¿ees not, when hee Å¿eeth that God hath committed unto them, the ineÅ¿timable treaÅ¿ures of his word; in compariÅ¿on where of, both theÅ¿e upper fruits of the earth, and thoÅ¿e hid treaÅ¿ures below, are meere droÅ¿Å¿e and corruption? and therefore it is not like, when he hath committed unto them thoÅ¿e great matters, hee would deny unto them theÅ¿e Å¿maller bleÅ¿Å¿ings. Or is it, that there hath beene paid Tythes of the upper fruit of the earth already, and therefore cannot Tythe be twice demanded of one ground Ca. ex parte de Decimis, & ibi Ab. 18. in one yeare, according to a new over-ruled doctrine? But that opinion is both contrary to Law many hundred yeares obtained in the Church without contradiction, whereby it is ordained, that as often as the earth fructifieth in one yeare, Å¿o often Å¿hall Tythes in the Å¿ame yeare bee paid of it: and alÅ¿o it is contrary to Divinitie and reaÅ¿on, that it Å¿hould bee otherwiÅ¿e. For when as God hath given thee more HarveÅ¿t or more Vintages in one yeare, is it not both godly and reaÅ¿onable, as God hath increaÅ¿ed his bleÅ¿Å¿ings towards thee, Å¿o thou alÅ¿o Å¿houldeÅ¿t riÅ¿e in thank fulneÅ¿Å¿e towards him? For, where every one hath received more grace or more favour, there ought he to be more thankfull, leÅ¿t God for lack of this correÅ¿pondencie in thankfulneÅ¿Å¿e, bring thy nine parts, for thine ingratitude towards him, to a tenth onely. For certainely Å¿o hee is able to doe, by Å¿ending deluge and drought upon the earth, by bringing barrenneÅ¿Å¿e upon it, by deÅ¿troying that which is Å¿prung out of the earth already, by Å¿torme and tempeÅ¿t, by the GraÅ¿hopper and the Caterpiller: for all this hath hee threatned to all thoÅ¿e that are unthankfull this way, neither is the Lords hand more Å¿hortned now than it was then. Whereas notwithÅ¿tanding to the contrary, hee hath promiÅ¿ed great kindneÅ¿Å¿e unto Å¿uch as Å¿hall pay their Tythes truely and cheerfully, as that hee will open the windowes of heaven, and powre out his bleÅ¿Å¿ings without meaÅ¿ure upon them. Hilarem enim datorem amat Deus. BeÅ¿ides this, the earth that bringeth out mettals in the matrix of the earth, is not that that bringeth out corne and graÅ¿Å¿e in the top of the earth: for that earth that is
the mother of mettals, being preÅ¿t downe farre into the bowels of the earth, can yeeld no Å¿uÅ¿tenance to thoÅ¿e fruits that grow Å¿o many fathoms above it, to which it conferres nothing Å¿ave that it doth Å¿upport and beare up that other earth, which nouriÅ¿heth the plants and fruits of the upper earth, whoÅ¿e Å¿uÅ¿tenance is not fetch't deep out of the earth, but is Å¿uckt out of that earth which is with in one cubit, or two of the top of the earth: which may eaÅ¿ily be perceived by thoÅ¿e fruits and trees that grow upon hard rockes neere to the top of the earth, whoÅ¿e food, although it be neere unto the top of the earth yet do they flouriÅ¿h, and Å¿tand faÅ¿t, as other trees and fruits doe, which have more fat and deepe mould under them. And therefore cannot the Tything of thoÅ¿e things which are above, excuÅ¿e the Tytheing of the treaÅ¿ures that are below, albeit the concluÅ¿ion were true, that two things are not to be paid out of one ground in one yeare, for theÅ¿e are not one ground, and the concluÅ¿ion it Å¿elfe is erroneous, and therefore I conclude this point thus: Since Mettals and minerals, and other Å¿ubterraneous bodies are in no leÅ¿Å¿e Obligation to God, than other fruits of the earth are, there muÅ¿t be no leÅ¿Å¿e Tythes paid of them, than are of other fruits of the earth: for that theÅ¿e are the inward fruits of the earth, as well as thoÅ¿e are the outward, and therefore of like things, there muÅ¿t be like judgement and like conÅ¿equence. And thus much as concerning the Tythes of Mettals and Minerals.

div.head: SECT. 3.

argument.p: That Tythes of Turves be due.

div.p:
ANd now becauÅ¿e I am in this matter of Tythes, I will Å¿hape an anÅ¿wer to one doubt that is made, as concerning the Tythes of Turves, that is, of earth diÅ¿poÅ¿ed, and prepared for fewell, which are Å¿aid not to be Tytheable, and that upon this reaÅ¿on: That Tythes are not paid of the earth it Å¿elfe, but of thoÅ¿e things which Å¿pring out of the earth: which opinion is true, if it be underÅ¿tood of earth
not Å¿eparated from the body, and maÅ¿Å¿e of the reÅ¿t of the earth. For if Tythes Å¿hould be yearely paid thereof, as it is paid of other things that grow out of the earth, all the whole earth in a Å¿hort time would become the Clergies. But if it be meant of earth that is Å¿evered from the reÅ¿t of the maÅ¿Å¿e, and globe of the earth, then is it otherwiÅ¿e. For that earth that is thus Å¿evered from the other earth, is no more part of that earth from whence it is Å¿evered, than a mans hand, or leg being Å¿ever'd froÌ the body, is part of his body after it is cut off from it. And therefore of this earth Å¿o provided for fewell, may Tythes as well be paid, as of any other fewell of wood, cole, or otherwiÅ¿e that is provided to be burnt. For there is one reaÅ¿on of things, when they are united together in one body, and another of thoÅ¿e things, when they are divided from the Å¿ame bodie: for Å¿o long as they are in one and the Å¿elfe Å¿ame body, they follow the nature of the whole, but when they are divided, then is there another conÅ¿ideration of them. Separatorum enim Å¿eperata eÅ¿t ratio, & ex Å¿eperatis non infertur de uno ad aliud. L. finali. ff. de calumntatoribus. Corne, GraÅ¿Å¿e, and Å¿uch like, while they Å¿tand, are not Tytheable, although the Tythe then is in them pro indiviÅ¿o: For while that they Å¿tand, they are part of the earth upon which they Å¿tand, and therefore Å¿o long untytheable, becauÅ¿e the earth it Å¿elfe is untytheable. But if they be cut downe, then are they to be Tythed, becauÅ¿e they are now no longer parts of the earth, but bodies by themÅ¿elves Å¿eparated from the earth, Å¿o that now the not tything of them is penall: Of which Å¿ort are turves Å¿eperated from the reÅ¿t of the maÅ¿Å¿e of the earth. Neither is this my opinion alone, but it was Linwoods long agoe, and other EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall writers, who not onely make Turfe Tytheable, Provincial, de decim. c. Å¿ancta, & ibi Linwood verbo turbaruÌ. when it is prepared for fire, but alÅ¿o great rods, and Å¿mall twigges, Å¿tickes, and chips of timber, buts, and roots of trees, thornes, bryers, walnut Å¿hels, and nut Å¿hels, vveeds, coles, and cole-brands (called Titiones, becauÅ¿e they are Å¿o L. Ligni appellaitione Â§ 4. 5 & 6 ff. de legat. 3. burnt as they Å¿hall not make a Å¿moake) cowÅ¿hards, which the Law calls Editus boum. All which a man can uÅ¿e to
no other purpoÅ¿e than to burne: for where wood lackes, theÅ¿e Å¿ucceed in place of wood, and are called by the name of wood, and are in like obligation, as concerning the Tythe due thereout, as wood it Å¿elfe is; Vbicunque enim eÅ¿t cadem L. Illud. ff ad legem Aqu ãâ¦ã . ratio, veleadem aequitas, ibi debet eÅ¿Å¿e eadem juris diÅ¿poÅ¿itio. And therefore not in that, that Turves Å¿ometimes were gremiall earth, they are to bee diÅ¿charged of Tythe: but in that they are accounted for Fewell by the law, when they are Å¿o prepared to be burnt, they are to pay Tythes in like Å¿ort, as other things applyed to that uÅ¿e do.

div.head: SECT. 4.

argument.p: That the cogniÅ¿ance of barren heath, and waÅ¿te grounds belongeth to the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Courts, and what every of them are.

div.p: ANd Å¿o farre as concerning the Prohibitions which ariÅ¿e out of this proviÅ¿o. Now it followeth that I Å¿peake Å¿omething of the next proviÅ¿o, which is concerning 2 Ed 6. c. ãâã . 3. the Tythes of barren heath, and waÅ¿te ground, and the Prohibitions thereupon.

This proviÅ¿o hath two branches, the one for comparitive barren heath, and waÅ¿te ground, the other for abÅ¿olute barren heath, and waÅ¿te, for either of which is aÅ¿Å¿igned a time of Å¿even yeares, either for the paiment of Å¿uch Tythes, as before the time of their improvement, and converting to arable, they were charged with, or for the free and abÅ¿olute diÅ¿charge of them from all manner of Tythes for Å¿eaven whole yeares next after their improvement ended and determined. For Å¿o I take the Statute meant, when as it made the one Tytheable, the other not, for if otherwiÅ¿e they had beene both in one predicament of the barrenneÅ¿Å¿e, the Å¿tatute had not made the one free from Tythe for Å¿o many yeares as it doth, and charged the other all that tune with Tythe.

For theÅ¿e two kindes of grounds, although the Statute Å¿ay nothing, which is comparative barren, which is abÅ¿olute,
yet reaÅ¿on telleth us, that is comparative that hath a poÅ¿itive under it, and a Å¿uperlative above it: and therefore that is comparative waÅ¿te, barren, or heath, in reÅ¿pect whereof there is Å¿ome over ground more or leÅ¿Å¿e, vvaÅ¿te, heath, or barren, Å¿o that it hath Å¿imply and poÅ¿itively in it Å¿ome condition of heath, waÅ¿te, or barren: but if it hath nothing of any of theÅ¿e qualities in it, then is it neither heath, barren or waÅ¿te, howÅ¿oever long otherwiÅ¿e it hath lien unmanured, and not turned to tillage: For it is not the turning of a ground to tillage that makes it heath, barren, or waÅ¿te, but it is the ill diÅ¿poÅ¿ition of the ground it Å¿elfe, Å¿ubject to theÅ¿e inconveniences, that cauÅ¿eth it not to be turned to tillage; for no man will willingly till that, where the gaine of the tillage will not quit the coÅ¿t and labour of husbandrie, as for the moÅ¿t part it falleth out theÅ¿e grounds that they doe not.

Barren ground therefore Å¿imply, is that which being eared, yeeldeth not the Å¿eede againe, or at the moÅ¿t, yeeldeth Å¿o Å¿mall advantage for the tillage, as that the tenant GloÅ¿. L. licet. C. de locato & conducto verbo Å¿terilitates. after that hee hath paid his Rent, hath not the worth of halfe his Å¿eede againe; much like unto that ground whereof the Scripture Å¿peaketh, whoÅ¿e barrenneÅ¿Å¿e is Å¿uch, as being eared, and Å¿owed, neither the Mower Å¿illeth his hand, neither the Gleaner his lap with the yeeld thereof. TheÅ¿e grounds are not onely called Sterilia of the Latines, but alÅ¿o InÅ¿oecunda, Infrugifera, & Å¿ine prole, for the exceÅ¿Å¿ive barrenneÅ¿Å¿e that is in them: and the Greeks upon like occaÅ¿ion terme Å¿uch conditioned grounds; ã in non-Latin alphabet ã
L. Å¿i quis uÅ¿uras. ff. de eo qus protutore.
ã in non-Latin alphabet ã , in which Å¿ence, money not put to uÅ¿ury is by the Law called barren money, and AriÅ¿totle calleth it fruitleÅ¿Å¿e money: for that mony was not deviÅ¿ed thereby to increaÅ¿e money, as greedy uÅ¿urers in all ages have done, but AriÅ¿t. 1. l. politicorum. that by the meanes thereof men might eaÅ¿e the difficulties, and neceÅ¿Å¿ities of change of one kind of thing for another, as a horÅ¿e for an oxe, Å¿heepe for a goat, iron for braÅ¿Å¿e, and Å¿uch like: for there is nothing that may not be eÅ¿teemed by AriÅ¿t. 4. Ethicorum. c. 1. money, and the uÅ¿e of money, is the uttering of money,
whereby it is commonly Å¿aid, Money is loÅ¿t by the uÅ¿e thereof, not that money doth periÅ¿h or decay by uÅ¿e, for wee Å¿ee the cleane contrarie to that, for though money goe thorough a thouÅ¿and mens hands, yet it is Å¿till of the Å¿ame value, and remaineth in her proper eÅ¿Å¿ence or being: but that the uÅ¿e of money is in the laying of it out, and that by the uÅ¿e thereof, money paÅ¿Å¿eth from him whoÅ¿e it was, and the propertie thereof goeth to another, and therefore as to the firÅ¿t owner it is Å¿pent, and loÅ¿t: without which looÅ¿ing, money naturally gaineth nothing; for lay it up in a coÅ¿ter or cheÅ¿t never Å¿o long, it will never be the more in number, although perhaps as S. James Å¿aith, It will gather a ruÅ¿t Iam. cap. 5. 7. 1. and canker, and that ruÅ¿t, and canker will be a witneÅ¿Å¿e againÅ¿t them which Å¿o hoord it up from the Å¿ervice of God, and the Common wealth, in the day of the Lord: So then, as that money is barren, that lyeth Å¿till, and bringeth out nothing, Å¿o is that ground barren, that being tilled, yeeldeth no fruit, or at the moÅ¿t, Å¿o little as the gaines will not recompence the charge.

Although heath ground, and barren ground be almoÅ¿t Synonomies, yet to Å¿peake properly, heath is as it were an effect of barrenneÅ¿Å¿e, for that there is no ground that bringeth forth heath, but for the moÅ¿t part it is barren. And therefore as heath it Å¿elfe is an unfruitfull kinde of Å¿hrubs, and is good almoÅ¿t for nothing but for the fire; for that neither growing or cut downe, it hath any beneficiall uÅ¿e at all for the common wealth: Å¿o alÅ¿o the ground it Å¿pringeth out of, hath neither faireneÅ¿Å¿e to the eye, nor goodneÅ¿Å¿e to the yeeld, but is commonly either a blacke Å¿ower ground, that hath no Å¿weetneÅ¿Å¿e at all in it, or is a drie hungrie Å¿oyle, Å¿uch as evermore cryeth give, give, and never reÅ¿toreth ought againe. Proverb. 12.

WaÅ¿te is that which for the unfruitfulneÅ¿Å¿e thereof hath layen time out of minde unmanured, in which Å¿ence it is all one with barren ground; or it is Å¿uch ground as for the charge of hedging, ditching, fencing, and tilling no man will manure.

Our forefathers anciently compriÅ¿ed all theÅ¿e three under one name, calling them them all by the name of Novalia, that is, new-broken-up-ground, not onely becauÅ¿e they were not broken up in the memorie of man before, but alÅ¿o, for that being eared, they yeelded little or no fruit at all: and therefore the interpreters of the Law defining what Novalia are, Å¿ay, that they are Å¿uch grounds as before the tillage therof were inutilia; & example them out, in Mountaines, C. commiÅ¿Å¿um de decimis verbo inutilia. MarÅ¿hes, Thickets, and Å¿uch other unprofitable ground, as out of which before the Å¿tocking of them up, and converting them to tillage, the Church tooke little or no benefit at all. And thoÅ¿e are the Å¿ame or coÅ¿en German to thoÅ¿e which this Statute calleth heath, barren and waÅ¿te, for they are one and the very Å¿elfe Å¿ame vvith them, in all the chiefe points, for which they are excepted out of the Statute.

So then now, there is no further queÅ¿tion what is heath, barren, and vvaÅ¿te ground, but who Å¿hall trie the matter of this quality; whether the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Judge, in whoÅ¿e continuall poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion this triall hath beene untill now of late, that under colour of this Statute, it hath bin incroched upon as it may appeare by all the Titles of the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law, where there is any mention of the Tythes of new broken upground, and the decrees of the Lawgivers in the Å¿ame, betweene the MonaÅ¿tories challenging them by graunt, and the Parochian MiniÅ¿ters of the PariÅ¿hes vvhere they grew, claiming the Å¿ame by right: Or the Temporall Judges vvhoÅ¿e is the CogniÅ¿ance of the Tytle, and Tenure of the ground, as alÅ¿o is the Å¿etting, letting, buying, Å¿elling, and other alienating of the Å¿ame.

For the point it Å¿elfe, the Statute maketh no mention but paÅ¿Å¿eth it over with Å¿ilence; and therefore it is to be preÅ¿umed that it meant, that it Å¿hould there reÅ¿t, where it was before the making of the Statute: for the Statute was not made in derogation of the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall proceedings, that were before; but in affirmance thereof, as the whole drift of the Å¿aid Statute doth Å¿hew.

And if the Statute had meant otherwiÅ¿e, it vvould Å¿urely have expreÅ¿Å¿ed it either in the proviÅ¿o it Å¿elf, or after in the derogatory clauÅ¿e; where it maketh an enumeration of Å¿uch things as it intended Å¿hould be exempted from the tryall of the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law, and by vertue of this Statute, Å¿hould not be compriÅ¿ed under the Å¿ame, among which there is no word of this proviÅ¿o, or any other in the Å¿ame Statute before named.

Neither is it unto the purpoÅ¿e, that the Common Law of this Land taketh knowledge of the Tenure and Title of Lands, and Å¿uch other complements belonging to the Å¿ame; for theÅ¿e things that are here in queÅ¿tion, are no part of thoÅ¿e Legall EÅ¿Å¿ences, which the Law requireth to the Tytle and Tenure thereof, as is Fee-Å¿imple, Fee-taile, and other of like nature, according to the learning of that Law, but theÅ¿e are certaine accidents over and beÅ¿ide the Tenure of the Land which may be preÅ¿ent or abÅ¿ent without the injurie of the Tytle: as God many times turnes flouds into wilderneÅ¿Å¿e, and Å¿prings of vvater againe into drineÅ¿Å¿e, and a fruitfull Land makes hee barren for the wickedneÅ¿Å¿e of them that dwell therein, and yet the Tytle or Tenure of the ground is not changed, by theÅ¿e changes of qualities, but remaines the Å¿elfe Å¿ame that it was: Å¿o that theÅ¿e things are no more Å¿ubject to the ordering of the Common Law, than it is in the Common Law, to judge and determine what mould is white and what is blacke; what ground will beare wheat, vvhat barley, vvhat oats; for theÅ¿e things are no matters of skill of Law, that they need to be fetcht out of bookes, but they are matters of common experience which every country man can as well skill of, as the greateÅ¿t Lawyer that is, and therefore the Law in this caÅ¿e is not deÅ¿irous of any curious proofe, but contenteth it Å¿elfe onely vvith the depoÅ¿itions of two or three honeÅ¿t men, which Å¿peake Å¿enÅ¿ibly and feelingly to the point that is in hand, vvhich is enough to direct any wiÅ¿e Judge in his Å¿entence, Å¿o that it needs not theÅ¿e long circumÅ¿tances of twelve men to teach the Judge what, and
how truly the witneÅ¿Å¿es have depoÅ¿ed. For if every qualitie of the ground reÅ¿teth in the mouth of twelve men onely, then Å¿hould no man be able to Å¿ay out of the mouth of a witneÅ¿Å¿e, and pronounce thereupon, this ground is mountaine, this is plaine, this is medowe, this is arrable, unleÅ¿Å¿e hee were warranted by the verdit of twelve men thereunto: which if it be an abÅ¿urditie to hold, then Å¿ure it is a like abÅ¿urditie to Å¿ay, that barren, & heath, waÅ¿te cannot be pronounced without a Jurie, for that theÅ¿e things are like obvious to Å¿enÅ¿e, and of like qualitie as the others are.

And I pray you, when they have drawne it unto their tryall, what do they in effect otherwiÅ¿e than the EcclehaÅ¿ticall Judge would or Å¿hould have done, if it had remained Å¿till under him? for do they give credit Å¿imply to the conceit of the Jurie, as touching that which hath beene declared, and pleaded in the cauÅ¿e before them, or do not the Judges themÅ¿elves rather make a briefe of all that hath beene pleaded in the cauÅ¿e before them, and thereof make as it were a verdit, and put the Å¿ame in the mouth of the twelve for their verdit, before they goe from the barre? So that the whole weight of the cauÅ¿e Å¿tandeth rather in the Judges direction, in Å¿uch Å¿ort as it is at the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law, than it doth in the mouth of the Jurie; for the Jurie men for the moÅ¿t part, are Å¿imple people, and Å¿carce foure of the twelve underÅ¿tand their evidence: Å¿o that it may Å¿eeme rather to be a matter of Å¿uperfluitie than of good policie, to referre a matter to their verdit, vvhen as they Å¿ay no other thing, than what the Judge taught them before; Stultum eÅ¿t enimid facere per plura, quod fieri poteÅ¿t per pauciora: for albeit perhaps Å¿ome capricious fellow of the Jurie, upon the confidence of his owne braine, Å¿ometimes Å¿tart aÅ¿ide from that which the Judge hath told him, and draw the reÅ¿t of his fellowes, as Å¿o many Å¿heepe after him; yet for the moÅ¿t part the Judges voice is their direction, their loadÅ¿tone, and the North pole to guide them in this buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e.
BeÅ¿ides, in this ProviÅ¿o, as in Å¿ome other precedent, there is a great diÅ¿advantage offered to the Clergie, which they much complaine of, and that is, that in caÅ¿es of this nature, they are compelled to Å¿uffer triall under them, who are in a manner, parties unto the Å¿uit, by reaÅ¿on of the intereÅ¿t they have therein, either in preÅ¿ent, or in conÅ¿equence; Å¿o that many now adayes (learning too late by other mens harmes what the event in their owne cauÅ¿e will be) chuÅ¿e rather to loÅ¿e their right, than to venture their cauÅ¿e upon Å¿uch partiall Judges, as the twelve men are.

div.head: SECT. 5.

div.p: ANd Å¿o far as concerning thoÅ¿e prohibitions which are forced out of this Statute, for naturally they grow not out thereof: Å¿o that I might now paÅ¿Å¿e over to the other branch of my diviÅ¿ion, that is, of Å¿uch matters as are now held by the Common Lawyers, to bee in a certaine meaÅ¿ure onely of the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall proceeding, but were anciently wholly of the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall cogniÅ¿ance; but that the name of the Statute, De Sylua caedua, offering it Å¿elfe unto mee in the concluÅ¿ion of this Statute of Edward the Å¿ixth, gives mee occaÅ¿ion to Å¿peake Å¿omthing thereof, before I come to the reÅ¿t.

This Statute, as the words thereof doe Å¿hew, was made in behalfe of the Laitie againÅ¿t the Clergie, for the exemption of great Woods of twenty yeares growth and upward, from the payment of Tythes; and that in three caÅ¿es onely, where the wood was great, when it was xx. yeares of age and upward, where it was Å¿old to Merchants, either to the profit of the owner himÅ¿elfe, or in ayde of the King in his warres; Å¿o that without theÅ¿e caÅ¿es, it Å¿eemeth the Statute intended no further exemption: for Statutes are things of Å¿trict Law, and are no further to bee extended, than the words thereof give matter thereunto, eÅ¿pecially when
the thing it Å¿elfe naturally was liable to ordinary courÅ¿e of the Law, as other things of like nature are, and the Statute comes in derogation of their ordinary courÅ¿e: as in this caÅ¿e, great timber anciently was no leÅ¿Å¿e tytheable than Å¿mall trees are, and Å¿o by nature ought to be, if the Statute were not to the contrary; yet notwithÅ¿tanding theÅ¿e limitations of the Å¿ame, if great wood bee cut downe to any other uÅ¿e than to Å¿ale, as to build, or to burne to a mans owne uÅ¿e, a prohibition in this caÅ¿e lyeth, and yet is there no Identitie of reaÅ¿on to extend it, nor any abÅ¿urdity would follow, if it were not extended; for here is neither money Å¿ought, (which gave occaÅ¿ion unto the Law-givers to make this Statute of exemption) neither is it an unnaturall thing, for to pay Tythes of great wood; for before this time they were paid, and by the Law of God, it Å¿eemes, they ought to bee Gal. 6. 6. paid; for that he that is taught, ought to communicate to him that teacheth him in all things: and therefore Å¿ince the reaÅ¿on that moved the Law-givers to order it Å¿o in one caÅ¿e, ceaÅ¿eth in the other, there is no reaÅ¿on of exemption; and when there is not an Identitie of reaÅ¿on in the things that are in demand, there can no Å¿ound inference be brought in from the one to the other, for of Å¿everall things, there is a Å¿everall reaÅ¿on, and a Å¿everall conÅ¿equence; neither can there bee framed thereof a good implication, either poÅ¿itively, or remotively: neither hath this interpretation of theirs any warrant of Law for it, Å¿ave that it hath beene Å¿o defined and decided: but what is that to the purpoÅ¿e, if it hath beene wreÅ¿ted and wronged contrary to the true Å¿enÅ¿e of the Statute, and that by thoÅ¿e that take benefit thereby, whoÅ¿e partiality being taken away, the thing it Å¿elfe would eaÅ¿ily turne againe to his owne nature, and right would take place?

The reaÅ¿on they yeeld for the exemption of great woods of the ages aforeÅ¿aid, although to themÅ¿elves it be plauÅ¿ible, yet to others it is Å¿trange, as namely, that great Trees are Plowd. in Soby contra Molyns. part of the Free-hold, and that men uÅ¿e not to pay Tythes of their free-hold, but of thoÅ¿e things which Å¿pring out of
their free hold, as out of Corne, GraÅ¿Å¿e, Fruit, and Å¿uch other; whereas indeed the talleÅ¿t Timber tree, that is, if it were as high as the higheÅ¿t Cedar in Lebanon, is no more part of the inheritance or free-hold, than the loweÅ¿t bramble that groweth in the field; for they are both equally part of the ground wherein they grow, and doe take alike nouriÅ¿hment and Å¿uÅ¿tenance from the Å¿ame; neither doe they differ in that they are trees the one from the other, Å¿ecundÃ¹m magis & minus, as the Logicians Å¿ay; but in that, the one is a great tree, and the other a Å¿mall Å¿hrub: and the cauÅ¿e of this proviÅ¿ion here in England for theÅ¿e great trees, was not for that one was more of the inheritance than the other, but for that the one yeeldeth more profite to the common-wealth than the other, and therefore they have made the cutting downe of the one, more penall than the other: as in like caÅ¿e by the Civile Law, whoÅ¿oever privily cutteth downe, or barketh a Vine, an Olive, or a Fig-tree, or doth ff. Arborum furtim caeÅ¿arum, toto tit. any other unlawfull act, whereby any fruitfull tree, or any Timber tree doth periÅ¿h and decay, it is Theft; and it is puniÅ¿hed in the double value of the hurt which is done, and if he be Tenant to the ground which hath done this villany, he loÅ¿eth his hold: which commeth not of that, that one kinde of Tree hath more Å¿tate in the ground than an other hath, but that the Law hath reÅ¿pected, the neceÅ¿Å¿ary uÅ¿e of the one more than the other.

By the Civile Law, although this word, Wood, be generall, L. Ligni appellatione de Leg. 3 et L. Carbonum ff. de verb. Å¿ignificat. yet it is thus diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hed, that Å¿ome is wood, Å¿ome is Timber, which the Law cals Materia. Timber is that which is fit to build or underprop withall: Wood is whatÅ¿oever is provided for fewell, Å¿o that under that name there paÅ¿Å¿eth Reed, Cole, Turfe, Cow-dung, and whatÅ¿oever is any L. Ligni appellatione Â§. Ofiliu â¢ , & Â§. idem. ff. de lega â¢ . ãâã
where ordinarily uÅ¿ed for fewell. Timber is of a higher conÅ¿ideration than wood is, inÅ¿omuch as if a man bequeath unto an other all his wood that is in grove field, there Å¿hall not paÅ¿Å¿e by this legacie, Å¿uch Trees as are cut downe for Timber: but if they were dotterd Trees, or the owner thereof purpoÅ¿ed them for fewell, and Å¿o cut them out into billet,
or fagot, in Å¿uch Å¿ort, as there could be no other uÅ¿e thereof than to burne, then it is otherwiÅ¿e: for by this meanes, of great wood, it is become Å¿mall wood, as being cut out in Å¿hides or Å¿plinters, fit for to burne. So that in the reckoning of the Civile Law, Timber Å¿tands not onely in the nature of the wood it Å¿elfe, but is in the deÅ¿tination and purpoÅ¿e of the owner, who according to his good liking may make that wood, which is fit for timber, fire-wood, or timber: which if it were Å¿o in account with the great Lawyers of this Land, the Church Å¿hould have more Tythes of Wood appointed for fewell, and leÅ¿Å¿e Å¿uite for the Å¿ame.

As they exempt the bodies of great Trees above xx. Plowd. ut Å¿upr. yeares growth, from payment of Tythes, Å¿o alÅ¿o they free the boughes thereof, upon this reaÅ¿on, that the boughes thereof are fit and Å¿erviceable for building, which although happily may be in Å¿ome of them that are next to the Trunck of the tree, yet it is farre otherwiÅ¿e in thoÅ¿e that are more remote from the Å¿ame, whereof there can bee no other uÅ¿e, than to burne: and therefore the Law preciÅ¿ely holds, in caÅ¿e where wood is bequeathed, by which is meant fire-wood onely, unleÅ¿Å¿e the TeÅ¿tator otherwiÅ¿e expreÅ¿Å¿e his minde, the lops of timber trees, which the Law cals Superamenta L. Ligni Appellat. Â§. Ofilius De Leg. & Fod. 3. materiarum are bequeathed, for that the lops have not that uÅ¿e that the Timber hath, that is, to build or prop up withall, but they Å¿erve to burne onely: By which Å¿everall ends, there is Å¿everall conÅ¿ideration and account made of them. Neither is it to the purpoÅ¿e, that they alledge for the defence hereof, that the acceÅ¿Å¿orie followeth the nature of the principall, for that rule is not true in every acceÅ¿Å¿ory, L. EtÅ¿i. C. de Praediis minorum. but onely in Å¿uch, wherein is the like reaÅ¿on as in the principall, which in the trunck and lop of a tree cannot bee alike for building.

Further, how the Boughes of a tree that are of the Å¿ame Å¿ubÅ¿tance, as the body of the tree is, Å¿hould be acceÅ¿Å¿ories to the tree, I Å¿ee not, for nothing can bee an acceÅ¿Å¿ory to an other that is of the Å¿ame nature and Å¿ubÅ¿tance as the other is; as the legge, or hand, are no acceÅ¿Å¿aries to the body, for
that the legge or hand are of the Å¿ame Å¿ubÅ¿tance that the bodie is: The Child, neither while it is in the Mothers wombe, L. 1. ff. de ventre inÅ¿piciendo. neither after it is borne, is an acceÅ¿Å¿orie to the Mother, for while it is in the Mothers wombe, it is part of the wombe, and after it is Å¿evered from her wombe, it is a man or woman like principall as her Å¿elfe is: But that which is an acceÅ¿Å¿ory to an other, muÅ¿t be of an other nature than the principall is; Å¿o in naturall living creatures, haire, hoofes, hornes, and finnes, and Å¿uch other like excrements, are acceÅ¿Å¿ories to the creature whoÅ¿e they are, for that they are of a farre different nature from the bodies, out of which they come: and Å¿o in other naturall things not living, as the Earth it Å¿elfe is, the Trees, GraÅ¿Å¿e, and fruit that Å¿pring out of the Å¿ame, are acceÅ¿Å¿ories thereto. Further, in Civile matters, expences and executions are acceÅ¿Å¿ories to the cauÅ¿es out of which they riÅ¿e: and in Marriages, Dowries, and Jointures are accounted acceÅ¿Å¿ories to them, for that without L. dotis ff. de jure dotium. Marriage, neither Joynture nor Dowrie can Å¿tand. UÅ¿urie is Å¿aid to be an acceÅ¿Å¿orie to the principall, not in reÅ¿pect that the proper Å¿ubject of either of them is Money, and Å¿o there is one Å¿ubÅ¿tance or nature of them both, but in regard of the dependencie the one hath of the other; for hee that will make challenge to UÅ¿urie, muÅ¿t firÅ¿t prove there is a principall. But for the better clearing of theÅ¿e matters of acceÅ¿Å¿orie & principall, we muÅ¿t know that in bodies whoÅ¿e Å¿ubÅ¿tance is all one, There are Å¿ome parts like, which the PhiloÅ¿ophers call partes Å¿imilares; Å¿ome other unlike, being likewiÅ¿e called of them partes diÅ¿Å¿imilares, which in no Å¿ort are acceÅ¿Å¿ories one to an other, but make one continued bodie of both, which the Law cals ã in non-Latin alphabet ã : Similar parts are Å¿uch, as have one Å¿ubÅ¿tance, forme, and figure, as the trunke or body of a tree is all one in inward eÅ¿Å¿ence, and outward Å¿hape: DiÅ¿similar parts are thoÅ¿e, which have one inward nature with the other, but are divers in outward Å¿hew, as the boughes and rootes of the Tree are divers betweene themÅ¿elves, and different from the body, and yet all agree in one Å¿ubÅ¿tance, and have all the generall name
of Wood, whereby they are diÅ¿charged from being acceÅ¿Å¿aries the one to the other, and yet they are not under one capacitie or Å¿ervice, or one comprehenÅ¿ion of Law, becauÅ¿e they are unlike one to the other; and of unlike things, there is unlike reaÅ¿on, and unlike conÅ¿equence.

Now upon theÅ¿e grounds to exempt Timber Trees wholly from the Å¿ervice of him, that is Lord aÅ¿well of the tall woods, as of the low Å¿hrubs, is very hard, for though himÅ¿elfe dwels not in houÅ¿es that are made with mans hand, nor hath any need of tall Trees to repaire his Tabernacle, or prop up his dwelling: yet Å¿ince hee hath left Å¿uch behinde him, as have charge of his flock, and feed them in word and worke untill hee come, and they dwell in earthly habitations, as other men doe, and their edifices and buildings have need of repaire, in like Å¿ort as other mortall mens houÅ¿es have, being all in like manner Å¿ubject to rottenneÅ¿Å¿e and corruption; great reaÅ¿on it had beene to have allowed him Å¿ome proportion of theÅ¿e great woods, towards his Å¿ervants neceÅ¿Å¿ary uÅ¿es, during the time of their Å¿ervice here, and if not in the very tenth it Å¿elfe, yet in the xxx. xl. or l. part of the Å¿ame, that God thereby might have beene aÅ¿well acknowledged to be the Lord of the great Oakes of the ForreÅ¿t, and that by him they have their length, breadth, and thickneÅ¿Å¿e, as he is accepted and reputed to be Lord of the Å¿mall brambles and buÅ¿hes of the field: for as now the caÅ¿e Å¿tandeth, God may either Å¿eem to have forgot himÅ¿elf, that hee hath not made timber trees tytheable, as hee hath done other Å¿maller woods, eÅ¿pecially having Å¿uch occaÅ¿ion to uÅ¿e them, both in the Chancels of Churches that are dedicated to his uÅ¿es, and alÅ¿o in the buildings and repairings of his MiniÅ¿ters houÅ¿es, who Å¿upply his roome in their Å¿everall Congregations, untill hee returne to Judgement; or that may well be objected againÅ¿t us, in allowing Å¿uch things for Tythes as us pleaÅ¿e, and diÅ¿allowing the reÅ¿t, as was by that ancient Father of the Church Tertullian, objected againÅ¿t the Senate of Rome, who being intreated by the Emperour Tiberius (for the Å¿trange wonders and miracles he heard to
be wrought by our Saviour JeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t) that he might bee entertained among the number of their Gods, refuÅ¿ed Å¿o to doe, for that they heard that our Saviour was a Jealous God, and did in no Å¿ort admit the Å¿ocietie and fellowÅ¿hip of other Gods; which this grave Father hearing, (although many yeares after) Å¿aid merrily, although wiÅ¿ely, That God Å¿hould be God, if Man would let him.
And thus far of thoÅ¿e cauÅ¿es which are held to be abÅ¿olutely of the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall cogniÅ¿ance, and yet notwithÅ¿tanding are ecclipÅ¿ed by interpoÅ¿ition of Å¿undry contrary matters.
