TheÅ¿e two kindes of proceedings the Princes and Sages of former ages Å¿eeme to have Å¿orted to the two kindes of JuriÅ¿diction that are amongÅ¿t us, the one Spirituall, the other Temporall: and therefore the Law of the Land it Å¿elfe Å¿aith, in a cauÅ¿e of Diffamation, when money is not demanded, but a thing done for puniÅ¿hment of Å¿inne, which is all one, as when the Civilians Å¿ay, when it is done ad publilicam vindictam, it Å¿hall be tryed in the Spirituall Courts: whereupon by argument of contrary Å¿enÅ¿e it followeth, that where the puniÅ¿hment of Å¿inne is not required, but amends in money is demanded, there it is to be tryed in the Temporall Court, for the Law would that â¢â¢ ery man Å¿hould have his remedie agreeable to reaÅ¿on in what Å¿ort him beÅ¿t liketh. And therefore be the fault what it may be, that the words of the Diffamation do Å¿ound unto, as long as it Å¿tands but in words, and the partie doth not take upon him to juÅ¿tifie the matter that is compriÅ¿ed under thoÅ¿e words, and doth Å¿eeke but for the puniÅ¿hment of the Å¿landerous words onely, Å¿o long it is to be tried at the Spirituall Law; for the Law Å¿peaketh in generall in caÅ¿es of Diffamation, where puniÅ¿hment of Å¿inne onely is required: Å¿o that where a man is called Traitor, Felon, or murtherer, or any other crime belonging unto the Common-Law, being every one of them words of great diffamation, Å¿o the partie therein Å¿eeke puniÅ¿hment onely, and not his private intereÅ¿t, there the Spirituall Law is to hold plea thereof. For where the Law doth not diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h, there neither ought wee to diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h: but the Law hath Å¿aid in generall, that cauÅ¿es of Diffamation, whoÅ¿e proÅ¿ecution is thus qualified, do belong unto the tryall of the Spirituall Law: and therefore even thoÅ¿e caÅ¿es before remembred where the partie followeth this kinde of proÅ¿ecutions, ought by
that Law to belong unto the Spirituall Court, as on the contrarie Å¿ide, Spirituall cauÅ¿es of Diffamation being propounded to a pecuniarie end ought to be ordered in a Temporall Court,

But where any man takes upon him to juÅ¿tifie the crime that hee hath objected, there either Court is to hold plea of the crime that properly belongeth to that Court, for that now words are no longer in queÅ¿tion, but matter is in tryall, whether the partie diffamed hath indeed committed that offence that he is charged withall or no; which can be tryed in no other Court, than in that to which it doth properly appertaine. And that this was the courÅ¿e anciently held in matters of Diffamation betweene the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall and Common Law, it is manifeÅ¿t by the Statute of 2. of Edward 2. Edw. 3. c. 11. the 3. chapter 11. where although the Statute taxeth the perverÅ¿e dealing of Å¿uch, who when they had beene indicted before the Sherifes in their Returne, and after delivered by InqueÅ¿t before the JuÅ¿tice of the AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿e, did Å¿ue the indictors in the Spirituall Court, Å¿urmiÅ¿ing againÅ¿t them that they had diffamed them, and therefore in that caÅ¿e forbad the like Å¿uits; for that juÅ¿tice thereby was hindered, and many people were feared to indict Offenders: yet that Statute plainly Å¿heweth that in all other caÅ¿es of Diffamation riÅ¿ing out of Temporall crimes beÅ¿ide this, the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law had the cogniÅ¿ance: and that this was forbidden, it was not for that words of this nature, could not be cenÅ¿ured at the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law, when puniÅ¿hment of Å¿in onely is required, but for that it was not fit that thoÅ¿e things, which had beene once ordered in one Court, Å¿hould be called againe to examination in another: and therefore the generall proceeding in matters of Diffamation, is not there prohibited, but the particular croÅ¿Å¿ing of matters after judgement is there reprehended.

So that the diÅ¿tinction whereof I formerly Å¿pake, which taketh upon it to determine when a caÅ¿e of Diffamation is of the Temporall cogniÅ¿ance, and when of the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall, cannot here take place: for that it is contrary to
the former Statute or Decree that divided theÅ¿e caÅ¿es into Temporall or EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall cogniÅ¿ance by the varietie of the proÅ¿ecution thereof, and that it is contrarie to the ancient practiÅ¿e that hath confirmed this proÅ¿ecution in either Court, but eÅ¿pecially in the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Court, which hath Å¿till holden the triall of Å¿uch Diffamations wherein Å¿in hath bin only Å¿ought to be puniÅ¿hed, untill now of late, that men have Å¿tept over the bankes, of theirauthoritie and confounded either JuriÅ¿diction with the promiÅ¿cuous acts one of another; when as the Statute it Å¿elfe is plaine, that the Authors of this Statute or Decree, whetherÅ¿oever you call it, which Å¿et theÅ¿e bounds to either Law, in proceeding upon matters of Diffamation, reÅ¿pected not Å¿o much the qualitie of the crime, upon which the Diffamation grew, as the manner of proceeding therein, ayming in the one at publique vendict, which is to be Å¿ought out of the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law, and in the other at private intereÅ¿t, which is to be had out of the Temporall Law.

Neither is an Action of Diffamation, a matter of Å¿o light eÅ¿teeme or qualitie, (a mans fame or good name being in equall ballance with his life) as that it Å¿hould be drawne away to be attendant on any other action that is of Å¿maller weight or importance than it Å¿elfe is: for this is one of thoÅ¿e Actions which for the Å¿peciall preheminence thereof, are called Actiones praejudiciales, that is, Å¿uch that draw Å¿maller cauÅ¿es unto them, but themÅ¿elves are drawne of none other, but Å¿uch as are like principall, or greater than themÅ¿elves are. So that unleÅ¿Å¿e the manner of proceeding bring theÅ¿e cauÅ¿es under the compaÅ¿Å¿e of the Common Law, in Å¿uch Å¿ort as I have before Å¿hewed, the coupling of them with another matter of the Å¿ame Law, will hardly bring them under the triall thereof: for that there be few actions greater then it Å¿elfe is, Å¿o that if the crime be EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall, howÅ¿oever it toucheth a Temporall cauÅ¿e, the tryall Å¿hall be Å¿till at the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law. And the Å¿ame that I Å¿ay of Diffamations riÅ¿ing out of EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall crimes, I hold alÅ¿o to be true in Diffamations Å¿pringing out of
Temporall crimes, where puniÅ¿hment is required for the offence committed, and amends in money is not demaunded, unleÅ¿Å¿e happily that grow of penance injoyned, which the offender will redeeme by giving money to the Judge, or to the partie grieved. And this I take to be a farre better limitation for either Law, having the ground of the Civile Law, and a Statute of the Common Law, and common reaÅ¿on it Å¿elfe for it, than the other diviÅ¿e is, which Å¿o diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿heth this buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e, as Å¿till it makes it reÅ¿t in the mouth of the Judge, which cauÅ¿e of Diffamation is meere Å¿pirituall, and which not, which were not to be done if there were cleare dealing in the matter: for Lawes are Å¿o to be made, as that as little as may be, be left to the diÅ¿cretion of the Judge, but all be expreÅ¿Å¿ed as farre as the nature of the cauÅ¿e vvill give leave: vvhich albeit it be hard to doe, for the varietie of the caÅ¿es that every day happen, never thought on before, yet that is to be laboured Å¿o farre as may be; for this libertie of leaving many things to the Judges diÅ¿cretion, is many times great occaÅ¿ion of confuÅ¿ion in Judicature, Å¿aying Å¿ometimes this, and Å¿ometimes that, as his private humor Å¿hall lead him: and therefore a plaine diÅ¿tinction betweene both the Lawes vvere beÅ¿t, that every man may Å¿ee, and Å¿ay vvhat is proper to either of them.

div.head: SECT. 2.

argument.p: That the Å¿uit of BaÅ¿tardie, as well in the principall as in the incident belongs unto the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law.

div.p: ANd thus farre as concerning matters of Diffamation. Now followeth that I Å¿peake of matters of BaÅ¿tardie.
BaÅ¿tardie is an unlawfull Å¿tate of birth, diÅ¿abled by divine and humane Lawes to Å¿ucceed in inheritance.
Of BaÅ¿tards, Å¿ome are begot and borne of Å¿ingle women, (in which ranke alÅ¿o I put widowes) Å¿ome other of married women.

Of Å¿ingle women, Å¿ome are Å¿uch as a man may make his wife, if himÅ¿elfe be Å¿ole, and unmarried, as thoÅ¿e that are kept as Concubines in place of a mans wife; Å¿ome other are Å¿uch as a man cannot make his wife, although himÅ¿elfe be Å¿ole and unmarried, for that either they are already precontracted to Å¿ome other, or that they be in Å¿o neere a degree of affinitie or conÅ¿anguinitie one to the other, that the marriage would be damnable, & the iÅ¿Å¿ue thereof unlawfull.

Of Å¿uch as are begotten of Å¿ingle women, by Å¿ingle men, who are in caÅ¿e to marrie them if they will, Å¿ome are called by the Civile Law Filii Naturales, becauÅ¿e they were begot by Å¿uch as they held for their wives, and yet were not their wives, who might be legitimate by Å¿undry waies, as hereaÅ¿ter Å¿hall be Å¿hewed.

Some other begot of Å¿ingle women, if they were begot in vage luÅ¿t, without any purpoÅ¿e to hold Å¿uch a one for a Concubine, but upon a deÅ¿ire only to Å¿atisfie a mans preÅ¿ent luÅ¿t, whether they were begotten by married men or Å¿ingle men, were called Spurii, vvho for the moÅ¿t part are putative children, and their father is not otherwiÅ¿e knowne then by the mothers confeÅ¿Å¿ion, vvhich Å¿ometimes Å¿aith true, Å¿ometimes otherwiÅ¿e. IÅ¿idore Å¿aith, they vvere Å¿o called becauÅ¿e they were borne out of puritie, for that Å¿uch kinde of luÅ¿t is contrary to holy Matrimonie, whoÅ¿e bed is undefiled, and therefore the other is corrupt, and abominable.

But where any was borne of a woman Å¿ingle or married, that proÅ¿tituted her Å¿elfe to every mans pleaÅ¿ure, and made publike profeÅ¿Å¿ion of her Å¿elf to be an harlot, (Å¿uch as they are whom the Law calleth Scorta) theÅ¿e were called Manzeres.

ThoÅ¿e which were begotten of married women were called Nothi, becauÅ¿e they Å¿eemed to be his children whom the marriage doth Å¿hew, but are not, no otherwiÅ¿e than Å¿ome feavers are called Nothi, that is, baÅ¿tard feavers, becauÅ¿e they imitate the tertian or quartan Feaver in heat, and other accidents, but yet are neither tertians nor quartans, as the
learned PhiÅ¿icians well know: but theÅ¿e are counted Å¿o to bee baÅ¿tards, if either the husband were Å¿o long abÅ¿ent from his wife, as by no poÅ¿Å¿ibility of Nature the childe could bee his; or that the Adulterer and AdultereÅ¿Å¿e were Å¿o knowne to keepe company together, as that by juÅ¿t account of time, it could not fall out to be any other mans childe but the Adulterers himÅ¿elfe: and yet in theÅ¿e very caÅ¿es within this Realme, unleÅ¿Å¿e the huÅ¿band be all the time of the impoÅ¿sibility beyond the Seas, the Rule of the Law holds true, Pater is eÅ¿t quem nuptiae demonÅ¿trant.

The moÅ¿t nefarious and laÅ¿t kinde of BaÅ¿tards are they whom the Law calleth InceÅ¿tuoÅ¿i, which are begot between AÅ¿cendents & DeÅ¿cendents in infinitum, and betweene Collaterals, Å¿o farre as the Divine Prohibition and the right interpretation thereof doth Å¿tretch it Å¿elfe.
The effects of theÅ¿e Å¿orts of BaÅ¿tardies are divers.

FirÅ¿t, it Å¿taineth the bloud, for that hee that is a BaÅ¿tard can neither challenge Honour nor Armes from the Father or Mother, for that he was begot and borne out of Matrimony, which is the firÅ¿t Å¿tep to Honour: and therefore the ApoÅ¿tle calleth Marriage honourable, whereupon it muÅ¿t H ãâ¦ã 13. 4âª follow, that the oppoÅ¿ite thereof is Å¿hame; for, albeit it bee no Å¿inne for a BaÅ¿tard to be a BaÅ¿tard, yet is it a defect in him to be Å¿uch a one, and a thing eaÅ¿ily Å¿ubject to reproach.

Secondly, it repelleth him that is a BaÅ¿tard, from all Å¿ucceÅ¿sion, deÅ¿cending from the Father or the Mother, whether it be in Goods or Lands, unleÅ¿Å¿e there bee Å¿ome other collaterall proviÅ¿ion made for the Å¿ame: for that all Å¿uch Lawes and Statutes as are made to any of theÅ¿e purpoÅ¿es, were intended to the benefit of Å¿uch as are legitimate, and are next of kin by lawfull Å¿ucceÅ¿sion, and not by unlawfull conjunction.

To legitimate him that was a BaÅ¿tard, when there could no claime be made unto his birth-right but by grace, among the Romans were Å¿undry wayes; firÅ¿t where the Father of the BaÅ¿tard (they being both Å¿ingle perÅ¿ons) married the woman, by whom he begot the child; Å¿econdly, where the father
did by his laÅ¿t Will and TeÅ¿tament, or by Å¿ome publick inÅ¿trument Å¿ubÅ¿cribed by witneÅ¿Å¿e, name him to be his naturall and lawfull Å¿onne, or Å¿imply his Å¿onne, without the addition of any of theÅ¿e two words, baÅ¿e, or naturall, and therewithall did make him his heire, which could not be, but in Å¿uch caÅ¿es onely, where the father had no other naturall and lawfull childe left alive.

Thirdly, whereas the Prince by his ReÅ¿cript, or the Senate by their Decree, did doe any one that credit, as to grant them the favour of legitimation, which was done, for the moÅ¿t part, in Å¿uch caÅ¿es onely, where either the father of the childe, or the childe himÅ¿elfe, offered himÅ¿elfe to be attendant on the Court or Prince.

In this Realme, none of the foreÅ¿aid legitimations take place, as farre as I can learne, but onely that which is done by Parliament, and that very rarely; for beÅ¿ides thoÅ¿e that King Henry the eigth did in the variety and mutability of 28. 8. cap. 7. his minde, towards his owne iÅ¿Å¿ue, I thinke there cannot be many examples Å¿hewed: for, as for that which is wrought 1. Mar. 1. parliament. cap. 1 by Å¿ubÅ¿equent Marriage, being a thing anciently preÅ¿Å¿ed by the Clergie of this Land, to be admitted in like Å¿ort, as it is uÅ¿ed in other Lands, where the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law taketh place; it was rejected by the Earles and Barons with one voyce, and anÅ¿wer was made, that they would not change the Lawes of the Realme in that point, which to that time had beene uÅ¿ed and approved. All theÅ¿e caÅ¿es of BaÅ¿tardie in other Lands, whether they be Å¿uch, or not Å¿uch, are triable by the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law: But here with us it is queÅ¿tionable, to what Law, and how farre they doe appertaine, whether to the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall or Temporall.

For the matter of BaÅ¿tardie, what it is, the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law, and the Temporall differ not; but there is a diverÅ¿itie betweene them in the proÅ¿ecution thereof, for the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law bringeth it two wayes in Judgement; the one incidently, the other principally; but the Common Law maketh two Å¿orts thereof, the one generall, the other Å¿peciall: But firÅ¿t of the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall diviÅ¿ion, then of the Temporall.
BaÅ¿tardie is then Å¿aid to be incidently propounded, when it is laid in barre of Å¿ome other thing, that is principally commenced; as when one Å¿ueth for an inheritance that he pretendeth is due unto him by his nativitie, an other croÅ¿Å¿eth him therein, by objecting againÅ¿t him baÅ¿tardie, with purpoÅ¿e to exclude him from his action in the inheritance: here the barre is in the incident, becauÅ¿e it comes excluÅ¿ively to the action of inheritance, but the action for the inheritance it Å¿elfe was in the principall, for that it was begun in conÅ¿ideration of the inheritance, and not with intent to prove himÅ¿elfe legitimate; which happily hee never dreamed of, when he firÅ¿t entered his action for the inheritance. In which caÅ¿e, he which is charged with the baÅ¿tardie, may require himÅ¿elfe to be admitted to prove himÅ¿elfe legitimate, before the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Judge, and to bee pronounced to be Å¿uch a one. Ad Curiam enim Regiamnon pertinet Glanvill lib. 7. cap. 13. agnoÅ¿cere de BaÅ¿tardia: AgainÅ¿t which the Law of the Land doth not oppoÅ¿e it Å¿elfe, but acknowledge it to bee the right of the Church. And yet to avoid all Å¿ubtill and 9 Hen. 6. ca. 11. Å¿urreptitious dealing in this behalfe, it hath Å¿et downe a warie and cautelous forme of proceeding, by which the Å¿ame Å¿hall be brought unto the Ordinarie, and Å¿uch as have intereÅ¿t in the Å¿uit, may have notice thereof, and time to object in forme of Law againÅ¿t the proofes and witneÅ¿Å¿es of him that pretends himÅ¿elfe to be Mulier, if they Å¿o thinke good: and what Å¿hall be certified herein by the Ordinarie, as concerning the nativity of him that is burthened to be a BaÅ¿tard, (that is, whether hee were borne before or after Glanvill lib. 7. cap. 15. his Parents marriage) Å¿hall be Å¿upplied in the Kings Court, either by judging for, or againÅ¿t the Inheritance.

But BaÅ¿tardie is then taken to bee principally propounded, when either one finding himÅ¿elfe to be greeved with Å¿ome malicious Å¿peech of his adverÅ¿arie, reproaching him with BaÅ¿tardie, or himÅ¿elfe fearing to be impeached in his good name, or right, doth take a courÅ¿e to cleere his nativitie, by calling into the Law, him or them by whom hee is reproached, or feareth to bee impeached in his right and
credit, to Å¿ee him, to prove himÅ¿elfe legitimate, and to alledge & object againÅ¿t it, if they ought have, or can have to the contrary: which if either they doe not, or doing to the utmoÅ¿t what they can, can bring no good matter againÅ¿t his proofe, but that it Å¿tands Å¿till good and effectuall in Law, to all intents and purpoÅ¿es whatÅ¿oever (although perhaps hereby hee Å¿hall not be able to carry the inheritance, both for that it appertaineth not to the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law, to judge of Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments; and alÅ¿o for that there is a preciÅ¿e forme Å¿et downe by Statute, how Å¿uits of this nature Å¿hall be recovered) yet if no oppoÅ¿ite or contradicter appeare herein, and the Å¿uit was onely taken in hand againÅ¿t Å¿uch, as either openly reproached him, or Å¿ecretly buzzed abroad Å¿landerous Å¿peeches, as concerning his legitimation: it is not to be doubted, but by an accident alÅ¿o it will be good for the inheritance it Å¿elfe, for where a mans legitimation is Å¿ufficiently proved, thereon followeth all things which naturally thereto belong. But if any man 9. Hen. 6. c. 11. urge the forme of the Statute, being intereÅ¿Å¿ed therein, then muÅ¿t it neceÅ¿Å¿arily be followed, for that otherwiÅ¿e it would be thought, all that was done before, Å¿o farre as it may concerne the inheritance, although it were but in a conÅ¿equence, were done by colluÅ¿ion. This kinde of proceeding hath been much more in uÅ¿e in former times than it is now, and never any oppoÅ¿ition made againÅ¿t it: but now it goeth not altogether cleere without contradiction, as many other things are offenÅ¿ively taken, which notwithÅ¿tanding have good ground, and Å¿ufficient warrant for them.
And Å¿o farre as concerning the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall proceedings in this buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e: Now to the Temporall Å¿orts of them.

Generall BaÅ¿tardie is Å¿o called, becauÅ¿e it comes in incidently, and is in groÅ¿Å¿e objected againÅ¿t Å¿ome that Å¿ue in a matter principall, to diÅ¿appoint his Å¿uit. This Å¿uit, becauÅ¿e it is of the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall cogniÅ¿ance, it is Å¿ent by the Kings writ to the Ordinarie, with certaine additions for more perÅ¿picuity of the inquirie thereof; as that whether he that is charged with the BaÅ¿tardie, were borne in lawfull Matrimonie,

Inqutratis utrum praedictus A. pars rea, genitus vel natus Lib. Intrac. fol. 35. fuit anto Matrimonium contractum inter talem Patrem Å¿uum, & talem Matrom Å¿uam: vel poÅ¿t. So that either they Glanvill lib. 7. cap. 15. muÅ¿t confeÅ¿Å¿e there is no Å¿uch baÅ¿tardie, as they make Å¿hew there is, diverÅ¿e from that that is tried before the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Judge, or that themÅ¿elves doe confound the members that Å¿hould divide the Å¿ame, and make them one, or the other, as them liÅ¿t; for both Å¿imply they cannot be, unleÅ¿Å¿e they be diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hed with other notes and differences, than hitherto I finde they are. But to Å¿ay the truth, if theÅ¿e things be well weighed and conÅ¿idered, Å¿peciall BaÅ¿tardie is nothing elÅ¿e, but the definition of the generall, and the generall againe is nothing but the definite of the Å¿peciall: for whoÅ¿oever is born out of, or before lawfull Matrimonie, hee is a BaÅ¿tard, and he againe is a BaÅ¿tard that is borne before, or out of lawfull Matrimony, Å¿o that theÅ¿e things to bee a BaÅ¿tard, and to bee borne out of lawfull Matrimony are convertible one with the other: Å¿o then as it were very hard to make a divorce betweene theÅ¿e things that are Å¿o â¢ eere in nature one to the other, being convertibl â¢ termes one to the other; Å¿o hard againe it were in policie to disjoyne theÅ¿e things in triall, that are Å¿o neere in affinitie one to the other, becauÅ¿e they are the Å¿ame in Å¿ubÅ¿tance and nature as the other are, and therefore Eodem jure conÅ¿eri debent; And alÅ¿o ne continentiae cauÅ¿arum dividantur,

And Å¿o farre hitherto as concerning the reaÅ¿ons and arguments, that may be brought againÅ¿t this Å¿peciall BaÅ¿tardie. Now it reÅ¿teth that I Å¿hew by ancient precedents, that both theÅ¿e Å¿orts of BaÅ¿tardy have appertained to the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall
Courts onely, and the firÅ¿t precedent is in the incident the other in the principall: and the precedent is no leÅ¿Å¿e ancient than Henry the Å¿econds time, as that which happened under Alexander the third, about the yeare of our Lord 1160. and the caÅ¿e is this.

A certaine man of Norwich DioceÅ¿Å¿e called R. H. had iÅ¿Å¿ue I. H. who had a Son called C. H. I. H. deceaÅ¿ing before R. H. Cap. L â¢â¦ or. ext. qui filii Å¿unt legitimi, his Father, C. H. Å¿ucceeded in his Grandfathers Inheritance, his Å¿aid Grandfather being dead; but M. H. Brother to the Å¿aid Grandfather, pretending that the Å¿aid I. H. was a BaÅ¿tard, draweth the Å¿aid C. H. into the Temporall Court upon the Inheritance; whereupon C. H. called the Å¿aid M. H. into the BiÅ¿hop of Norwich his Court, for the triall of his nativity; but the BiÅ¿hop long protracting the cauÅ¿e, C. H. appealed to the Pope, who delegated the Å¿ame cauÅ¿e to the BiÅ¿hop of ExceÅ¿ter, and the Abbot of Hereford, with order, That if the Å¿aid M. H. Å¿hould not within two Moneths, prove that which hee objected againÅ¿t C. H. that then they Å¿hould intimate the Å¿ame to the Å¿ecular Judge, before whom the inheritance was in queÅ¿tion, that he Å¿hould not Å¿tay any longer upon the queÅ¿tion of legitimation, but proceed to Judgement in the cauÅ¿e of the inheritance. div.head: SECT. 1.

argument.p: The meanes how to relieve the Civill Law: that they are of two Å¿orts: that two things are required to the firÅ¿t meane, and that the former of theÅ¿e is the right interpretation of Lawes, and what that is.

div.p: THe meanes therefore to relieve the profeÅ¿sion of the Civile Law are two. The firÅ¿t is, by the reÅ¿toring of thoÅ¿e things which have beene powerfully by the Common-Law taken from them, and the bringing of them backe againe unto their old and wonted courÅ¿e: The other is by allowing them the practiÅ¿e of Å¿uch things as are grievances in the Common-wealth, and fit to be reformed by Å¿ome Court, but yet are by no home-Law provided for.

The firÅ¿t of theÅ¿e Å¿tands in two things, whereof the one is the right interpretation of the Lawes, Statutes and cuÅ¿tomes which are written, and deviÅ¿ed in the behalfe of the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law. The other conÅ¿iÅ¿teth in the correcting and Å¿upplying of Å¿uch Lawes and Statutes that are either Å¿uperfluous or defective in the penning, made in the behalfe (as it is pretended) of the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall profeÅ¿Å¿ion, but yet by reaÅ¿on of the unperfect pe ãâ¦ã g thereof, are conÅ¿trued for the moÅ¿t part, againÅ¿t them.

The right interpretation of the Law, Statutes, and CuÅ¿tomes pertaining to the practiÅ¿e, Å¿tandeth as is pretended in the Judges mouth, who notwithÅ¿tanding hath that authoritie from the Soveraigne, and that not to judge according as him beÅ¿t liketh, but according as the right of the cauÅ¿e doth require.
The Å¿upply or reforming of that which is over-plus, or defective, is in the Parliament, Å¿o notwithÅ¿tanding as that the Prince evermore breatheth life into that which is done.

Lawes, Statutes or CuÅ¿tomes, are then beÅ¿t interpreted when as the very plaine and naturall Å¿enÅ¿e of them is Å¿ought after, and no forraine or Å¿trained expoÅ¿ition is mixt with them; for that turneth juÅ¿tice into worme-wood, and judgement into gall: then that the Judge be not too Å¿ubtill in his interpretation, but follow Å¿uch expoÅ¿ition of the Lawes, as men of former age have uÅ¿ed to make, if they be not plainly abÅ¿urd, and erronious, for oft Å¿hifting of interpretations breedeth great variance in mens Å¿tates, among Å¿uch as have buÅ¿ie heads, and much diÅ¿crediteth the Law it Å¿elfe as though there were no certaintie in it: with which although the fage Judges of our time cannot be charged, for ought that I know, yet (I cannot tell how) men much complaine that Lawes are farre otherwiÅ¿e conÅ¿trued in theÅ¿e daies, than they were in former ages: which as it is an ordinarie complaint in the Temporall Courts, Å¿o it is not without cauÅ¿e, much lamented at the Spirituall Court, where the interpretation upon the three Statutes of Tythes made by King Henry the eight, and Edward his Å¿onne, among other inconÅ¿tancies of other Lawes, hath Å¿uch great varietie of Å¿enÅ¿e and underÅ¿tanding in Å¿undrie points thereof, as that if the makers thereof were now alive, and the firÅ¿t expoÅ¿itors thereof Å¿ate in place of Judgement againe (the Statutes being meaÅ¿ured by the interpretation they now make of them) vvould hardly acknowledge them either to be the Statutes that they then made, or the other did after expound, and declare: for every of theÅ¿e Statutes and the Å¿enÅ¿e that was given of them, vvas wholy for the benefit of the Church, according to the tenor thereof, but as they now receive explication,, they are not onely not beneficiall unto the Church, but the greateÅ¿t hinderance to the Å¿ame that may be; for the words are made to jarre with the Å¿enÅ¿e, and the Å¿enÅ¿e vvith the vvords, neither is there kept any right analogie in them: and therefore the Reverend
Judges are to be intreated (becauÅ¿e they challenge unto themÅ¿elves the opening of the Statutes alone, albeit peradventure that be yet Å¿ubjudice, where the Statute of EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall cauÅ¿es is to be interpreted) that they would recall Å¿uch exorbitant interpretations, as have of late gone abroad upon theÅ¿e Statutes, and reÅ¿tore them to their ancient Å¿enÅ¿e, and underÅ¿tanding. No man can Å¿o cunningly cloake an interpretation, but another will be as cunning as hee to Å¿pie it out, and then the diÅ¿credit will be the Lawes. Lib. 1. Polit â¢â¢ . A Å¿mall errour (Å¿aith AriÅ¿totle) in the beginning, is a great one in the end, and hee that goeth out of the way a little, the longer he goeth on, the further he is off from the place his voyage was to: and therefore the Å¿peedier returne into the way againe is beÅ¿t. The old Proverbe is: He that goeth plainly goeth Å¿urely, which may be beÅ¿t verified in the expoÅ¿ition of the Law, if any where elÅ¿e; for commonly men offend no where more dangerouÅ¿ly than under the authoritie of the Law, and therefore one Å¿aith very well, that There are two Å¿alts required in a Judge, the one of knowledge, whereby hee may have skill to Judge uprightly; the other of conÅ¿cience, whereby hee may be willing to judge according to that as his skill leadeth him unto: both which being in the grave Judges, it is not to be doubted, but they will be eaÅ¿ily induced to review their owne, and their predeceÅ¿Å¿ours interpretations, and reduce Å¿uch exorbitant expoÅ¿itions as have Å¿caped out thereof unto the right and naturall Å¿enÅ¿e thereof: which if perhaps they Å¿hall be loath to do, for becauÅ¿e it makes for them, or for Å¿ome other like partiall reÅ¿pect, then humble Å¿upplication is to be made unto his MajeÅ¿tie, that hee himÅ¿elfe will be pleaÅ¿ed to give the right Å¿enÅ¿e of thoÅ¿e things which are in controverÅ¿ie betweene both the JuriÅ¿dictions: for his MajeÅ¿tie by communicating his authoritie to his Judge to expound his Lawes, doth not thereby abdicate the Å¿ame from himÅ¿elfe, but that hee may aÅ¿Å¿ume it againe unto him, when and as often as hee pleaÅ¿eth. WhoÅ¿e interpretation in that is to be preferred before theirs, firÅ¿t for that his interpretation is impartiall
as hee that will not weaken his left Å¿ide to make Å¿trong his right (for Å¿o are theÅ¿e juriÅ¿dictions as they are referred unto his politique bodie) but will afford them equall grace, L. 1. num. 8. C. de legibus. L. 1. num. 7. C. cod â¢ . omnes populi ff. de juÅ¿tit. & jure. and favour, that hee may have like uÅ¿e of them both, either in forraigne or domeÅ¿ticall buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e, as occaÅ¿ion Å¿hall Å¿erve: then that his Judges interpretation maketh right onely to them betweene whom the cauÅ¿e is, but his highneÅ¿Å¿e expoÅ¿ition is a Law unto all, from which it is not lawfull for any Å¿ubject to recede, neither is it reverÅ¿eable by any, but by himÅ¿elfe, upon a Å¿econd cogitation; or him that hath like authoritie as himÅ¿elfe hath: and therefore moÅ¿t fit to be interpoÅ¿ed betweene JuriÅ¿diction and JuriÅ¿diction, that the one partie be not Judge againÅ¿t the other in his owne cauÅ¿e, which is both abÅ¿urd and dangerous.
And let this Å¿uffice for the right interpretation of Lawes and Statutes: Now it followeth that I Å¿peake Å¿omething of the Å¿upplies that may be made to the defects that are in the Å¿ame.

div.head: SECT. 2.

argument.p: The Å¿econd thing required to the firÅ¿t correcting of Å¿uperÅ¿tition, and Å¿upplying of defective Statutes.

div.p:
IT is not to be doubted, but it was the full minde and intent of the Lawmakers, which made thoÅ¿e three Statutes to infeoffe the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Courts in the inheritance of all thoÅ¿e cauÅ¿es that are compriÅ¿ed in thoÅ¿e Statutes, Å¿ave thoÅ¿e that are by Å¿peciall name exempted, and that they did by the Å¿aid Statute, as it were deliver unto them full and quiet poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of the Å¿ame, for even Å¿o Å¿undrie branches of the Å¿aid Statute do Å¿hew, as I have elÅ¿ewhere made it manifeÅ¿t: and that there hath growne queÅ¿tion upon many points thereof, and that the profeÅ¿Å¿ours of the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law have beene interupted in the quiet poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion thereof, commeth of the unperfect penning of the Å¿ame, and not of any juÅ¿t title or claime that may be made by the profeÅ¿Å¿ours of the other Law thereunto: but this is a thing
not onely proper to theÅ¿e three Statutes, but alÅ¿o common to all other Statutes which are writ of any EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall cauÅ¿es within this Land; which notwithÅ¿tanding may be remedied, if it Å¿eeme good unto his Å¿acred MajeÅ¿tie and the reÅ¿t of the wiÅ¿edome of the land aÅ¿Å¿embled together at any time for the making of wholÅ¿ome Lawes, and the reforming of the Å¿ame, by Å¿upply of a few words in Å¿ome places, or periods that are defective, and yet keeping the true meaning and Å¿enÅ¿e of the Å¿ame.

As for example in the Statute of the two and thirtieth of Henry the eight, in the Â§ wherefore, neere the beginning of the Å¿ame Statute, the Statute ordering, that all perÅ¿ons of this Realme, and other of the Kings Dominions Å¿hall truly, and effectually Å¿et out, and pay all and Å¿ingular Tythes, according to the lawfull cuÅ¿tomes, and uÅ¿ages of the PariÅ¿hes where they grow, and become due: becauÅ¿e there is a queÅ¿tion made where theÅ¿e cuÅ¿tomes and uÅ¿ages Å¿hall be tryed, in the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall or Temporall Law; if theÅ¿e or the like words had beene added to the Å¿ame (to be proved before an EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Judge after the forme of the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law, and not elÅ¿ewhere) the whole matter had beene cleare for that point.

And whereas againe in the end of the Å¿ame Statute, there be Å¿ome good words tending to the appropriating of theÅ¿e matters of Tythes, and obligations, and other EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall duties to the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Court: and that the remedie for them Å¿hall be had in the Spirituall Court according to the ordinance of the firÅ¿t part of that Act, and not otherwiÅ¿e: yet becauÅ¿e there is no penaltie to that act, buÅ¿ie men eaÅ¿ilie make a breach thereinto, for that Lawes without penalties, for the moÅ¿t part are weake & of no force: if therefore this or the like Å¿upply were made (if any man Å¿ue for theÅ¿e, or like duties in any other Court, than in the Kings EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall court, the parties Å¿o Å¿uing, to forfeit the treble value of that which he Å¿ued for, to be recovered in the Kings EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Court, where it ought to have bin commenced, by the way of Libells, or Articles, the one halfe thereof Å¿hall
be to the King, the other to the partie grieved) many of theÅ¿e Å¿uits would eaÅ¿ily be met withall. Neither is it to the purpoÅ¿e that this is matter of mony, and Lay-Fee that Å¿hould be in this Å¿ort forfeited, and therefore is not Regularly to be Å¿ued for in the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Court; for Å¿eeing the cauÅ¿e is EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall, upon which the matter of forfeiture ariÅ¿eth, it may be very well allowed, Ne continentiae cauÅ¿arum dividantur: and for that ordinarily every juriÅ¿diction that is wronged may defend it Å¿elfe with a penaltie: beÅ¿ide, we do by the like right in the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall courts recover expenÅ¿es of Å¿uits in Law, fees of Advocates, & Proctors, & mony for redemption of Å¿in, Å¿o that it will be no Å¿trange matter to have this kinde of Å¿uit allowed unto the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Court.

Further, whereas there are in the Statute of Edward the Å¿ixt, chapter 13. in the beginning almoÅ¿t of the Å¿aid Statute two clauÅ¿es under paine of forfeiture, one of treble value, for Tythes carried away before they were divided, Å¿et out, or agreed for: The other of double value where the Tythes were hurt or impared by the partie Å¿topping or letting him that had intereÅ¿t thereunto to carrie them away, or by withdrawing, or carrying them away himÅ¿elfe; & the Å¿ame is ordered by a clauÅ¿e in the Å¿econd branch thereof reaching unto them both (for that a clauÅ¿e put in the end of two Å¿entences, Å¿tretcheth it Å¿elfe indifferently unto them both, if there be no more reaÅ¿on it Å¿hould belong to the one than the other, as there is not in this caÅ¿e, for if it were not Å¿o, the firÅ¿t penalty had no order Å¿et down, how it might be recovered) that the Å¿ame Å¿hall be recovered according to the Kings EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law: to which if there were added this word [only] and not elÅ¿ewhere, or otherwiÅ¿e, and they martialled in their right places, there were nothing more Å¿ure or Å¿trong.

Moreover, whereas in the firÅ¿t proviÅ¿o of that Statute it is decreed, that none Å¿hall be compelled to pay any manner of Tythes for any Hereditaments, which by the Lawes or Statutes of the Realme, or by any Priviledge, PreÅ¿cription, or CompoÅ¿ition Reall, are not chargeable therewithall; whereby it is doubtfull in what Court the Å¿aid Exemptions
are to be alledged: if there were inÅ¿erted theÅ¿e words, or other of like nature [the Å¿aid Lawes, Statutes, Priviledges, PreÅ¿criptions, or CompoÅ¿itions reall to be alledged, argued, traverÅ¿ed, and determined before the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Judge onely according to the forme of the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Lawes, and not elÅ¿e-where] upon like forfeiture of treble dammages, as is aforeÅ¿aid, it would make this poynt Å¿ure unto the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law.

Over and beÅ¿ides this, whereas in the Å¿ame Statute there is a diÅ¿charge allowed to barren, heath, and waÅ¿te ground, in Å¿ome for not payment of tythes, in other for the manner of payment of them for the Å¿pace of 7. yeares, after the improving and converting of them into arrable ground or meadow; it would make the matter plaine, which Law Å¿hould have the pronouncing thereupon, if there were added theÅ¿e or the like words [So the Å¿ame ground be proved in forme of Law in the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Court, to be barren, heath, and waÅ¿te.]

LaÅ¿tly, whereas in the Å¿aid Statute among other limitations of cauÅ¿es, wherein the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Judge is not to deale by vertue of the Å¿aid Statute, there is one in theÅ¿e words, neere the end of the Å¿aid Statute [Ne in any matter whereof the Kings Court of right ought to have JuriÅ¿diction] which limitation is Å¿o vage & large, that thereout there may be forged as many divers kindes of Prohibitions, as the Poets Å¿ained Vulcan ever made thunderbolts for Jupiter. And therefore it were very well and conÅ¿onant to the good meaning of the Å¿aid Statute, that this vageneÅ¿Å¿e were reÅ¿trained and reduced to a more certainty of matter, by theÅ¿e or like words, [By any ancient Law or Statute of this Land.]

And Å¿o farre as concerning the imperfection of the Å¿aid three Statutes, and how they may be amended and made reducible to the firÅ¿t meaning and intent of the makers thereof, by Å¿ome Å¿mall Å¿upply, alteration, or change of words, the Å¿enÅ¿e and ground-worke Å¿tanding ever the Å¿ame, according to the wiÅ¿dome of his MajeÅ¿tic, and his great Councell aÅ¿Å¿embled in Parliament.

div.head: SECT. 1.

argument.p: The Å¿econd Meane to releeve the Civile Law, which is, by allowing it the practice of Å¿uch things as are greevances in the Common-wealth, and fit to be reformed by Å¿ome Court, but yet are not otherwiÅ¿e provided for: And firÅ¿t of the greevances which concerne Parents and Children, and how they may be releeved.

div.p:
NOw it followeth, that I Å¿hew wherein the practice of the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law (under which I compriÅ¿e the Civile Law, Å¿o farre as it is in uÅ¿e amongÅ¿tus) may bee increaÅ¿ed to the benefite of the Å¿ubject, and the enlargement of the profeÅ¿sion, without the prejudice of the Common Law. And that I may firÅ¿t begin with the piety of Fathers towards their Children, & children againe towards their Parents, which is the beginning of all Common-wealths; for even Nature it Å¿elfe hath taught that, not onely in the moÅ¿t brutiÅ¿h people that bee, but alÅ¿o Å¿etled it in the Å¿avageÅ¿t kinde of beaÅ¿ts that are upon the earth, the one to cheriÅ¿h that which it Å¿elfe hath brought out, and the other to love againe that which hath brought it out: and yet, what Law is here in England, which provideth for the one or the other, unleÅ¿Å¿e it be the Statute of the xliij. of Elizabeth? and that is but for poore folkes children onely (where otherwiÅ¿e they Å¿hould be a burthen to the PariÅ¿h) but for the Parents themÅ¿elves, or other children that are caÅ¿t off, either by the negligence, or the unnaturalneÅ¿Å¿e of the one toward the other, there is no proviÅ¿ion at all. Yet by the Civile Law there is a purveiance made, whereby both the Father ff. dc agnoÅ¿cend. et alendis liberis vel parenti â¢ . c. de alendis liberis vel parentib. is compelled to acknowledge his childe, (if there bee any variance betweene the huÅ¿band and the wife upon any jealouÅ¿ie or Å¿uÅ¿picion of Adulterie, if the Å¿ame cannot bee proved by the womans owne confeÅ¿Å¿ion, by witneÅ¿Å¿es, by
the act it Å¿elfe, or Å¿ome other violent preÅ¿umption) and to ff. de ventre inÅ¿piciendo, cuÅ¿todiendo
que partu. ff. de â¢ fficio proconÅ¿uls, l. nequicquam Â§. de plano. nouriÅ¿h and maintaine the Å¿ame; but if the fault appeare againÅ¿t her, and it be Å¿o Å¿entenced by the Judge, then may he as well refuÅ¿e the one as the other: but for other children upon whom there is no Å¿uch doubt, the Parents may bee conÅ¿trained to maintaine, clothe, and feed them, and to Å¿et them out a portion of their goods, Å¿o that either the State and facultie of the Parents will beare it, or the children have not deÅ¿erved to the contrary, wherefore they Å¿hould not in that Å¿ort be provided for. And as the Father in this Å¿ort is bound unto the Childe; Å¿o the Childe againe is obliged unto his Parents, to provide for their Å¿uÅ¿tenance, Å¿o far forth as their abilitie will reach unto: for it is very unnatural, that the Parents Å¿hould want, Å¿o long as the children have meanes to releeve them. In both which caÅ¿es, if either the Parents refuÅ¿e to admit of their children, or the children againe refuÅ¿e to yeeld comfort unto their Parents, the Judge may interpoÅ¿e his authoritie, and injoyne each to maintaine other according to their ability, and as to his diÅ¿cretion Å¿hall Å¿eeme meet, which if any of them Å¿hould deny to yeeld unto, the Judge may, be DiÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿e of their goods taken and Å¿old to the value thereof, compell them to performe his order: and yet that onely in caÅ¿e of Maintenance, and not to diÅ¿charge debts, wherein either of them Å¿tand bound unto their creditors.

And if he Å¿ell ought of thoÅ¿e things which he ought not to Å¿ell, he may not Å¿ell it but by the decree of the Judge, interpoÅ¿ed upon the Å¿ame, and upon juÅ¿t cauÅ¿e proved before him: wherin if it appeare after, the Judge was abuÅ¿ed, by any falÅ¿e allegation and corrupt teÅ¿timony, the Å¿ale is void, and the Minor, when he comes to his full age, or within 5. yeares after, may reverÅ¿e & recover that which is thus Å¿old by colluÅ¿ion, out of the hands of him, to whom it was Å¿old, as being done againÅ¿t the authority of the Law. And that it may be better underÅ¿tood, how preciÅ¿e the Law is in this point, and what things it alloweth may bee Å¿old without the decree of the Judge, & what not, I will Å¿et downe the words of the Law it Å¿elfe, Å¿peaking of Tutors and Governors of Puples; whoÅ¿e place Executors & AdminiÅ¿trators do Å¿upply, Å¿o far forth, as they have the tuition & governance of Minors, during their under-age, faithfully tranÅ¿lated. And it is a law of ConÅ¿tantine the great, reproving a former law of S â¢ v ãâ¦ã
the Emperour, C. de adminiÅ¿trat. tutorum, vel curatorum. ãâã . lex qua. which gave leave to Tutors and Curators to Å¿ell away all the gold, Å¿ilver, precious Å¿tone, apparell, & otherrich moveables
the TeÅ¿tator had, and to bring the Å¿ame into money, which turned greatly to the hinderance of many Orphans: whereupon ConÅ¿tantine, after he had firÅ¿t ordered, that nothing Å¿hould bee Å¿old of the pearle, precious Å¿tone, naperi â¢ , utenÅ¿els of the houÅ¿e & other neceÅ¿Å¿ary Å¿tuffe & ornaments of the Å¿ame, Å¿aith thus. Neither Å¿hall it be lawfull for them, (meaning the Tutors or Curators) to Å¿ell the houÅ¿e wherein the Father died, and the childe grew up, wherein it is woe enough to the childe not to Å¿ee his AnceÅ¿tours images not faÅ¿tened up, or elÅ¿e pull'd downe. Therefore let the houÅ¿e, & all other his moveable goods Å¿till remaine in the Patrimonie of the childe, neither let any edifices or buildings, which came in good reparation with the inheritance, ruine or decay by colluÅ¿ion of the Tutor: but rather if the Father, or hee whoÅ¿oever the minor was heire unto, left any building in decay, let the Tutor both by the TeÅ¿timony of the worke it Å¿elfe, and the â¢ aith of many be compelled to repaire it: for Å¿o the yearly rent will bring in more profit to the Minor, than the price of the things being deceitfully Å¿old under-foot, will doe the Minor any good. Neither doth this Law onely make proviÅ¿ion againÅ¿t Tutors, but alÅ¿o againÅ¿t immodeÅ¿t & intemperate women, which many times gage unto their new married husbands, not only their owne Å¿tate, but even the Å¿tate and lives of their children. Further, it croÅ¿Å¿eth the courÅ¿e of putting the childrens money to uÅ¿ury (notwithÅ¿tanding anciently it was thought, therein conÅ¿iÅ¿ted all the Å¿trength of the Patrimony) for that courÅ¿e is Å¿eldome long, Å¿carcely continuall and Å¿table, and that thereby many times the money being loÅ¿t, the childrens Å¿tate comes to nothing: and therefore his concluÅ¿ion is, The Tutor Å¿hould Å¿ell nothing, without the order of the Judge, Å¿aving the TeÅ¿tators over-worne apparell, or thoÅ¿e things, which by keeping could not be kept from corruption, and Å¿uch cattell as were Å¿uperfluous. Whereby it appeareth, how carefull that age was, not to give way to Executors by Å¿ale of the TeÅ¿tators goods, to make gaine of the Orphans; neither is this age better than that; but that which was feared then, may bee
provided for now, by like authoritie as was then.

In this Land a man dying, leaving Legacies to his children, and his wife Executrix, or dying inteÅ¿tate, and Å¿hee taking adminiÅ¿tration, and in her Å¿econd marriage bringing all her firÅ¿t husbands Å¿tate, and her childrens portions unto her Å¿econd husband, & then dying, there is no remedy againÅ¿t the Å¿econd husband, to recover the Å¿aid Legacies or portions due unto the children out of his hands, becauÅ¿e he is neither Executor nor AdminiÅ¿trator, and that he came not to thoÅ¿e goods by wrong, but by the delivery of the Executrix, with whom he married: but yet by the Civile Law there is, and L Å¿i & me ff. de rebus creditis Å¿i certum petatur. that by this claime, that the Å¿aid goods came unto his hands, & that it is no reaÅ¿on, any Å¿hould be made rich by my goods againÅ¿t my will: for Legataries have no action againÅ¿t any, as AdminiÅ¿trators in their own wrong, or hinderers of the performance of the laÅ¿t Will of the deceaÅ¿ed, but Executors onely, and they then alone, when the party having it, holds it by wrong, and not by lawfull delivery, which in this caÅ¿e is otherwiÅ¿e.

By the Law of this Land, there is no proviÅ¿ion to preÅ¿erve the Å¿tate of a prodigall perÅ¿on from Å¿poile, which neither hath regard of time, nor end of Å¿pending, unleÅ¿Å¿e the Father provide for this miÅ¿chiefe in his Will, or by Å¿ome other good order in his life, but he is Å¿uffered to waÅ¿te and Å¿pend his goods untill there be nothing left (as though the Prince and Common wealth had no intereÅ¿t in Å¿uch a Å¿ubject, to Å¿ee hee did not waÅ¿te his Å¿tate, and abuÅ¿e his goods) whereby many great houÅ¿es are overthrowne, and many children whom the Fathers carefully provided for, never leaving raking and Å¿craping all their life time, that their children after them might live in great plentie and abundance, come to great Å¿hame and beggerie. I finde an old practice auciently uÅ¿ed in the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Courts, for reÅ¿training Executors or AdminiÅ¿trators for dealing covenouÅ¿ly in an ExecutorÅ¿hip or AdminiÅ¿tratorÅ¿hip, when there are more Executors named in a Will, than one, or more AdminiÅ¿trators deputed by the Ordinary in an AdminiÅ¿tration than one, which were well if it were recalled, and brought backe to his former uÅ¿e againe. And yet there is no remedie for this in Law, Å¿o farre as I know, for that all theÅ¿e making but one perÅ¿on in Law, the Law yeelds no action to the one to Å¿ue the other: but yet the ancient practiÅ¿e of the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law hath remedie, which would redreÅ¿Å¿e all this miÅ¿chiefe, if it were called again to uÅ¿e, & might goe without controlmeÌt, as the equity of the cauÅ¿e doth require. And the remedie is this, that Å¿uch other of the Executors
or AdminiÅ¿trators as are in this Å¿ort interverted from the execution of the Will, or AdminiÅ¿tration by the Å¿ubtiltie of any like Executor or AdminiÅ¿trator, Å¿hould crave the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of the Judge, and will him by vertue of his office, to call in Å¿uch practique Executor or AdminiÅ¿trator, and to command him under paine of excommunication, hee proceed no further in the Å¿ole execution thereof, but communicate all his acts, and dealings with the reÅ¿t of his Coexecutors or CoadminiÅ¿trators: which if it were Å¿o ordered, would make many mens Wills and AdminiÅ¿trations better performed than they are, and a great Å¿ort of poore Orphans Å¿tates more Å¿ure and certaine, than commonly they are in Å¿uch Executors or AdminiÅ¿trators hands.

And certainly in this caÅ¿e, there is Å¿ome good uÅ¿e of SuperviÅ¿ors in dead mens Wils (whom many men meerly jeÅ¿tar, calling them candle-holders, as though they could do nothing elÅ¿e in the execution therof, but hold the candle while the Executors tell the Defuncts mony) if they might be permitted to put in practiÅ¿e that authoritie which the Law giveth them, and that is when they finde any Executor deale fraudulently in the execution of any TeÅ¿tators Will, wherein they are named Å¿uperviÅ¿ors, or do ingroÅ¿Å¿e all the Å¿tate of the Defunct into his hands, as hath beene before Å¿aid, they call him to a particular account, that it may be Å¿eene how the adminiÅ¿tration Å¿tands, and each Executor may commumunicate to other particular receipts and disburÅ¿ements: which if any Å¿hall refuÅ¿e to do, then may the SuperviÅ¿or make thereof complaint unto the Judge, as though the Å¿ame man dealt not truly in the execution thereof, who though perhaps in the beginning could not take bond of him, for ff De adminiÅ¿tratione tutorum. l. 3. Â§. 1. the true execution of the Will (becauÅ¿e the TeÅ¿tator had made choice of him, and therein approved his faith, and that no man required caution of him for any Legacie in the Will be queathed, in which caÅ¿e the Judge might take bond of him for Å¿ecuritie of Å¿uch Lagacies as are bequeathed in the Will, yea though his faith hath beene approved by the Ordinarie, as hath beene before remembred) yet may the

And Å¿o farre as concerning thoÅ¿e things wherein the Civile, and the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law might be relieved, without prejudice to the Common Law, for becauÅ¿e they have no practiÅ¿e thereofâª and yet do not I bring forth theÅ¿e as the onely cauÅ¿es wherein the Civile and EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law may be licenced to deale in, over and beÅ¿ides the practiÅ¿e of thoÅ¿e things that they have already, but that theÅ¿e are few among many other which might be Å¿orted out, if Å¿o be there were any hope for the further enlargement of the profeÅ¿Å¿ion.

div.head: CHAP. III.

argument.p: Of the neceÅ¿Å¿itie of retaining the practiÅ¿e of the Civile and EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law in this Land.

div.p: BUt now to the neceÅ¿Å¿itie of the maintenance of the Civile and EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law in this Realme, as they are now practiÅ¿ed, or ought to be practiÅ¿ed, which was a thing firÅ¿t propounded, but laÅ¿t put in execution in this worke.

Albeit that which hath beene already Å¿aid as concerning the Civile and EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law may well imply the neceÅ¿Å¿arie preÅ¿ervation of them both within this Land, yet becauÅ¿e it was a thing I promiÅ¿ed to Å¿hew in the beginning of this TreatiÅ¿e, after that I had gone over the reÅ¿t of the
parts of my diviÅ¿ion, I will in a word or two make plaine the neceÅ¿Å¿itie thereof.

And therefore for a ground of all the reÅ¿t, I will aÅ¿Å¿ume this for a matter confeÅ¿Å¿ed, that every man knowes, that every well ordered Common-wealth Å¿tands on two parts principally, the politick part, which conÅ¿iÅ¿teth of the Prince and people, and the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall part which Å¿tandeth in Sacris & Sacerdotibus. And therefore well Å¿aid the Emperour, Two of the greateÅ¿t things that God ever gave unto In authent. quon. oport. EpiÅ¿copod in prin. col. 1. Auth. de non alienand. &c. rebut Eccl. c. 2. Â§. 1. the world (meaning earthly things) was the Empire or Å¿ecular government whereby the outward man is ordered and made, as AriÅ¿totle Å¿aith, bonus civis, that is, a good and loyall Å¿ubject: and the PrieÅ¿thood whereby the inward man is ruled, and is made, as the Å¿aid Author teÅ¿tifieth, bonus vir, that is, a good and vertuous man, which are two wonderfull effects of the whole government in generall; neither can the one of theÅ¿e be wanting, but the other will be ruinated and brought to deÅ¿olation.

Secondly, no man is ignorant of this, but in politique government two things Å¿way the whole Å¿tate, the one is peace at home, and the other is warre abroad: which as they have their Å¿eaÅ¿ons, Å¿o they have their cauÅ¿es and effects, the one from counÅ¿ell at home, the other from diÅ¿cipline abroad; neither can the one, or the other of theÅ¿e be maintained, but by their private and proper Lawes.

BeÅ¿ide, in peace who Å¿eeth not, there is as much need of vent by Å¿ea, for to benefit the Common-wealth by, either by importation of thoÅ¿e things that wee want at home, or by exportation of thoÅ¿e things wee abound with; as there is proviÅ¿ion to be made for the increaÅ¿ing and preÅ¿erving of thoÅ¿e things that wee have riÅ¿ing and growing by land in our owne countrie, neither of which can be had or injoyed without their proper Lawes fit and appertaining to either policie? And what Law is there that ordereth theÅ¿e buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿es but the Civile Law onely, which giveth a forme to Navigation, and all occurrents that happen by Å¿ea, whether they be in, or about the Navigation it Å¿elfe or the concontracts,
or as it were contracts that are made in, upon, or beyond the Å¿ame.

As a Legall forme is requiÅ¿ite in peace at home, and Marine affaires abroad, that every thing may have his due effect according to the right thereof, Å¿o alÅ¿o it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary in warlike exploits upon the Sea, that every action have his limits and bounds, whereby JuÅ¿tice may bee miniÅ¿tred: which if it be to be obÅ¿erved where lawfull warre is held betweene Prince and Prince, that every one be not left unto his owne luÅ¿t, much more is it expedient to be put in ure in Piracies and other Sea-robberies, where the innocent is Å¿poyled, and the Å¿poiler is enriched. The redreÅ¿Å¿e whereof is not, but by the Admirall Law, to whom the Princes of this Land have granted that authoritie.

For the often commerce of Princes with Princes, & the negotiation that one State hath with an other, there is nothing more neceÅ¿Å¿ary, than frequent EmbaÅ¿Å¿ages, wereby intelligence may be had what danger one State intendeth to an other, & how the Å¿ame may be prevented by Leagues or otherwiÅ¿e, and how the Å¿ame may be made and maintained: I know not what Law Å¿erves better for all theÅ¿e ends and purpoÅ¿es than the Civile Law.

In matters that appertaine to the Å¿oules health, the Preacher teacheth out of the word of God, wherein the right Å¿ervice of God Å¿tandeth, hee miniÅ¿treth the Sacraments unto the people, and inÅ¿tructeth them in other fundamentall points of Religion. but it is the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law that compelleth men to the due obÅ¿ervance hereof, and puniÅ¿heth the trangreÅ¿Å¿ors.

All men grant, that there is a proviÅ¿ion to be made for the MiniÅ¿ter, for that it is againÅ¿t reaÅ¿on that any man Å¿hould goe to warfare on his charges: but it is the Law of the Church that Å¿ets out this proviÅ¿ion, and yeeldeth remedie for the recoverie thereof, if it be denied.

Nothing is more due unto the dead, than that their laÅ¿t Wils Å¿hould be obÅ¿erved; for that it is Å¿uch an ordinance as a man hath not in his power againe, when God hath once called him hence, neither is there any thing that Princes
have more gratiouÅ¿ly granted unto their Å¿ubjects, than that in their life-time they may diÅ¿poÅ¿e of that which after they are dead, is none of theirs; and yet Å¿hall take place when they are not, as though yet they were theirs: in which proviÅ¿ion the Civile and the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Law, are above all other Lawes moÅ¿t religious.

ChriÅ¿tening, Wedding, Burying, whereby a man entreth into this world, converÅ¿eth in the world, and returneth againe unto the earth, from whence he was taken, and Å¿o after paÅ¿Å¿eth to glorie, and everlaÅ¿ting bliÅ¿Å¿e, are every one of the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall cogniÅ¿ance.

How many men of great skill, Å¿uch as few Princes have greater in all kinde of learning, are of this ranke, not only in the Å¿ocietie of them that profeÅ¿Å¿e this knowledge here in the chiefeÅ¿t Citie of the Land, but alÅ¿o in both the UniverÅ¿ities, and in Å¿undry other places of this Realme, not Å¿trangers, or forrainers, but home-borne Å¿ubjects, of the Å¿ame faith, of the Å¿ame religion, of the Å¿ame kindred, and familie, of like alleagiance to the Prince, and Å¿ervice to the Commonwealth as other his good Å¿ubjects are, even thoÅ¿e that oppugne this profeÅ¿Å¿ion chiefly; whoÅ¿e practice, if it be overthrowne, or proviÅ¿ion leÅ¿Å¿ened, not onely thoÅ¿e that are now preÅ¿ent, & make profeÅ¿Å¿ion of this knowledge Å¿hall be faine to turne their copie, but thoÅ¿e that are futurely to come, will change their profeÅ¿Å¿ion, when they Å¿ee there is no reward or eÅ¿timation belonging thereto? for it is honour that nouriÅ¿heth Arts, and no man will follow that profeÅ¿Å¿ion that is out of count, and credit; but every Father will Å¿ay unto his Son in like Å¿ort as Ovids Father Å¿aid to him, when hee Å¿aw him addict and give himÅ¿elfe wholy to Poetrie, Studium quid inutile tent as? It was anciently Å¿aid of the profeÅ¿Å¿ion of theÅ¿e Lawes, Dat JuÅ¿tinianus honores; but now it is Å¿o far off from that, that it conferres honours, as that it is almoÅ¿t a diÅ¿cre. dit for any man to be a Civilian in this State, and the profeÅ¿Å¿ion thereof doth Å¿carce keepe beggerie from the gate.

As God doth diÅ¿poÅ¿e his government by juÅ¿tice & mercie (whoreof notwithÅ¿tanding mercie hath the Å¿upreme place in the Lords Tabernacle, as that which was put above
upon the Arke, wherein were the two Tables of Å¿tone, in which the Law was written, to which St James alluding, Exod 25.
